PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 9 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Dickson Community Centre
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Australian Capital Territory: Dickson Community Centre
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the citizens of North Canberra respectfully showeth that of all regions in Canberra the area has the highest percentage of aged pensioners, invalid pensioners, widow B (women over 50) pensioners, sickness benefits pensioners and unemployed. In addition, it has above average youth unemployment levels, a greater proportion of non-nuclear families (including single households, couples without children, single parents and group households), and extensive expanses of households with an annual income of less than $6,000. There is only one two-room, converted C.S.I.R.O. workshop in the area to meet the needs of 45,000 people for general purpose community facilities.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that a Regional Community Centre be built at Dickson and that it be included in the forthcoming Budget.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rate of Duty on Old Cars and Parts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in the Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned citizens of Queensland, do respectfully pray that the present concessional import duty as exists under By-Law BL8255510 be maintained and not lapse on June 30, 1985 as presently planned by the Australian Customs Service. This by-law has permitted goods under Item 19 to be imported at a 2 per cent rate of duty and has greatly benefitted the Veteran, Vintage and Old Car Movement in the restoration of vehicles of 30 years age or more. While many automobile parts are produced in Australia, it is impractical to suggest they could be used during restoration of most old cars. It is reprehensible that this action should occur without debate, consultation or fair warning.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the concessional rate of duty on old cars and parts be maintained
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows that there is a need to end the current discriminatory application of sales tax on confectionery and to end the other anomalies existing in sales tax law. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled support a change in existing legislation so that this tax be replaced by a broad-based consumption tax with a uniform ad valorem rate without any exemptions whatsoever.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Harradine (from 14 citizens), Hill (from 13 citizens) and Richardson (from 472 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:
1. The Hawke Government's retirement incomes policies are piecemeal, inequitable, and discriminate against people who save towards achieving reasonable self-reliance in their retirement and
2. The Government's assets test legislation is particularly inequitable and its effects are especially discriminatory against farmers.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, will call upon the Government to:
1. Repeal the assets test legislation;
2. Institute a broad inquiry into Australia's retirement income and taxation systems; and

3. Following the receipt of the report of such an inquiry implement a retirement incomes policy which is fair and equitable, encourages self-provision and will be non-discriminatory in its operation and impact.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. We affirm our belief that, in Jesus Christ, human sexuality is placed in the context of mutual loving relationships and therefore Christians reject any form of pornography which depicts violence against adults and/or children and the economic, physical and spiritual exploitation which is basic to hard-core pornography.
2. We urge the Parliament to prohibit the importation or production of this kind of pornography.

3. We request the Parliament to continue a public inquiry during 1985 to report on the operation of Regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 in relation to video tapes and video discs which have been refused classification or classified ''X'' by the Film Censorship Board.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Additional Capital Gains Taxes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
They adversely affect the small and medium businesses in Australia, destroying incentives and discouraging investment in this important area of the Economy;
The Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

Any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not 'windfall gains' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
The owners of small businesses often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell their business to sustain them in retirement;
Your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Brownhill (from 189 citizens) and Robertson (from 18 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Governments failure to act to correct the anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions bring to its notice and due to have effect from the 21 March, 1985 the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners, and calls upon the Australian Democrats to support Senator Messner's bill for the abolition of the Assets Test.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the passage of the Social Security and Repatriation Assets Test Abolition Bill to repeal the Labor Governments iniquitous unfair Assets Test. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 36 citizens) and Messner (from 29 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Abortion Clinic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the under signed citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned who have great concern for the protection of the unborn child, call upon the Government to reject the Vinson Enquiry recommendation that an Abortion Clinic be established in Canberra.
And your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will reject this recommendation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That human embryos deserve legal protection to enable the development of their full human potential.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should: Pass Senator Harradine's Bill to prohibit experiments involving the use of human embryos created by in vitro fertilisation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I withdraw Business of the Senate notice of motion No. 1 standing in my name for this day of sitting for disallowance of the Extradition (Republic of South Africa) Regulations. I seek leave to make a brief statement about this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —These regulations allow the Government to extradite a fugitive to South Africa. The Regulations and Ordinances Committee was concerned to ensure that the regulations were protective of the rights of persons in Australia. The Committee asked the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to make provision for reciprocity in minimum and maximum penalties and to incorporate in the regulations a set of model protective provisions taken from current treaties. The Attorney-General has agreed to amend the regulations to explicitly state certain protections and safeguards which are normally found in extradition treaties. An undertaking has also been given to amend the Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966 to provide that an extradition crime will be one where the minimum penalty is at least 12 months imprisonment, not merely in the requesting country but also in Australia, had the offence been committed in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In a further letter amplifying these undertakings the Attorney-General has also agreed to amend the regulations to include provisions which will provide that extradition will not be granted for offences which are tried by other than normal criminal courts or for offences which attract cruel, unusual or grossly unjustifiable punishments. The Committee considers that this latter exemption is sufficient to meet its concern in relation to the situation where the maximum penalty in South Africa is grossly and unjustifiably greater than the maximum penalty under Australian law. The other humanitarian restrictions, based on article 4 of the model treaty, and which will be incorporated in the amended regulations, relate to mental illness, age, offences solely against military law, the statute of limitations, trial by provisional courts and other matters.

The Committee acknowledges that the Government needs effective extradition powers in the interests of international comity and domestic law enforcement. In relation to South Africa, however, the Committee was particularly concerned that the Attorney-General should actually put into the regulations a range of reasonable protections and safeguards for persons facing extradition proceedings instigated by the South African Government. In his undertakings to the Committee the Attorney-General has agreed to do this. The Committee understands that, while new regulations are being drafted, the Attorney-General, in exercising his existing discretion under the present Act and regulations, will take into account all of the safeguards and protections which will later be incorporated in the Act and the regulations and which are referred to in this statement. The Committee considers that this will ensure that that quality of just and considered treatment, which the Committee felt should have been expressly provided for in the original regulations, will in fact be accorded to any fugitive who is dealt with before the regulations can be amended.

The Committee looks forward to examining the recast Extradition (Republic of South Africa) Regulations when they are tabled in the Parliament. The Committee commends the Attorney-General for his ready co-operation in this matter and acknowledges the contributions made by his specialist extradition legal officers who discussed the Regulations with the Committee. The co-operation of the Department of Foreign Affairs is also acknowledged by the Committee. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the Committee's and the Minister's letters in order to record for the information of honourable senators the issues which were discussed between us.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA . THE SENATE
STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES
Lionel Bowen, M.P. 15 May 1985 Attorney-General
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
At its meeting on 9 May 1985 the Committee considered the Extradition (Republic of South Africa) Regulations (Statutory Rules 1985 No. 14).

The Committee would appreciate your advice as to whether 'the offence' for the purposes of paragraph 4 (1) (a) of the Regulations is one which is punishable in South Africa by a maximum penalty of not less than 12 months, regardless of any minimum penalty such an offence might attract in Australia.

The Committee acknowledges that there are arguments tending to support the view that the penalty referred to in paragraph 4 (1) (a) is a reciprocal minimum because 'the offence' may mean the offence both as committed in South Africa and had it been committed in Australia (see for example the omission of the phrase ''against the law of, or of a part of, a foreign state'' which, in section 4 of the Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966 follows the word 'offence'; and the deletion from paragraphs 3 (a) and 3 (b) of the Extradition (Brazil) Regulations (S.R. 1974 No. 130) of the phrase ''for which extradition of the person is requested'' (S.R. 1983 No. 166).

There are also arguments tending to support the view that the drafting does not encompass reciprocity of this minimum penalty (see the drafting in Treaties which expressly allow for reciprocity; and new paragraph 4 (1A) (a) of the Act, awaiting Proclamation, which appears not to be a reciprocal minimum penalty provision).

Neither the Explanatory Memorandum, nor the Second Reading Speech in connection with the Extradition (Foreign States) Amendment Act 1985 clarify this issue. The Explanatory Statement attached to the Regulations themselves is very short and inadequate.
The Committee would welcome any advice or assistance you can offer to assist the Committee on this matter.

If, as a matter of statutory interpretation, there is no reciprocity in paragraph 4 (1) (a) of the Regulations, the Committee would ask you to consider an amendment to achieve reciprocity so that extradition to South Africa could not arise where the penalty for the offence, if it had been committed in Australia, is less than 12 months imprisonment.

In examining these regulations the Committee also queries whether reciprocal or substantially reciprocal maximum penalty provisions may not be as important as the double-criminality rule in protecting the personal rights and liberties of a person who is the subject of extradition proceedings. The Committee recognises that double-criminality is provided for in paragraph 4 (1A) (a) of the Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966 (or paragraph 4 (1A) (b) of the Act as amended but not yet proclaimed). As such it is a fundamental protection of the rights of a fugitive.

The Committee appreciates that reciprocal extradition powers are crucial to international comity and effective domestic law enforcement. However, the Committee is concerned that the absence of reciprocal maximum penalty provisions may upset the balance between effective law enforcement and the protection of personal liberties.

This may be all the more likely to arise in regard to a country like South Africa, where the legal system and the humaneness of legislative and judicial penal policy have been the subject of long standing controversy. The Committee asks whether, for such a country, it would not be highly desirable to require that extradition be permitted only where the maximum penalty which is a guilty fugitive could receive would be substantially equivalent to the maximum penalty which an Australian court could impose if the offence had been committed within an Australian jurisdiction.

The Committee recognises that disparity in the penal provisions of relevant foreign states may make the inclusion of reciprocal maximum penalty provisions problematic. However, requirements about obtaining assurances that the death penalty will not be carried out, which appear to be standard in Treaties and Regulations, may provide a precedent for the kind of safeguard the Committee seeks with respect to penalties in South Africa.

The Committee would welcome your advice on this matter. Perhaps you could comment on the suggestion that an additional paragraph could be added to the Regulations to provide that where the offence is punishable by imprisonment for a period that is substantially longer than the maximum period imposed in Australia for such an offence, then a fugitive should not be surrendered to South Africa unless assurances, satisfactory to Australia, are given by South Africa that the person will not serve a longer imprisonment than the person would have served in Australia.
The Committee recognises that there may be difficulties associated with parole and other devices which, in Australia, reduce the actual period of imprisonment.

The Committee feels however, that some rule as to substantial equivalence of penalty should operate in the interests of personal rights and liberties of persons in Australia who are to be extradited to South Africa. The Committee would welcome your views on this suggestion.

The Committee would also welcome your advice on whether or not it would be feasible to incorporate in the Extradition (Republic of South Africa) Regulations, a set of model provisions, based on the range of protective provisions in current treaties. These would be model provisions offering Treaty-type protections additional to those referred to above.

The Committee appreciates that it is raising complex issues in a specialist area of the law. In order to assist the Committee in determining whether its principles should be applied to the Extradition (Republic of South Africa) Regulations the Committee asks if you would agree to one or more of your officers, experienced in these matters, attending the Committee's meeting at 8.30 am on Thursday 23 May 1985 in Senate Committee Room 6 to assist the Committee.
JOHN COATES
Chairman
DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER ATTORNEY-GENERAL PARLIAMENT HOUSE CANBERRA 2600
Dear John,

I refer to your letter of 15 May 1985 in which you raised certain matters of concern to the Senate Committee on Regulations and Ordinances in relation to the Extradition (Republic of South Africa) Regulations. Officers of my Department and the Department of Foreign Affairs attended on your Committee on 23 May and, as a result of that meeting and your letter I have approved a certain course of action.

I am seeking approval for an amendment to the Extradition (Foreign States) Act, (the EFS Act) to be made in the Budget Session Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill, to provide that the definitions of extradition crime and extraditable crime in sections 4 and 20 of the EFS Act will now require that there be reciprocal minimum penalties of imprisonment for not less than 12 months.

Following conclusion of the extradition agreement with South Africa the Extradition (Republic of South Africa) Regulations will be amended to similarly provide for reciprocal penalties. At the same time those Regulations will be recast to provide for certain protections and safeguards which are normally found in extradition treaties but which are not incorporated in the EFS Act. I would propose to forward a draft of these Regulations to your Committee for comment before they are made.

Finally, I am advised by my officers that your Committee accepted the reasons given for not requiring South Africa to give undertakings that a greater penalty would not be imposed on a person extradited to South Africa than that which could be imposed in Australia.
I thank your Committee for bringing these matters to my attention and trust that the action I have approved will meet the concerns expressed by the Committee.
Yours sincerely,
(Lionel Bowen)
Senator John Coates,Chairman,Senator Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances,Parliament House,Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER ATTORNEY-GENERAL PARLIAMENT HOUSE CANBERRA 2600
Dear John,

In my letter to you of 27 May 1985 in respect of the Extradition (Republic of South Africa) Regulations I advised that those Regulations would be recast to explicitly state certain protections and safeguards which are normally found in extradition treaties but some of which are not incorporated in the Extradition (Foreign States) Act.

I now write in amplification of that letter to indicate that the types of protections that are proposed to be included will be based on Article 4 of the model Treaty which I have approved to form the basis of negotiations with other countries. A copy of that Article is attached. I might add that the matters dealt with in paragraphs 4 (1) (a) to (1) (d) inclusive and paragraphs 4 (2) (d) and (2) (f) are safeguards already incorporated in the Extradition (Foreign States) Act and hence are already applicable. However, in this specific case, I can see justification for repeating them in the Regulations.

In addition I propose that the Regulations will provide that extradition will not be granted for offences which are tried by other than normal criminal courts or for offences which attract cruel, unusual or grossly unjustifiable punishments. The latter exemption should, in my view, be adequate to meet your Committee's concern in relation to the situation where the maximum penalty in South Africa is grossly and unjustifiably greater than the maximum penalty under Australian law.

In conclusion I should say that Rademeyer, if he is to be extradited, will be extradited in accordance with the Extradition (Foreign States) Act and the existing Extradition (Republic of South Africa) Regulations. Under that legislation my discretion to decide whether extradition shall take place is unfettered. In exercising that discretion, however, I can assure the Committee that I will take into account all the protections to which I have referred and which are to be included in the recast Extradition (Republic of South Africa) Regulations.
Yours sincerely,
(Lionel Bowen)
Senator John Coates,Chairman,Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I withdraw Business of the Senate notice of motion No. 2 standing in my name for this day of sitting for the disallowance of the Credit Ordinance 1985. I seek leave to make a statement in explanation of the withdrawal of the notice of motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the receipt late last night of further undertakings from the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) in relation to the Credit Ordinance, the Committee has decided to withdraw its notice of motion for disallowance. The Committee was concerned that a wide exemption power should be exercised only by regulations and should be made subject to tabling and disallowance; that exemptions should not be made until such an urgent amendment is put in place; that powers of entry using assistance or force should be authorised by a magistrate and be expressly qualified by an objective test of reasonableness; that a power to embark on 'fishing expeditions' in pursuance of a limited search warrant be restrained so that any additional material found on premises be placed in a sealed envelope and lodged with the registrar of a court pending a further warrant applying specifically to that material; and that all signatures should be witnessed and that a person signing vicariously should expressly state in writing that he or she does so by authority.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee had agreed to the Minister's undertakings urgently to amend the Ordinance to achieve these changes. The undertakings were received only late last night. The Committee decided that it would not recommend the application of principle (d) of the Committee's principles to the Ordinance.

While the Committee is of the opinion that the Ordinance does contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment, its disallowance would not serve the pressing interests of consumers in the Australian Capital Territory who would be deprived of important rights if the Ordinance were disallowed.

The Committee will table a full report on its scrutiny of the Credit Ordinance in the Budget sittings. The report will address the question whether, in the Australian Capital Territory, highly complex and detailed legislative proposals, which interlock with Commonwealth-State schemes, and make fundamental reform of significant areas of law, should take the form of a Bill in the Parliament rather than an ordinance. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard copies of some of the correspondence exchanged between the Minister, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Committee which will enable senators to be informed of the issues discussed and settled by the Committee.
Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows-
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA: THE SENATE
STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES
Gordon Scholes, M.P. 23 May 1985 Minister for Territories
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
As you know, the Committee met on 16 May 1985 to discuss with your officials issues arising from the application of the Committee's principles to the Credit Ordinance 1985.

At its meeting the Committee noted your letter of 15 May 1985 seeking to limit the questions which could be asked of these officials. While regretting this limitation, the Committee thanks you for your agreement to send officials to assist the Committee at its meeting.

The Committee met again on 21 May 1985 to complete its deliberations on the Ordinance. The Committee's Legal Adviser, Professor Douglas Whalan, attended this special meeting and advised the Committee.
The application of principle (d)

The application of principle (d) to Ordinances of the Australian Capital Territory has presented the Committee with difficulty because of the need to balance the width of the powers delegated to a Minister under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910 against the requirements of parliamentary scrutiny of delegated legislation. To be effective, such scrutiny of necessity calls for consideration of whether delegated legislation contains matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment. Notwithstanding the comments made in paragraph 3 of your letter concerning your belief that legislation applicable to the A.C.T. should take a certain form, Ordinances in the Territory are not immune from such scrutiny or from the application by the Committee of principle (d).

When considering the application of principle (d) to an Ordinance, the Committee, on behalf of the Senate, exercises a judgment in respect of the substance of the matters contained in the Ordinance and the propriety of such matters becoming law by virtue of ministerial decree rather than by parliamentary procedure. It may be impossible to lay down hard and fast rules to dictate, for all possible cases, what should or should not become law under delegated powers. However, it is neither impossible nor unreasonable to conclude that the Credit Ordinance 1985, being, in the words of the acting Minister for Territories, ''among the most fundamental and far reaching reforms of the law undertaken in this country'' contains matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment.

The Committee appreciates that a universally agreed position has not been reached on the application of principle (d) to ACT Ordinances but it is of the opinion that the change to the credit law was of such importance that it should have been by means of a Bill.

The Committee therefore again invites you to consider the urgent preparation of a Bill for introduction into the Parliament as a more appropriate means of legislating for those matters currently contained in the Credit Ordinance. Such a Bill could be in terms identical to the Credit Ordinance, though the Committee would prefer to see those terms amended to take account of the Committee's specific concerns in relation to sections 19, 29, 235 and 250 as discussed in the attached pages.

The Committee would welcome an undertaking that such a Bill will be introduced. It is the Committee's opinion that, from the point of view of your Department, the credit industry and consumers, this course would be preferable to a full scale disallowance debate in the Senate on 28 May 1985.
Comments on individual sections

The Committee maintains its concern about certain aspects of the legislation, namely sections 19, 29, 235 and 250. The Committee's explanation of its specific objections are set out in the attached pages.
Other matters

In connection with section 135 and the express references in sub-sections (1) and (2) to the balance of probability, the Committee would be grateful if it could sight a copy of the Attorney-General's legal advice which stated that the express inclusion of the words ''on the balance of probability'' would not upset the inference of the civil standard of proof in other sections, although its deletion, against the background of a uniform scheme of State legislation, would upset that inference in section 135 itself.
JOHN COATES
Chairman
Regulations and Ordinances Committee
Credit Ordinance 1985
Specific provisions of concern to the Committee
Section 19

The Committee remains of the view that the powers of exemption conferred by section 19 of the Ordinance are extremely wide and unless exercised by regulations subject to tabling and disallowance, infringe the Committee's principles, in particular principle (b).

The present power of exemption confers upon this Minister, or any future Minister, a power to abrogate or to suspend, in any way, for any period, subject to any conditions, any provisions of the Ordinance, including those provisions which, being designed to protect borrowers, are the very raison d'etre of the Ordinance.

The fifteen exemptions made to date and notified in Gazette S 95 are drafted with the complexity and precision of regulations. They go so far as to exempt identified commercial organisations from specified sections of the Ordinance.

It may be that these exemptions are essential to the effective implementation of the new credit legislation. It may be that, although they temporarily limit the full range of protections available to a borrower under the Ordinance, they do not in the circumstances, unduly trespass on personal rights and liberties within the meaning of principle (b) of the Committee's principles. It may be that at no time in the future will any Minister, of any party, grant exemptions which could be objectionable in terms of civil liberties.

However, the Committee does not accept that such reasoning is persuasive. The Committee is charged by the Senate with a responsibility to address those questions of principle embodied in its terms of reference, and to this end the Committee applies its principles. This is not done in isolation from the real world but with an awareness of how the application of principle can avoid present and future infringements of personal rights and liberties.
The Committee again recommends to the Minister that exemptions be made by regulations subject to tabling and disallowance in Parliament in the usual way.
Regulations and Ordinances Committee
Credit Ordinance 1985
Specific provisions of concern to the Committee
Section 29

The Committee recognises that the expression ''becomes aware'' in section 29 of the Ordinance is used in federal legislation and is not peculiar to the New South Wales or Victorian parliamentary counsel. The Committee also accepts advice from the Attorney-General's Department that ''becomes aware'' is a concept preferable to that which the Committee was suggesting.

However, insofar as the section is intended to protect linked credit providers and creates a criminal offence to achieve this protection, the expression is not as precise as the word ''knows'', which is also used in sub-section 29 (1).

If the expression ''becomes aware'' is really a description of the point in time at which a person obtains knowledge of the fact of a recision etc., this could be more clearly and more certainly conveyed by an expression such as ''As soon as a supplier knows that . . .''
The Committee again recommends that the Minister consider the wording of the section.
Regulations and Ordinances Committee
Credit Ordinance 1985
Specific provisions of concern to the Committee
Section 235

With regard to sub-section 235 (1), the Committee considers that the degree and use of force, which the Director or an investigating officer ''thinks necessary'' to effect entry to premises in execution of a search warrant, should be qualified by reference to a standard of reasonableness as is the case in sub-section 385C (3) of the Crimes Act 1900 (N.S.W.) as it applies in the A.C.T. (see the Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance 1984, A.C.T. Ordinance No. 32 of 1984.
The degree of ''assistance'' that the Director or an investigating officer ''thinks necessary'' should also be qualified by a test of reasonableness.

The deeming provision in sub-section 235 (4) authorises the Director or an investigating officer to take ''things'' not specified in a Magistrate's warrant under sub-section (3), if the officer believes, on reasonable grounds, that the ''things'' are ''connected with another offence against this Ordinance''. This power confers on administrative officials greater powers than are available to a police officer in the execution of a search warrant under sub-section 358C (4) of the Crimes Act 1900 (N.S.W.) as it applies in the A.C.T.

The Committee does not suggest that the provisions of that Ordinance should be used as a model precedent, any more than it suggests that the relevant terms of the Criminal Investigation Bill be incorporated automatically and uncritically into any legislation which happens to empower administrative officials to obtain and execute search warrants. Except perhaps in the case of police officers, each case should be examined on its own merits to determine precisely what powers of entry, search and seizure are essential to permit effective law enforcement by administrative officials without prejudice to the rights of individuals.

As far as the Credit Ordinance is concerned, the Committee recommends that the Minister amend the legislation so that force and assistance be qualified by reasonableness and, with regard to ''things'' other than those specified in a warrant under paragraph 235 (3) (c), a sealed envelope procedure should be used, as referred to on page 3 of the Committee's letter of 22 March 1985.
In the light of advice from the Attorney-General's Department the Committee withdraws its objection to the possibility of a Magistrate's search warrant specifying a period after business hours.
Regulations and Ordinances Committee
Credit Ordinance 1985
Specific provisions of concern to the Committee
Section 250

Insofar as section 250 enables a person actually to sign another person's name as if the person signing were the very person whose signature is written, without the need to qualify that vicarious signature by reference to any relationship of principal and agent, the provision does not reflect the common law and is objectionable within the Committee's principles.

At common law the onus of proof would rest on the agent to show that he or she had sufficient authority to sign any particular document that was signed. Under section 250 the onus of proof would rest on the person to show that his or her ''signature'' was not a real signature and that the signatory did not in fact have authority to sign the signature of the person.

It appears to the Committee that, to the extent that this significant burden of proof is reversed, there is a fundamental distinction between the requirements of common law and the requirements of the section.

The Committee considers that the section could operate to the serious prejudice of a borrower, in particular, older pensioners or persons in need of that special protection which the presence of a witness can lend to the conclusion of binding and potentially onerous legal contracts. The protection afforded by section 124, which may preclude a salesperson from executing a vicarious signature, is not, in the Committee's opinion, sufficient protection from the kinds of fraud and undue influence which the current drafting of section 250 almost invites.

The Committee recommends that the Minister amend section 250 to require that a person, signing his or her own name on behalf and under the authority of another person, shall clearly state that such signing is under such authority.
The Committee also recommends that a witness be present, as a signatory, where documents giving rise to binding legal contracts are being signed.

Dear Senator Coates
Thank you for your letter of 23 May 1985 in which you have raised various matters relating to the Credit Ordinance 1985.

I am concerned that if I were to proceed as you have suggested and undertake to introduce a Bill in substantially the same terms as the Ordinance, there would be considerable potential for uncertainty and disruption in the ACT credit industry. This might flow from a perception that the Bill would not have a smooth passage through the Senate and might be considerably amended, particularly in the light of the objections that your Committee has already raised in relation to the Ordinance.

In your letter you have quoted a statement by Mr Duffy that the Ordinance is ''among the most fundamental and far reaching reforms of the law undertaken in this country''. I think I should point out that Mr Duffy did not apply this description specifically to the Credit Ordinance. Instead, he used the words in relation to the ''introduction of uniform credit legislation throughout Australia''. The Credit Ordinance gives effect to the Australian Capital Territory's participation in this scheme. Although it has been modelled on State legislation, its operation is exclusive to the ACT and has no wider application and it is for that reason that the legislation has been prepared as an Ordinance. For a number of years it has been the routine practice to implement proposals specifically affecting the ACT by way of Ordinance-notwithstanding that from some viewpoint some are capable of being described as innovative, significant or complex. If this practice were to be changed, the workload of the national Parliament would become significantly disrupted by the addition of Bills having purely local ACT effect and I don't believe that this would be in any of our interests.

Accordingly, I am unable to give a unilateral undertaking that a Bill will be introduced. The question is of such importance that I could not do so without consulting my Ministerial colleagues. Moreover, I do not believe that it is unreasonable to expect that further consideration of this matter should take place only in the context of a definitive statement from the Committee about the application of principle (d). This issue has such far reaching implications for the conduct of ACT portfolio responsibilities that it is inappropriate that it should be addressed on an ad hoc basis as it has been in this case.
In relation to the particular sections of the Credit Ordinance that the Committee has identified as causing it continuing concern I would comment as follows:
Section 19

I can understand why the Committee is concerned about section 19, and why it believes that exemptions created pursuant to the section should be subject to some form of scrutiny by the Parliament and I am prepared to have the legislation amended to overcome the Committee's objections in this regard.
Section 29
I have considered the points raised in the Committee's letter and I have no objection to amending the legislation to include the alternative formulation suggested by the Committee.
Section 235

In relation to sub-section 235 (1): The Committee seems to take the view that the words 'as he thinks' apply both to the need for assistance and to the use of force. This is not so in my view. It is not a matter for the executing officer alone to decide whether force is necessary to effect entry. In my view the question of whether the use of force is lawful is one to be determined totally objectively. The crucial question is whether, as a matter of face, force is necessary, not whether, in the view of the executing officer alone force is necessary.
I would have no objection to the provision being amended to read 'with such assistance as he thinks reasonably necessary and by such force as is reasonably necessary'.

In relation to sub-section 235 (4): The provision on which the Committee relies (s. 358C) is of very limited scope and applies only to search warrants to be executed in the ACT to obtain evidence of a specific offence committed in another jurisdiction. It is not the general provision which applies to search warrants in the ACT.
The provision contained in sub-section 235 (4) is modelled on sub-clause 58 (5) of the Criminal Investigation Bill 1981. Similar provisions exist in the following Ordinances-
1. Radiation Ordinance 1983 21 (4)
2. Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 53 (4)
3. Business Franchises (Tobacco and Petroleum Products) Ordinance 1984 53 (4)
4. Air Pollution Ordinance 1984 39 (4)
5. Water Pollution Ordinance 1984 34 (4).

The Provision also appears in numerous recent Commonwealth Acts. The provision does little more than restate the position at Common Law following Chic Fashions (West Wales) Ltd v Jones (1968) 2 QB 299.

The approach suggested by your Committee is one which has been adopted in relation to seized items in respect of which legal professional privilege has been claimed. No question of privilege can arise in relation to items seized as affording evidence of the commission of an offence under this provision.
Section 250

I do not agree that section 250 enables a person to sign for another without the need to qualify the vicarious signature by reference to a relationship of a principal or agent. The section expressly contemplates that the vicarious signature is to be effected ''by or under . . . authority''. It seems to me that the provision does reflect the common law and I do not think it offends any of the Committee's stated principles. Nevertheless, I am prepared to consult on the matter with the other uniform credit jurisdictions and with the Attorney-General. It may be that some formulation which would be acceptable both to the other jurisdictions and to the Committee could be devised.
Section 135

The Committee has asked if it could sight a copy of the Attorney-General's legal advice in relation to the expression ''on the balance of probability'' in section 135. The advice had been provided orally by an officer of the Attorney-General's Department and accordingly I am not in a position to let you see a copy of it. I am assured that the substance of it has been accurately stated in my letter to you.
Yours sincerely
GORDON SCHOLES

Dear John,

In view of the Committee's consideration of the Credit Ordinance 1985 in the context of principle (d) of the Committee's principles for the scrutiny of delegated legislation I think it would be appropriate to inform you of my views on this issue.
My concern is with the application of principle (d) as such, rather than the Credit Ordinance which is the responsibility of my colleague the Minister for Territories.

It has long been recognised by the Senate, your Committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs and responsible Ministers (from both sides of the Parliament) that the application of principle (d) to A.C.T. Ordinances raises very difficult questions.

Both my immediate predecessors, Senator Durack and Senator Gareth Evans, have in response to requests from the Committee, provided detailed analyses of the issues involved and given their views (which are to similar effect) to the Committee.

I agree with the opinions expressed by Senator Durack and Senator Evans. Senator Evans' letter of 19 April 1984 contains a cogent explanation of the important legal and other difficulties encountered in the application of principle (d). I would particularly draw to the Committee's attention the points made in that letter about the differences between A.C.T. Ordinances and regulations made under specific statutes, and the implications of disallowance on the ground of principle (d). I emphasise the view that application of principle (d) in its current form is inconsistent with the intention of the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910.

To adopt a view that Territory laws should be enacted by Parliament by reason of the intrinsic significance of the subject matter of those laws, which is what the application of principle (d) seems to require, would have significant implications for many of the laws which I administer. In particular, I would be concerned that this could lead to the conclusion that substantial changes in the criminal law of the A.C.T. should be made by the Parliament and not by Ordinance. No objection has previously been taken by the Committee to the enactment of even quite substantial changes in the criminal law by Ordinance. This illustrates, I think, the point which has been made to the Committee by both Senator Evans and Senator Durack that principle (d), in its present form, cannot satisfactorily be applied to the consideration of Territory Ordinances.

Moreover, I should draw the Committee's attention again to the practical difficulties which would follow from enactment of Territory law on a given subject matter by an Act of the Parliament. Unless the Act itself empowered the making of Ordinances inconsistent with the Act-which would be in breach of other principles adopted by the Committee-even minor changes in the law relating to the subject-matter might have to be dealt with by the Parliament itself. In relation to such subject matter, the application of principle (d) would have the effect that legislative responsibility for subject matter thus dealt with by an Act of Parliament would revert to the Parliament itself instead of being exercised by the Governor-General and that the Parliament would have a substantive role, rather than the supervisory role contemplated by the Seat of Government (Administration) Act.

Considerable uncertainty may result from the Parliament exercising a co-ordinate law making role with the Governor-General. I mention, by way of example, that the fact that the evidence law of the A.C.T. became embodied in the Australian Capital Territory Evidence (Temporary Provisions) Act 1972 meant not only that it was not possible directly to amend the Evidence Ordinance which was taken up by that Act, but also that there was considerable doubt about the power to include evidentiary provisions in other Ordinances. The matter eventually had to be dealt with by the Parliament amending the Act to permit Ordinances to amend or repeal the provisions of the Evidence Ordinance continued in force by that Act.
Yours sincerely LIONEL BOWEN

Thank you for your letter of 27 May 1985 about the Credit Ordinance 1985.

The Committee met this morning, 30 May 1985, and considered your letter, a letter from the Attorney-General of 29 May 1985 and the information provided to the Committee on 16 May 1985 and 28 May 1985 by officers from your Department and the Attorney-General's Department.
The Committee decided that it would not proceed with disallowance of the Credit Ordinance in its entirety under principle (d) of the Committee's terms of reference.
I will provide a full explanation for this later today in the Senate when the matter comes up.
The Committee will report to the Senate in the Budget sittings on the whole question of the application of principle (d) to ACT Ordinances.

The Senate, this morning, agreed to postpone until a later hour of this day its notice of disallowance in connection with the Credit Ordinance. The Committee proposes to seek leave to amend its notice to specify that certain provisions of the Ordinance be disallowed.

The Committee would, of course, prefer that the Government agree to urgent amendment of the Ordinance to take into account the Committee's concerns and thus avoid the real need for disallowance of provisions which infringe the Committee's principles.

The Committee will recommend to the Senate that it should disallow sections of the Ordinance unless a firm and clear commitment is given by the Government to the Committee urgently to amend the Ordinance.
Section 19

In your letter of the 27 May 1985 you wrote that you could understand why the Committee is concerned about section 19, and why it believes that exemptions created pursuant to the section should be subject to some form of scrutiny by the Parliament. Therefore you were prepared to have the legislation amended to overcome the Committee's objections in this regard.

The Committee seeks to have it made clear that this is a commitment by the Government, urgently to amend section 19 to require that exemptions be made by regulations, subject to tabling and disallowance in Parliament in the usual way, and that no further exemptions be made prior to an urgent amendment to the Ordinance.
Section 29

In your letter of 27 May 1985 you wrote that you had considered the points raised by the Committee and that you had no objection to amending the legislation to include an alternative formulation suggested by the Committee.

The Committee seeks to have it made clear that this is a commitment by the Government urgently to amend the sub-section 29 (1) to substitute for the phrase ''A supplier who becomes aware, that'', the expression-''As soon as a supplier knows that . . .'' in sub-section 29 (1). The words ''the supplier'' should be inserted before the words ''shall forthwith'' in sub-section 29 (1).
Section 235

In your letter of 27 May 1985 you wrote that you would have no objections to sub-section 235 (1) being amended to read ''with such assistance as (he) thinks reasonably necessary and by such force as is reasonably necessary''.

The Committee is of the view that the relevant provisions of the Criminal Investigation Bill should not be incorporated automatically and uncritically into any legislation which happens to empower public servants to obtain and execute search warrants.

Each case should be examined objectively on its merits to determine precisely what powers of entry, search and seizure are an essential minimum to permit effective law enforcement without undue trespass on the personal rights and liberties of individuals.

In the case of the Credit Ordinance the Committee considers that where a power of assisted or violent entry into premises is to be conferred on public servants, the use of that power should be determined objectively and not merely in the mind of the public servant.

The Committee seeks a commitment that the Government will urgently amend sub-section 235 (1) so that the power of assisted or violent entry into premises is expressly conferred by the Magistrate's warrant and the necessity for such entry is determined objectively in terms of both assistance and of the use of force.
The Committee remains of the view that section 235 generally and sub-section 235 (4) in particular confers inappropriate police powers on public servants.

The Committee seeks a commitment that the Government will urgently amend sub-section 235 (4) to provide for a sealed envelope procedure when an investigating officer intends to remove things not specified in a warrant. These things should be placed in the custody of a court registrar and returned to the premises unless within 24 hours, a magistrate has been persuaded to issue a further warrant in respect of those things.
Section 250

In your letter of 27 May 1985 you rejected the Committee's request for an amendment to provide that a signature be witnessed and that a person making a vicarious signature expressly state in writing that it is done by authority.

The Committee remains of the view that section 250 could operate to the serious prejudice of a borrower, in particular older pensioners or persons in need of that special protection which the presence of a witness can lend to the conclusion of binding and potentially onerous legal contracts. The protection afforded by section 124, which may preclude a salesperson from executing a vicarious signature, is not, in the Committee's opinion, sufficient protection from the kinds of fraud and undue influence which the current drafting of section 250 almost invites.

The Committee seeks a commitment from the Government that it will urgently amend this section to provide that a person's signature shall be witnessed, that the witness shall sign as a witness and that a person signing vicariously shall expressly state in writing that he or she does so by authority.

I am also writing to the Attorney-General along similar lines to the above because of his concern about the application of principle (d) and because, in your absence, you may not be as fully involved as you would otherwise desire to be in resolving this matter.
JOHN COATES Chairman
MINISTER FOR TERRITORIES HON. GORDON SCHOLES, M.P. MEMBER FOR CORIO

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Committee thanks the Minister for his agreement to our proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The statement which the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has just made is one of the most significant statements made in this Parliament for some considerable time. The Committee, believe it or not, has been considering a piece of delegated legislation which honourable senators probably have not even had an opportunity of looking at-legislation which contains over 260 clauses which have been described by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) representing the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) as among the most far-reaching reforms of the law ever undertaken in this country. It repeals the money lenders ordinances and hire purchase ordinances and replaces them with provisions which are said to be the very vanguard of modern consumer credit law.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation was developed and almost finalised by the Standing Committee of Consumer Affairs Ministers and the Standing Committee of Commonwealth and State Attorneys-General. However, late last year, shortly before final agreement was achieved, the governments in New South Wales and Victoria jumped the gun and introduced their own credit legislation. Faced with this fait accompli, the Department of Territories printed this Credit Ordinance which, almost in every respect, including the numbering of sections, is identical with the New South Wales and Victorian legislation. The Ordinance was made on 22 February of this year. It seems that at no time did the Department of Territories consider, even as an option to be dismissed, whether or not this fundamentally reforming legislation should come before the Parliament in the form of a Bill. The view seems to have been taken both in the Department of Territories and in the Attorney-General's Office that legislation for the Australian Capital Territory will not be by Act of Parliament almost regardless of what is in the legislation. The Committee believes that there must be, by definition, some small number of exceptions to this attitude. That is why the Committee has its principle (d) which states:
The delegated legislation does not contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment.

In this Ordinance the innovative and complex provisions, which represent far-reaching reform of relationships between borrowers and credit providers, were developed at the level of Commonwealth and State Ministers. The detailed provisions were passed through the parliaments of New South Wales and Victoria and it is proposed that they go through the Western Australian and South Australian parliaments in the near future. The irony that emerges from this is that it seems that at no time was it ever really thought that the Commonwealth Parliament should examine such fundamental proposals. No real significance was attached to the fact that they relate to an interlocking Commonwealth-State scheme. They represent a quite fundamental reform of a financially highly significant area of the law, and they take the form of a major, lengthy and complex legal document.

When the Committee began to conduct its scrutiny of this legislation we asked the Minister for Territories if his officials could attend a meeting and discuss with the Committee why this highly important matter had not been brought into the Parliament in a Bill. On the morning of the meeting the Committee received a letter from the Minister refusing his officials permission to speak about that issue. After a discussion with the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Coates, when the Minister tentatively agreed to his officials talking about principle (d) and the question of Bill versus ordinance, the officials came and told us that the question was never really considered by them. However while some members of the Committee believe-on the basis of what Senator Coates has said this morning there is no doubt that the entire Committee apparently believes-that the Credit Ordinance should have come in by way of a Bill, we do not recommend disallowance for the reasons expressed by Senator Coates. But, as Senator Coates has said, apart from principle (d) we raised other issues with the Minister.

Section 19 of this Ordinance-believe it or not-gives the Minister power to exempt a credit company from the requirements of the legislation. Honourable senators should think about that for a moment. What I am saying is that the Minister may simply exempt a credit company from the entire requirements of the Ordinance. The power allows the Minister an absolute and unfettered discretion to suspend the application of all, or any, of the rights, safeguards and protections which are contained in the ordinance. He can abrogate, or suspend in any way, for any period, subject to any terms or conditions, all or any provisions of the Ordinance, including those provisions which, being protective of the rights of borrowers, pensioners and other people, are the very raison d'etre of this law reform. The Committee asked not that this unfettered power be removed but simply that it be exercised by way of regulation so that it becomes subject to tabling in this Parliament and disallowance in the normal way that such powers are exercised.

One would have thought that that was not an unreasonable request by a parliamentary committee but we ran into a brick wall. Neither the Minister nor his officials could accept the prospect that exemptions, drafted by officials in Melbourne, Sydney or Adelaide could come before this Parliament so that we could apply our minds reasonably to those exemptions. There seems to be a fear that the Senate might feel that particular exemptions may go too far and trespass on rights and liberties and be disallowed on the recommendation of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. The view seems to be that officials in other States who are making the running on this legislation-they are not even officials in the Australian Capital Territory-are to be trusted as the final arbiters of personal rights and liberties in this matter but this Senate-this Parliament-is not to be the final arbiter.

As Senator Coates said, late last night finally and reluctantly the Minister agreed to accept what the Regulations and Ordinances Committee has been insisting upon. We have the letter before us this morning. The Committee met at 8 o'clock last night and finalised this matter at just 10 minutes to 10.

I will not go into the other sections which Senator Coates has already explained to the Senate. The Committee has said to the Minister that it absolutely insists upon these changes being made and finally the Minister has agreed to them. We have been scrutinising this one Ordinance for over 10 weeks with as much care, tact and reasonableness as any Senate committee could muster. The Committee has exchanged seven letters with the Minister; it has held two hearings with officers and discussed the issues with 13 officials. Today, the final day for disallowance of this Ordinance, we have finally, and apparently reluctantly, been able to drag the Minister to a situation where he accepts what the Senate Committee has been insisting upon all this time.

It seems that every time there is a new Minister for the Territories he has to learn all about what the Regulations and Ordinances Committee is on about even though it has been in existence since 1932. Surely departmental officials can properly brief the Minister as to what the Regulations and Ordinances Committee is about. In all the time that I have been a member of the Committee, I do not ever remember it being unreasonable in its discussions with the Minister or not giving fair and proper bipartisan consideration to matters.

I conclude by referring to something that happened 14 years ago when the Senate was asked to disallow an ordinance on the recommendation of the Committee. On that occasion Senator Wood, who was then the Chairman of the Committee-some older honourable senators will recall that Senator Wood was Chairman of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee for something like 20 years-in his concluding speech to the Senate, stated:

During the 18 years I have served as member and Chairman of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee I have not seen a member of any political party working on the Committee a political angle. I believe that members have worked on the basis that it is a committee representing this Parliament. They work in the highest parliamentary traditions. I feel confident that when members of the Committee introduce a report recommending to the Senate that something be done or that something be disallowed the fullest consideration has been given to that recommendation. That has been my assessment during my time with the Committee.
He continued:

I am not a legal man. I am a layman. Sometimes I think it would be better to have a legal man as chairman but as a layman I do my best to interpret what is suggested and what is recommended or decided. From that point I try to be absolutely impartial and fair, at all times keeping in mind what is best from a parliamentary point of view. Briefly I mention the words of the late Senator Pearson when he discussed the Regulations and Ordinances Committee with the late Sir Robert Garran. Sir Robert Garran said to him that in his opinion it was the most important Committee in Parliament. Its duty was to see that Parliament ran the country with legislation, not the Executive with regulations and ordinances. Those words came from the great mind of one of the men who helped to write the Constitution. I have always kept that in mind and I have always tried to apply that principle in the considerations of this Committee.

I believe that still stands today. Senator Coates is a layman, not a lawyer, and he does the same sort of thing as Senator Wood was talking about there. This Committee is totally impartial and apolitical and applies its mind to protecting the civil liberties of the subject. I think it is about time that officers in the Attorney-General's Department as well as those in the Department of Territories understood what this Committee is on about and gave it the respect to which it is entitled.
