TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) a short question which I meant to raise at the placing of business. However, we moved from that more quickly than I thought we would.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a genuine question seeking information. It is not asked in the spirit of criticism or carping. We have in front of us today a red sheet on page 2 of which are listed five items of Government Business. A rumour is now circulating around this chamber, particularly from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), that he wants other matters added and disposed of before the end of business today, including Government Business Order of the Day No. 11-the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Bill. I also hear on the grapevine that, although it is not listed on the red sheet, Government Business Order of the Day No. 8- the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill-also is to be covered before we rise today.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that the red sheet was prepared only an hour ago, I simply ask whether it is not possible, when honourable senators are facing a day such as this, particularly as the last day, and have to make arrangements, that we can be informed now or at least given a rough idea of what business the Government wants to dispose of before we rise at 4.15 p.m. or 5 p.m. today. Are we to continue this evening or are we to sit tomorrow? I say, without scoring points, that this is hardly the way to conduct the business of the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Government Business Orders of the Day are set out on page 2 of the red order of business. Items numbered 1 to 5 are listed. It then says that further Orders of the Day are listed on the Notice Paper.
—There are 26 of them. Are you going to do the 26?

—No. I understand Senator Chipp's particular concern. If one follows the Notice Paper down in terms of legislation, after the Australian Sports Commission Bill 1985 there are two Bills to be dealt with cognately, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Amendment Bill 1985 and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Amendment Bill 1985. It is desired, subject to the concurrence of the Senate, that the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Bill 1985 and allied Bills be dealt with cognately with those Bass Strait Bills. Other than that, the red sheet picks up the legislation which the Government wants to achieve. Those Bills that remain are the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill 1985, the States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill 1985, the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill 1985, the Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill 1985, the Australian Sports Commission Bill 1985, the two Bass Strait Bills together with the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Bills and the Dairy Legislation Amendment Bill 1985, the Dairy Produce Market Support Bill 1985 and the Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Amendment Bill 1985, which we anticipate might be short.
—The Government is not seeking to get the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1985 through?

—Senator Chipp, if we had a wonderful day and had time, we would certainly seek to get it through, but we do not anticipate that. I say by way of apology that Senator Grimes was handling these matters last night. He is in hospital and, as a result of that, there was some hiatus and I apologise that that matter was not discussed.

DEBATE.TITLE: FERTILIZERS (SUBSIDY) AMENDMENT BILL 1985[COGNATE BILL:STATES AND NORTHERN TERRITORY GRANTS (RURAL ADJUSTMENT) BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure as to the extent of the degree of concurrence, but I think it is suggested that the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill 1985 and the States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill 1985 be dealt with cognately.
—Has that the concurrence of the Senate? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — We are dealing with the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill 1985 and the States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill 1985 concurrently as they are both rural Bills, even though they are of different subjects. The Fertilizers Bill provides for a subsidy of $20 per tonne of contained nitrogen for nitrogenous fertilisers and $12 per tonne of single strength superphosphate or $138 per tonne on the available phosphorous content. This is a continuation of the existing Nitrogenous Fertilizers Subsidy Act and the Phosphate Fertilizers Subsidy Act for a further 12 months. The Industries Assistance Commission's interim report recommended that the subsidy to farmers be terminated and that a bounty to manufacturers be paid. The Government, in its wisdom, has rejected that and it is my understanding that the manufacturers are quite happy with the continuation of the existing arrangements.
—Do you share our wisdom on this?

—I say to Senator Button that on this occasion I do. It is expected that a full IAC report will be released this year. The total cost of the subsidy will be $55m per year. It must be recognised that this subsidy makes up in a very small way for the penalty of protection to secondary industry. Various figures have been floated, but currently it is estimated that protection to secondary industry costs each farm, across the board, about $9,000 per year. This fertiliser subsidy is a benefit of only about $300 per year. I reiterate that it makes up for protection to secondary industry in a very small way. The real value of the subsidy to farmers has decreased. It was actually 23.2 per cent of the price in 1963. In 1983, it was down to about 10.7 per cent of the price.

SPEECH.PARA: The fertiliser manufacturers are not happy with the existing arrangements for cartage of phosphate rock from Christmas Island. The contract was entered into by previous governments-our governments-when the rates of international shipping firms were about the same and relatively high. Since then, things have altered and the superphosphate rock carried to Australia in Australian National Line ships is carried at a very high freight rate. This is having a quite detrimental effect. It is estimated that of the subsidy of $12 per tonne, $7 goes in shipping costs. At a time when a series of pieces of legislation has gone through this Parliament, all extolling the virtues of opening up the rural industry to market forces, we ought to extol the virtues of opening up some of these freight contracts to market forces. This would have a beneficial effect both for manufacturers and, consequently, for the end users-that is, the farming community of Australia.

When farmers are trying to keep costs down and increase production, the use of fertilisers is very necessary. Some of our soils are quite deficient in superphosphate. For instance, in the dairying industry one of the best ways to keep up production is through the continual use of nitrogenous fertilisers. Protection to secondary industry is currently running at about 26 per cent. Protection to primary industry is running at about 9 per cent, but the protection to the fertiliser manufacturing industry is a negative percentage, due particularly to the monopoly ANL has on the carrying of phosphate rock from Christmas Island.

The second Bill we are dealing with cognately is the States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill 1985. Until now loans and grants to the end users were handled by the States. Now the States will have to raise money themselves or through commercial channels. The Commonwealth Government will be involved now only in an interest subsidy. That subsidy will cover two main categories. Category A will deal with debt reconstruction, farm build-up and farm improvement. The subsidy will cover 50 per cent of interest rates over a seven-year period. Category B will provide carry-on finance, with a 25 per cent subsidy over seven years.

Category C is different altogether. It provides for grants on loans for household support, particularly for farms that are obviously no longer viable. Such funds will come from Consolidated Revenue, and one could say that basically it is a subsidy in lieu of unemployment benefit while farmers whose farms are no longer viable seek ways of getting out of the farming game and into some other occupation. There is a maximum loan of $8,000 per year per individual. The bad debts on this will be shared by the Commonwealth and the States on a 50:50 basis up to a certain limit and then the Federal Government will take over. The Federal Government will pay the administrative costs to the tune of one per cent of the loan value for categories A and B and 2 per cent of the loan value for category C.

The rural community is still reeling from the onslaught of the Labor Government. I point out that 77 per cent of the real cuts in the recent mini-Budget adversely affected the rural community, and not the least of those effects is the rising fuel prices. If it were not for that sort of thing, maybe we would not have to go so far down this track, particularly in relation to category C, where people just have to get out because they are no longer viable. It is all very well to open up the rural community to market forces-I suppose we would all contribute to that philosophy-but when the rest of the community is opened up to market forces, particularly the labour market, we will all be on far more even ground. The Opposition is not opposing either Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill and the States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill, which we are discussing cognately, have a linked theme-the support provided to rural industry by the Federal Government. The nitrogenous fertilisers subsidy scheme has had a chequered history for quite some time. The scheme goes back to the 1960s and was due to expire at the end of next month. Last year the Government asked the Industries Assistance Commission to inquire into the extent and duration of assistance for the consumption and production of fertilisers in Australia, and the interim report came down a couple of months ago. The report recommended against the continuation of current subsidies for consumption of fertilisers and in favour of short term assistance to local phosphate fertiliser manufacturers. We are now awaiting the final report from the IAC which, as I understand it, is due in either September or October. The Government has indicated that it is still considering the recommendations in the interim report and, therefore, this piece of legislation will continue the subsidy for 12 months, in the same way that it has been available in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: The area of contention in relation to fertiliser subsidies, or any support to rural industries, is that there is a general belief in the community that the community is supporting, to a very large extent, rural industries in Australia. I believe it is important to keep in perspective the type of support the community provides to rural industries and the type of support the community provides to secondary industries. The figures from the IAC for 1981-82-there has been no comprehensive update since then, unfortunately-indicated that effective assistance to primary industry was about 9 per cent compared with 26 per cent for secondary industries. That is really an extraordinary difference. It proves that the often propounded view that the rural sector is grossly over- supported is a fallacy.

The rural sector has indicated constantly that it is in favour of the winding down of protection. Obviously, in economic terms, the winding back of protection is much more useful to primary industry than to secondary industry in most cases, but not in all. Therefore, one could expect primary industries to be concerned about that. It is often thrown back at them that they constantly seek support from government, so it is important to keep in mind the relative support which is provided one to the other. A good example of this is the Government's own restructuring of the car industry. That is another industry in Australia which has been beset by problems over some considerable time. I think there has been genuine support in the community for the Government's reorganisation of the car industry. That reorganisation is a method by which we hope to see some winding back in support for that industry. It is useful to note that, even when the current restructuring plan concludes in 1990, a 57 per cent import duty will still apply. It has been admitted, certainly by Treasury officials, that that type of support which is provided to manufacturing industry across the board can be costed at approximately $1.5 billion to rural industry. In other words, if that support to manufacturing industry in Australia were removed, the average real income of all farmers in Australia would be raised by 17 per cent.

That type of relationship between various sectors in our community has been well known. It is to this Government's credit that in fact it is moving away from some of those hidden subsidies that occurred in the past to try to get that support provided to industry on the books so that everybody in this country can see how much it is costing us to support various industries and what the community in general is paying to provide that support. I believe that is an approach which ought to be favoured. However, it is a hard approach for a government to be required to take. Pulling out that type of support which has been hidden and putting it on the balance sheet exposes it to public view. This enables people to start asking questions. At least when it is exposed to public view there can be some sensible debate in the community about the costs and the benefits of any of these types of support provided to industry. Hence, in general the Australian Democrats support the notion of subsidies up front rather than the hidden type of protection mechanism which has been so much a part of Australia's method of supporting its industries.

The Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill of course is only an interim measure but the States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill has been long overdue. Again it is to the credit of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) that he has undertaken a number of hard tasks in this area. In general, I think those tasks have been performed well, although certainly not to everyone's satisfaction. Later today we will be rediscussing another problem in the rural sector which has not yet been solved, and which looks to be a long way from being solved.

I hope that the discussions which take place and the comments made can be as close as possible to what actually goes on. For example, Mr Kerin was quoted recently as saying that all the farmers he speaks to want to be subsidised. I do not think that sort of comment helps the debate. Certainly, in the context of the support provided by the general community to our primary and secondary industries, the support that goes to primary industry is way below the level of that provided to secondary industry. The flowthrough from that fact might be that manufacturing industry should be less supported and exposed more to market forces. If we are talking about subsidies, let us make sure that at the same time we do not run one standard for one industry in this country and another standard for another set of industries so that those industries are significantly disadvantaged in attempting to operate in the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating two Bills cognately this morning-the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill 1985 and the States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill 1985. I refer firstly to the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill. I am pleased to support this legislation. It will extend the operation of the nitrogenous fertiliser subsidy and the phosphate fertiliser subsidy schemes for a further 12 months to June 1986. The subsidy rates to be paid in 1985-86 are the same as those applying for 1984-85; that is, $20 per tonne of contained nitrogen, $12 per tonne of single strength phosphate or $138 per tonne on the available phosphorous content of other phosphatic fertilisers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Industries Assistance Commission, as has already been pointed out, in its interim report brought down in March of this year recommended the discontinuation of these subsidies but on my reading of the recommendations they were not based on the premise that the rural sector was not in need of some sort of assistance to counterbalance the heavy burden imposed up on it by the cost of subsidies provided to secondary industries; rather, that it was not the most effective and efficient way of providing assistance to rural industries. The cost of these subsidies in 1985-86 is expected to be $55m compared with $55.3m in 1984-85. That, in itself, is a further decline from $58 in 1979-80. In other words, the real value of the subsidy has been declining slightly ahead of the rate of inflation. As I was moved to observe on another occasion in the Senate, in 1968-69 when the price of bulk superphosphate was $26.62 a tonne the phosphate bounty was being paid at $7.87 a tonne or about 30 per cent of the value of the product. Now, of course, the price is approximately $97.40 a tonne and the level of assistance is $12 a tonne. The level of that assistance is in the range of 12 per cent of the value of the product. Over the same period the value of the bounty on nitrogenous fertiliser has diminished even further from 30 per cent of the value of the product to approximately 6 per cent.

The interim report of the Industries Assistance Commission points to some distortions in the distribution of the subsidy over the total areas under pasture and crops. However, I refer the Senate to the very significant benefit the subsidy provides to the industry in general, and in particular in Western Australia. Because of the soil types found in Western Australia it has been necessary to use a disproportionately higher amount of fertiliser to maintain crop yields than in the eastern States. Overall, about 35 per cent of the fertiliser used in Australia is used in Western Australia but Western Australia has only 9 per cent, in number, of Australia's farms. Yet those farms account for 16 per cent of the total value of agricultural production. Interestingly enough, 29 per cent of Western Australia's crop land consumes 31 per cent of the fertiliser used for crops to produce only 15 per cent of Australia's crop output on a value basis. Similarly, Western Australia has 27 per cent of Australia's pasture and uses 30 per cent of the fertiliser applied to pasture in Australia but, on a value basis, it produces only 13 per cent of livestock production. That, I think, is a reflection of the natural infertility-some might say hostility-of Western Australia's soils compared with those in other parts of Australia. It is indicative of the special soil husbandry which must be practised in my State of Western Australia.

The IAC report suggests-I am interested to note this figure-that the subsidy is equivalent to approximately one per cent of total farm costs for most farms. I do not know what the definition 'for most farms' is intended to mean. In Western Australia the subsidy represents between 7 and 9 per cent of total farm costs for all farms and between 13 and 15 per cent for wheat belt farms in Western Australia. It also ought to be pointed out that, while the amount of subsidy is modest, it is, as I understand it from my reading of the figures, the largest single item of Commonwealth assistance to industries in the rural sector. As the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) concedes, the farm sector suffers cost imposts arising from protection of secondary industries, by tariffs, bounties, quotas and other mechanisms, of between $7,000 and $9,000 per farm per annum, depending, of course, on whose figures one uses-those of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, the National Farmers Federation or the Minister.

Regrettably, the lack of time denies me an opportunity to detail what is probably the most significant factor in the level of phosphate costs at the farm gate. However, in the short time available I will pursue my line of thought to the extent of considering the burden carried by the rural sector of the Australian National Line's monopoly on the cartage of rock phosphate from Christmas Island to Australia. The agreement between the Australian Phosphate Corporation Ltd and the Australian National Line is estimated to have increased freight rates for rock phosphate shipped under the agreement by over $20 a tonne in 1984-85. Based on 1983-84 production levels, this is expected to cost the Australian farmers $18m per year for the period of the agreement, provided the freight differential is passed on to the farmers as an addition to the subsidy presently provided under this legislation.

It is worth noting that as far back as 1981-82 the Phosphate Mining Co. of Christmas Island Ltd, as it was then known, stated in its annual report that phosphate freight costs from Florida to Australia were substantially lower than those between Christmas Island and Australia. Given the comparative distances, it is extraordinary that one could import phosphate from Florida at a price significantly lower than that from Christmas Island.

TALK.START.PARA: —From Fremantle to the north of Western Australia.
—No; I was talking about freight from Christmas Island to Australia.
—No; if you take it from Fremantle to the north of Western Australia it costs more than to get it from Florida.

—Yes, it costs more to get wheat from Fremantle to Victoria than from Florida to Australia, thanks to the Australian coastal navigation legislation, ANL's monopoly and the subsidy supplied by the taxpayers.
—I did not want to set you off, Senator. I was just trying--

—Is Senator Button trying to help my argument? The final IAC report has yet to be received, but the question of tariffs, bounties and quotas, as I am sure Senator Button will agree, is a very complex subject which cannot be properly approached in a piecemeal fashion; it requires a uniform approach. Causes and effects will, of course, interact until governments are bold, courageous and prepared enough to tackle this politically sensitive question. They will continue to distort our economy and the allocation of our resources, both financially and physically.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter before us is the States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Bill. Without going through its purpose, which has been dealt with by Senator Collard, I believe that continuation of the rural adjustment scheme is imperative, given the present extreme difficulties faced by the rural sector. The fundamental problem faced by farmers is one of spiralling costs resulting in ever declining terms of trade. In only three years the ratio of prices received to prices paid has declined from an annual average of 85 in 1982-83 to the BAE's latest estimate for the 1984-85 December quarter of 80.

Perhaps another way of looking at this matter is to consider the cost of generating $1 of farm income. In 1979-80, that cost a Western Australian wheat belt farmer 41c. In 1984-85 that figure rose to 61c.

The problem of farm costs was clearly set out in the submission on that subject to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) by the National Farmers Federation. This identified one of the major costs on the farm sector as being the result of industries assistance elsewhere in the economy. This alone imposed a cost of up to $9,000 per farm. As Mr Ian McLachlan pointed out in his address to the 1985 annual conference of the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia:
If the farm sector's huge untapped potential is to be realised, we can no longer continue to carry the cost of inefficiency elsewhere and feather-bedding the Australian economy.
That, no doubt, is a quotation which does not fall on deaf ears with the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button.

The farm sector is extremely efficient. I think that assertion is upheld by the figures. In 10 years, the volume of rural exports has increased by 53 per cent, from an index of 66 in 1974-75, to 101 in 1984-85. The volume of rural production over the same period has increased by 20 per cent. But the benefits of increased productivity are being eroded by increased costs. Farm inflation in Australia is far higher than that of the United States of America, for example-a major competitor on rural product markets. Since 1981, for example, labour costs in Australia have increased by 42 per cent, compared with only 15 per cent in the United States. The price of fuel has increased by 40 per cent in Australia, as compared with no increase in the United States. Fertiliser costs in Australia have increased by 27 per cent, as compared with 2 per cent in the United States. How can we expect to compete?

Overall, since 1980-81 United States farm cost inflation has been 14.5 per cent, as compared with 33 per cent here. Furthermore, Australia's farm inflation rate is expected to rise by a further 6 per cent this year, as compared with less than 3 per cent in the United States. By contrast, the prices of most rural commodities on international markets are expected to remain subdued during the coming year. The international market is oversupplied, after record production of some crops in recent years, with high stock levels also on hand. Demand for agricultural products is unlikely to increase significantly because of the high levels of international debt in developing countries. That, in itself, is a matter for another long and complicated debate.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimates that average prices received by Australian farmers will increase by 5 per cent in 1985-86. This fails to match the forecast increase in the price of farm inputs of 7 per cent; hence farmers' terms of trade are expected to decline by a further 2 per cent. For the individual farmer, this translates into yet another decline in profitability. Farm incomes are expected to decline by 14 per cent-a very sad figure-in 1984-85, with a further decline in real terms of 12 per cent in 1985-86, according to the BAE.

In Western Australia, a run of up to 10 poor seasons in some areas, and eight in most areas, combined with the crippling effects of the cost-price squeeze, has resulted in an average level of wheat belt farm debt of $170,000 per farm, and in many cases over $1m. The rate of return, quite naturally, on those figures at least, including capital appreciation, on an average Western Australian broad acre farm in 1983-84 was only one per cent. Farm income per family farm for the same year was $11,592-and that is farm income per family farm, not per individual.

Those sorts of figures well illustrate the need for rural adjustment assistance. I think the point made in the submission to the Western Australian Legislative Assembly Select Committee on Rural Hardship by the Primary Industry Association of Western Australia in February 1984 is worth noting. It said:

It cannot be stressed too strongly that the adverse terms of trade facing agriculture . . . combined with successive droughts in many areas throughout the State is threatening the very survival of many producers.

It is ironic that on the one hand the weather is destroying the wheat growers in Western Australia and, on the other hand, the Federal Government is destroying the dairy farmers in the eastern States. I do not think this Government has made a serious effort to tackle the problems facing farmers in the area in which it is able to do so-the area of farm costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Subsidise them heavily in one place and not in the other?
—No, I am just saying that it is ironic that, whether it is by the gift of God--
—You are a real dry.

—No, I made it quite clear in the debate on the dairying Bills that I believe that the adjustment was accepted by the industry, the community and the Opposition. It is just the brutal distortion and dislocation that has been cast upon the industry by the Government that has been difficult to accept. Had common sense prevailed and had the Government been realistic enough I am sure that the adjustment could have taken place smoothly and properly without the sort of disruption that the Government is seeking to impose upon the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Farmers Federation in its submission on farm costs found that the institutional factors which contribute substantially to the problems relating to Australian farm costs are mainly a function of five government activities, the first being industry protection which, as I have already said, is costing each farm up to $9,000 per annum. Other factors include excessive spending and borrowing at Federal, State and local government levels, which pushes up the level of interest rates, and an inflexible labour market. The National Farmers Federation estimates that Australian farm labour costs are about 20 per cent higher than those in the United States of America and, of course, the high labour costs are reflected in a whole range of goods and services. I mention the over-regulation of services such as transport, to take just one example. The resultant increase in freight costs in the grain industry alone is estimated to be $112m. The final factor is the level of government taxes and charges at both Commonwealth and State levels. For the information of Senator Button, I do not exclude Liberal governments from that criticism.
This issue was also examined by the Western Australian Legislative Assembly Select Committee on Rural Hardship. The Committee believed that there was a strong case for:

. . . a full review of all forms of government charges to country dwellers, farms and businesses . . . (and) an examination as to what relief can be given to country areas in government charges, given the difficult economic circumstances and outlook faced by agriculture.
Certainly, the Committee was in no doubt as to the seriousness of the situation, describing itself as:

. . . mindful of the possibility of a collapse of agriculture in the marginal wheat belt and low productivity new land areas should the terms of trade and seasonal conditions not show improvement in the near future.

The failure of this Government to take action to ease the cost pressures on farms has had very serious implications for the rural sector and therefore for the total Australian rural economy. The rural sector in 1983-84 contributed something like 37 per cent of Australia's total export earnings, to the value of $8,516m. In the same year, it contributed six per cent of gross domestic product, with the gross value of rural production being $15,091m. Export earnings are vital, particularly in view of Australia's level of external debt. In 1983-84, interest payments alone on our external debt were of the order of $3,400m, representing 12 per cent of export receipts, compared with $1,000m or 4.5 per cent of export receipts in 1979-80. Total debt service payments, that is, principal plus interest, accounted for 28 per cent of export receipts in 1983-84 compared with 8 per cent of export receipts in 1979-80. Perhaps the most significant figure is not the decline in export dollars earned by the rural sector but the increase in the level of debt repayments by this Government.

The magnitude of the cost squeeze faced by agricultural producers is now such that increasing numbers will be forced to leave the industry. While the rural adjustment scheme has an important role to play, both in aiding farmers who will be viable in the long term and those who are being forced out of the industry, the most pressing requirement of the rural sector is that the Government act to contain farm costs and prevent a further decline of the agricultural industries. I believe that can be done by a sensitive, understanding, pragmatic approach by this Government to the rural sector, recognising the fundamental and vital role that it plays in the Australian economy and, therefore, accommodating it accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their support of the legislation. I have only a couple of things to say by way of comment. It is true, as Senator Collard said, that there has been an interim report from the Industries Assistance Commission and there will be a final report later this year in relation to fertilisers. The Government, conscious of the pressures which the farm community is under, particularly wheat growers, has moved to extend the bounty, or subsidy, in its existing form. As honourable senators will know, the IAC, in suggesting the removal of the subsidy, suggested some other things which might be done to help the manufacturing sector of the fertiliser industry which is also plagued by severe problems. The Government will be looking at those things in the context of the final IAC report. I make it clear that, however many complaints there might be about costs and however desirable imported fertilisers might be to provide a competitive environment for fertilisers, it is in the long term interests of this country, I think, that we retain a satisfactory fertiliser industry. Those matters, particularly the proposal of the IAC for a bounty on phosphoric acid, will be looked at in the context of the final IAC report.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne gave us a long discourse on the problems and tackled this Government for its failure to relieve farm costs. Any government can be tackled for that from time to time. One very important item vital to farm costs is the inflation rate, which has halved since we came into government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not farm inflation rates.
—Senator Crichton-Browne went on with all those gobbledegook figures.
—They might be gobbledegook to you because you don't understand them. The average farmer understands them.

—No. Anybody can cite any figures to prove anything about any particular sector of the economy. The figures on farm incomes are always horrendous, even at the best of times, because they always include marginal farms which perhaps would not be there if the rural reconstruction process were as rational as it ought to be. Senator Crichton-Browne can go on with those figures and argue all those things. I am not saying that there are not very severe problems in certain sections of the rural sector, but I just say that all these things sometimes have to be treated with a critical analysis and a note of caution. Having said all those things, I am very conscious of some of the issues raised by Senator Collard and, to a lesser extent, by Senator Crichton-Browne relating to transport costs and so on. They are major problems for this country. They are major national problems, but they cannot be addressed, I am afraid, in the context of a fertiliser Bill, and I do not propose to try. I thank honourable senators for their support and commend the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not have a great deal of trouble with the greater part of the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill. However, we object to certain clauses and will be moving amendments during the Committee stage. I would like to deal with those matters during this second reading debate rather than take up the time of the Senate at this late stage with a general debate about other social security matters. The area which is causing the Opposition concern and is a vital element of the Bill is the clauses relating to the amendment of the provisions for compensation in the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act 1977. The Opposition, as has the Government no doubt, has read about much discontent within both the private and public sectors concerning the escalating cost of workers compensation. Indeed, employers understand only too well the effects of compensation payments that are being felt in the cost structures of business right across the Australian community. It is one of the fastest rising expenses in any business's profit and loss account. This is being reflected in insurance premiums for workers compensation rising very rapidly, as they have done since about 1973. The rise at that time coincided with the very strong rise in wages being paid to people generally as a result of certain actions of the Whitlam Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that the Government would be more sensitive to these feelings at present than to introduce such rather radical changes to the compensation scheme which in fact liberalise it even further. The people of Australia are most concerned that further extensions of benefits are being made at such a difficult time in the development of the economy. Let me just cite some statistics from an article which appeared in the 6 to 12 July 1985 edition of the National Times. They read as follows:
Compensation claims paid by private insurers mushroomed from $261m in 1977 to $647m in 1982-a rise of 148 per cent. Over the same period the CPI rose by only 57 per cent.

That means that the cost of compensation has outstripped the rate of inflation by almost three times. The basic comparative figures for the last 10 years for public sector compensation read as follows: In 1974-75 there were 35,000 claims costing $15m; but in 1983-84 there were 54,776 claims costing $121m. That means that there has been an eight-fold increase in the amount of payments in compensation over a period of 10 years. Therefore, we feel justified in expressing our concern on this matter. We believe that there is a vast amount of Press concern. We hear many stories in the media about it. Certainly there is vast concern in the employment area. Employers are well aware of the costs of compensation. I will quote some views of the media in relation to this matter. The Australian Financial Review of 9 January 1985 stated:

Serious weaknesses in the operation of the Federal employees compensation office are being reviewed by a team of consultants and officers from the Public Service Board and the Department of Social Security.

Government sources expect the review, which has been running for some months, to go to the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, next month. This has led to soaring administrative costs, as well as overloading of an antiquated administrative structure for processing claims.

That sums up very clearly the views of a very important financial journal in this country with regard to the Commonwealth compensation scheme. Indeed, I think it sums up the Opposition's position very clearly. That same article went on to state:
The 1982-83 annual report shows a 33 per cent increase in expenditure on compensation claims from $75,610,000 in 1981-82 to $100,665,000 in 1982-83.

That is a very significant rise. This legislation gives, for the first time in compensation history, a privileged position to a trade union official. Of course, it is typical of this Government that it is merely reflecting the views of the trade union movement. When the trade union movement calls jump, of course this Government jumps. We have seen that with respect to other legislation debated in the Senate this week, the Queensland arbitration system. We have seen the way in which this Government has overridden States' rights and the rights of every individual Queenslander. Of course, in due course, that will have an effect on the rights of every individual Australian. That does not concern this Government. It continues down the track of following the bidding of its trade union masters. Strangely enough, the Government has not been making clear what it intends to do about this matter but this is clearly a break in tradition. In this legislation the Government has introduced a definition of 'a trade union'. It is also prepared to give a Commonwealth employee who is also an official of a trade union cover for work done after hours when he is employing himself in the interests of the members of the union. Obviously one cannot really relate that to the direct work in which that person is engaged for the Commonwealth, but this Government sees fit to interpret the activities of such an employee as including his out of work time operations as a member of a trade union.

We need to consider a few situations where this might become an issue. For instance, there is the question of travel. Such a person might be in the position of going to a meeting of a trade union in some out-of-the-way place. That might involve a great number of social activities as well. Would a trade union official in that situation be covered for compensation? Apparently under this legislation he would. What about the almost farcical situation which could arise where an employee who is a trade union official is active on a picket line against his own employer? One can imagine where that might happen. Suppose he is injured as a result of his activities against his own employer. Can he then claim compensation against that employer as a result of those activities? Is that covered by the legislation? I would like to hear from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) on that point.

The truth is that this Commonwealth employees scheme is very generous. It is clear that the Commonwealth is now the subject of a raid by the trade union movement which wants to get a piece of the action. The trade union leadership and members want to make sure that they are covered and perhaps they have in mind extending those coverages to other parts of the employment field as well, once this legislation is passed and the precedent has been established for the private sector. At present, if a trade union member wants to take coverage to compensate himself he can do so by insuring himself privately with private insurers. There is no reason why he should not do that. People who are members of professional organisations, who are self-employed, or who run small businesses have to do so. Why should a trade union official be selected for special treatment by the Commonwealth in these situations? It is true that the Government has been most secretive about this and has included Commonwealth compensation provisions in a rather large omnibus Bill affecting social security matters. I suppose that the Government thought the matter would be buried in this Bill and would not come to the attention of the public. The Opposition has very strong views about this and I will move amendments in the Committee stage in order to try to have those extra conditions struck out.

There is no doubt that the Australian people are complaining very greatly about the cost of private sector compensation. In the last 10 years we have seen a tremendous rise in the cost to the Commonwealth of compensation payments to its own employees. These have increased eight-fold. The ironic thing is that, at the very time the Government preaches cuts in expenditure, reduces expenditure to the States, as it did yesterday, brings in an assets test in order to reduce payments to pensioners and tells us we must cut back on welfare in the community, it goes out of its way to compensate trade union officials who work as employees of the Commonwealth Government. I think that is outrageous. This Government does not practise what it preaches. Indeed, when it is under pressure from the trade union movement, as we know it always will be, the Government will always jump when the trade union movement calls the tune. It is most ironic that this Government preaches such hardship and frugality on the part of those in the community who are in greatest need and cuts expenditure right across the board, yet is prepared to reward trade union officials in such a way as it seeks to do by this legislation.

The Liberal and National parties in the election campaign last year, in our policy statement, drew to the attention of the people the problems with the Commonwealth employees compensation scheme. We see it as unwieldy, administratively archaic, far too large and consequently almost out of control. We suggest, and this is written into our policy, that on our election to government we will try to examine the feasibility of laying off the compensation scheme to private insurers in the insurance market. We believe that would be a far more effective way of handling compensation problems of Commonwealth employees and it would develop a far more effective scheme for employees. At the same time we shall seek to reduce substantially the administrative costs of operating the scheme. That remains the policy of the Liberal and National parties and we will seek to implement that upon election to government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I share some of Senator Messner's concerns about the changes that are being made via the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill, particularly in Part VI related to the amendments to the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971. The Opposition will move to delete certain words from clause 34 (c) which inserts a definition of 'trade union'. I am not particularly fussed about a definition being inserted. There has not been such a definition to date, and I gather that it is required only because clauses 35 and 37 are being inserted to amend the principal Act and refer to trade unions and trade union activities. Presumably, there needs to be a definition. Because the Opposition opposes the inclusion of clauses 35 and 37, which I will deal with together at the moment, a consequential amendment is also included. I suggest to Senator Messner that if clauses 35 and 37 are deleted, it will not matter whether clause 34 (c) stays there or not. Is that not the case?
—We will go in that order.

—As I said, I share some of Senator Messner's concerns in this area. Workers compensation legislation is fairly heavily entrenched in the legal system in most Western countries. It was pioneered by Bismarck 100 years ago and spread to England and Australia. The aim of the legislation when it was first introduced was to compensate workers for loss of limbs or for other injuries which they sustained at work and which were essentially related to work. It was later extended to cover journey provisions. If a worker was injured going directly from home to work or directly from work to home, that worker would be covered if injury were sustained in the course of that travel. Although employers got a little upset about it, it seemed a reasonable extension since if the person concerned did not travel to get to work, he or she could not work in the first place. The employers argued that although they could have some control over what happened to people in their employ when they were at work, they felt a little miffed at having to pay workers compensation claims when they had no control over what happened in the employee's journey to and from work. Nevertheless, that has been part of the compensation system for a long time, and we are not arguing about that at the moment; we are arguing about the extent to which the compensation can be extended.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner raised the question whether an employee should be compensated if he or she is injured during picket line operations, presumably during lunch-time strike meetings and anything else that is involved not in the actual work for that person's employer, which in this case is the Commonwealth Government and, hence, the taxpayer, that work being part of trade union activity. I share that concern. I fail to see why if somebody whizzes off to a strike meeting at lunch-time and gets caught in a punch-up the employer should be considered liable. I am also concerned about the general extension to what takes place in an ordinary recess or an authorised recess. So far as I can gather, this is limited almost entirely to lunch breaks and tea breaks if somebody is on shift work. So far as I can work out-and the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), who knows far more about compensation than I, can correct me if I am wrong-if an employee takes a lunch break to which he is entitled and in crossing the road to the deli gets hit by a bus, he is compensated as part of the journey provisions that are already covered under sections 32 to 34 of the principal Act. There is apparently some sort of hiatus, I understand, if workers are injured actually at the place they have gone to. If they have crossed the road safely, have got to the deli and while buying their cheese sandwich a crazed gunman comes in and mows them down, I gather there is some question about whether they are covered. Since such an event is highly unlikely, I can see no purpose in supporting clauses 35 and 37 simply to cover that sort of contingency, or a case involving somebody strolling over to the National Library during a lunch break and having stacks drop on top of him. Activities of that sort are fairly unlikely. We have managed quite well without such provisions to date, and I see no point in extending them.

So far as I am concerned, clauses 35 and 37 can fairly adequately be omitted because they unnecessarily extend the journey provisions already in the principal Act. They leave the Commonwealth Government as an employer open to all sorts of problems that can arise out of people's activities during ordinary or authorised recess if they are undertaking simply trade union activities. Clause 36 is a different kettle of fish altogether. I am not exactly sure why that has been picked up by the Opposition since essentially it extends to partially incapacitated employees who are unable to obtain suitable employment a greater benefit than at present. I presume it means that if somebody is partially incapacitated and cannot get work because of that partial incapacity, he will then be treated as if fully incapacitated. Presumably, not being able to obtain a job renders a person significantly financially embarrassed and disadvantaged regardless of whether the person is totally or partially incapacitated. I understand that there are provisions for appeal to the delegate or to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or, if a court case is involved, to the administrative decisions judicial review body if the Commonwealth Government believes that the lack of employment, despite the worker taking all reasonable steps to get a job, is due to high unemployment in the community and not to the partial incapacity. I would be interested at the Committee stage if Senator Messner could say something more about it because at the moment I see it as not a particularly draconian clause to include.

I will certainly be prepared to support the Opposition's objections to the inclusion of clauses 35 and 37. If it wants to run a division on clause 34 (c) I suppose that is fair enough; it is only consequential in that it sticks in a definition of trade unions which seems harmless enough. But, while I can see that quite serious problems could arise out of the inclusion of clauses 35 and 37, I think that, given the problems of defining partial incapacity and the fine dividing line between what is partial incapacity, what is full incapacity, what is partial incapacity that is likely to render one unemployable in that or any other job or only partial incapacity that is likely to render one unemployable in that or any other job or only partial incapacity that is likely to render one unemployable in that particular area, to leave that clause will not do any great harm.

I indicate now that we will support the exclusion of clauses 35 and 37. I am not quite sure how we will do it in the terms in which Senator Messner has put his amendment. Perhaps we will just oppose the clauses when we get to them at the Committee stage. Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask Senator Messner whether he thinks it is really worth while worrying about clause 34 (c); the simple adding of a definition is no great hassle if clauses 35 and 37 are excluded.

I do not want to spend time on what is in fact a very pressured last day talking about the rest of the amendments to what is a fairly substantial Act. I leave my remarks by saying that we share some of the concerns of the Opposition about clauses 35 and 37 and we will support the Opposition in that area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that there is support for the bulk of this legislation but extremely disappointed that the Opposition wishes to take out certain clauses of it which do have a strong justification. I am particularly disappointed that the Opposition will be supported in this endeavour by the Australian Democrats, who I think have forgotten yet again just who they are supposed to represent in this place. They do have, or they claim to have, some sort of constituency, I would have thought, with the working people of this country and they will not be very popular, I can assure them, with this measure.
—It may surprise you to know, Minister, that we can probably live with that.

—It would not surprise me a great deal, knowing the way in which they juggle principle and popularity on an almost daily basis. I deal first with clause 36 in which the Australian Democrats do share our desire not to go along with the Opposition. This clause, which the Opposition seeks to remove, makes it possible for partially incapacitated employees, who nonetheless are unable to obtain suitable employment, to be treated for the purposes of social security benefits as though they were totally incapacitated. I draw to the attention of the Opposition that, on the advice available to me, the number of cases falling into this category-Senator Haines may even be interested in this-identified in section 36 is only around six per annum in the whole of the country.
—You don't think that number will grow as a result?

—The number of identified cases of partially incapacitated people, where their prospects of obtaining a job are so impossible that it is a simple matter of justice that they be properly compensated, is very low indeed. No doubt more claims might be made but, in terms of the criteria that would be applied to those claims, I am advised that the numbers would still be very low indeed. I do not want to repeat all this at the Committee stage so perhaps Senator Messner might take this on board and contemplate withdrawing his amendment in that respect. I should think there is hardly anything wrong with it in principle and in practice it is not likely to bankrupt this or any future Treasury.

SPEECH.PARA: As to clauses 35 and 37 for which the 34 (c) definition of 'trade union' is consequential, what we are talking about here is basically clarifying existing law, making it clear that it is properly a matter reasonably incidental to one's employment to go to buy a sandwich during a recess with the consequent travel backwards and forwards to the sandwich shop in so acting. That is a situation which, in the absence, regrettably, of a no fault liability system in this country at the moment, is compensable only for a person who is injured in such a situation if there is a liability to be compensated arising under the terms of the relevant compensation legislation.

The main point I want to make here is that I am advised and believe that provisions of the kind contained-perhaps Senator Haines will listen to this too-in clauses 35 and 37 are not as unique as is being claimed. I am advised that provisions of this kind are the norm in workers compensation legislation right around the country so far as coverage during ordinary work break recesses is concerned. It is certainly the norm in New South Wales, I am advised, and I believe it is the situation elsewhere. So far as the specific provision being written in as it is in clause 35 (5C) for trade union officials acting on behalf of their employees to be covered during their absence from the work place, I am advised that there is a specific provision to that effect in New South Wales. Elsewhere in the country such a situation would have to be governed by the ordinary principles of compensation law which say that someone is entitled to compensation where the activity in question arises out of or in the course of the employment, which is construed by the courts as meaning activities reasonably incidental to employment. Thus, where someone, being a job delegate or a shop steward, goes to a trade union meeting on behalf of that union's members-this is the sort of situation this legislation aims to address-it is pretty clear that, as a matter of normally applicable compensation law around the country, the person would be entitled to compensation in those circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you include picketing and those kinds of activities?

—I am not necessarily saying that but certainly where a person is acting on behalf of the union members. It would be a matter for interpretation under the existing law as it is a matter for interpretation in this clause as to how that would be construed, that is, whether the activity relates to the representation of the interests of the trade union. I am not sure whether a picketing activity would be construed as a representative activity for the purposes of the operation of this clause. I do not deny that there may be arguments about those borderline cases but what the legislation is basically designed to do is to give some fairness and justice and compensation to the very common situation of a work place union representative representing his members' interests in union activities which occur outside the location of that work place.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Democrats in particular, but also Senator Messner, to contemplate the extent of the damage that would really be done by removing this clause. I do not see that it adds significantly-at best, it adds only marginally-to the kinds of compensation provisions which presently apply in Commonwealth law. Clauses 35 and 37, when read together, very much bring it into the mainstream of compensation law and practice as it operates around the rest of Australia.

There is really nothing much more I can say and, given the time, I do not want to. I do not want to repeat myself at the Committee stage. I simply hope that, the arguments having been canvassed in those terms, it will be understood that this is not just a pro-trade union clause which is being put in as some sort of sop to the Australian Council of Trade Unions or the Government's trade union constituency. It is an attempt to clarify and define the rights of members in the work place and to ensure that no injustice is done and that no compensation is denied when someone is acting in a way that is associated with ordinary employment activity and which involves activity reasonably incidental to that employment relationship. Accordingly, I urge that the Bill be passed intact, without those provisions taken out.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

Clause 34 (Interpretation)
Motion (by Senator Messner) agreed to:

Clause 35 (Employment to include attendance at certain places)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take the time of the Senate by reiterating the arguments we mentioned in the second reading debate and to which the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) referred in his reply. However, I am afraid that the Opposition is not convinced by the arguments of the Government and we will be pressing our amendment, which is to oppose clause 35.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply repeat the Government's opposition to this amendment. For the Australian Democrats in particular to support this amendment would be neither right nor popular. I hope that they will contemplate the merits of the argument once again and vote to retain the clause.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the clause be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause disagreed to.
Clause 36 (Partially incapacitated employees unable to obtain suitable employment)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the Australian Democrats are not as convinced to support the Opposition's amendment to oppose this clause as they were on clause 35 as Senator Haines asked about the justification for the Liberal and National parties taking a strong stand on this matter. This clause covers a situation where a person who is partially incapacitated but available for work, who cannot find work but who has undertaken certain schemes to try to rehabilitate himself, is to be treated as a totally incapacitated person and would be compensated on that basis. That is at variance with the situation where an individual who is partially incapacitated can draw other rehabilitation benefits and so on and enter rehabilitation and other schemes which will assist him to find work but on a far lower level of social security benefit-either the unemployment benefit or some other benefit. Consequently, this represents a major step forward in increasing and lifting the level of benefits for Commonwealth employees as against those in other sectors.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) referred to compensation being provided in this way in other legislation, and in this respect he spoke of New South Wales. We are not convinced that that is necessarily the precedent we ought to be following in this case. In fact, we stand in total opposition to that proposition when it is remembered that so much attention is being given to the cost of workers compensation in the employment market today. The Liberal and National parties will be opposing clause 36.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on what Senator Messner has said. The principle contained in this clause is a very sound one. It simply means this: As the legislation presently stands, a person who has an incapacity which, on medical grounds, does not completely take away his ability to work-in other words, in theory at least, he is able to do some sort of work-would get partial compensation only. The unfairness of that is that it ignores the reality of the situation for a person who, for instance, theoretically has a capacity to work but cannot do it.

SPEECH.PARA: A typical example could be the situation of a migrant worker who injures his back and that stops him from doing the only work that he has been able to do, that is, heavy work. In theory he is able to do other work, such as clerical work or some other light work. Although he may be physically able to do it, he is not equipped to do it due to lack of experience or lack of ability. Such a person would be denied what ought to be considered proper compensation, that is, compensation for not being able to do his normal type of work. Although the incapacity from which he suffers would leave him with some physical ability to do clerical or light work, he would be unable to do the type of work he had been doing in the community. Such a person should not be thrown on the scrap heap, as it were, because no suitable job is available to him. When his incapacity has been caused by his employer it is only fair that he should be given the equivalent of the wage he has lost.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 37 (Journey to or from employment).

TALK.START.PARA: —This clause relates to an earlier discussion we had during the second reading debate with regard to compensation for trade union officials. I will not reiterate those arguments. I merely say that the Liberal and National parties will oppose this clause.

—I understand that, in effect, this is the second half of clause 35 and that clauses 35 and 37 arise out of an Administrative Appeals Tribunal case last year involving an Australian Broadcasting Corporation employee who was hit by a bottle which was wielded by somebody in the park he was in. I do not know whether there was any provocation or what the circumstances were. I would like the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) to indicate whether the basis for this provision is that a Commonwealth Government employee was having his lunch break and during that time somehow got involved in a fracas, and was ruled ineligible for compensation. I gather that the rest of it is as a result of requests from the Australian Council of Trade Unions that trade union provisions and activities be included in the legislation so that trade unionists are covered when they are on official union business such as, I presume, stop work meetings, picketing and what have you. They are not presently covered while engaging in such activities. I repeat what I said earlier. I do not think that such a person should be compensated, but I would like the Minister's opinion on whether the two observations I have made are correct.

—For reasons I indicated earlier, the Government wants to retain this provision. We regard it as fair and just that it be there. The case that gave rise to this measure was, I understand, one where an ABC employee was asleep in a park during his lunch break and was woken up after being hit by a bottle which had been thrown by some lunatic at the sleeping figure. Some might say that they wished ABC figures slept more often. But that apart, that person was not covered because he was not engaged in any journey to or from work; he was engaged during a recess at a particular place. If he had been travelling to or from it, arguably he may have been covered under the existing law. What clause 37 is all about is trying to clarify that situation and to give rights to people, rights which otherwise, it would appear, they may not have. I hope that the Australian Democrats will think about that.

—Is the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) saying that if someone takes his lunch break at the local hotel he is covered between the time he leaves work and gets to the hotel and that he is covered, no matter what his state, between the time he leaves the hotel and the time he returns to work? Is the Minister seriously suggesting that should that person get caught up in a drunken brawl at the hotel, the Commonwealth Government as the employer, and hence the taxpayer, should pay him compensation for any injuries sustained in that pub brawl?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is well known to most people, except obviously Senator Haines, that there are all sorts of exceptions to the circumstances for which a person can be compensated. Serious and wilful misconduct is one of the classic exceptions contained in Commonwealth legislation and would undoubtedly cover a situation of a person's participation in a brawl. I do not think we will advance matters much further with this conversation. Senator Haines and the Australian Democrats have obviously embarked on yet another populist anti-union, anti-worker enterprise of the kind with which we have become familiar, and it does not seem that reason will prevail, let alone justice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill proposes to extend the bounty assistance which is currently provided to the shipbuilding industry in Australia to vessels which are constructed or modified for export from Australia. The Bill picks up the fact that the existing assistance arrangements apply only to Australian vessels. So there is a differential position to this point between ships which are built for export and ships which are built for local use. The Opposition will be supporting this legislation. It believes that the legislation is in the overall interests of Australia and of the particular industry, although we will be seeking to amend it in a way which I will indicate shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: For those who are concerned with industry policy, particularly the element of industry policy which this Bill deals with-namely, assistance by way of bounty-the tale of assistance to the shipbuilding industry is one which has some educational aspects. There has been a very long history of assistance by way of tariff initially before the war and, since the war, largely by way of bounty and by the imposition of restrictions on the importing of vessels. There have been a number of inquiries. I suppose the unfortunate fact is that at the end of many years of government intervention and assistance we have an industry which is not in a very satisfactory shape. The present scheme of assistance followed a report from the Industries Assistance Commission in 1979. The previous Government introduced a bounty scheme which operated from July 1980 for certain vessels, a bounty which started at 27.5 per cent and which phased down to 25 per cent from 1 July 1984, to 22.5 per cent from 1 July 1985, and to the long term rate of 20 per cent from July 1986. So we are in the latter part of a period of assistance which was laid down in 1980 and with which this Bill does not significantly interfere. Rather it simply extends assistance to vessels for export. The Government, in leaving it in place, is, I suppose, acting consistently with its attitude in other areas where it has sought to avoid making changes which upset the expectations which have been aroused by the putting into place of a program over a certain period.

It seems to the Opposition that as a matter of principle it should support the extension of the bounty to ships for export on the basis that, if a bounty is warranted, it is inconsistent with the view of the Opposition and, I think, of the Government that all sectors of Australian industry should be encouraged to be outward looking in their activities and to look to the export market and not merely to the satisfaction of domestic demands. If that is a general objective of policy, clearly it is inconsistent to have special assistance which relates only to a segment of industry and which encourages the Australian industry to be more inward looking. On that very broad principle, I suggest that it is necessary to support this legislation.

One of the unfortunate features of the assistance scheme which has operated since July 1980 has been that it has led, not to an increase in specialised shipyards and to the development of larger productive units, but rather to the encouragement of the entry into shipbuilding by quite a large number of new concerns. Whilst it may be quite desirable that there should be people prepared to enter into the industry, when that is done on the basis of there being some public subsidy available from the taxpayer and when there is no increase in the general competitiveness of the Australian industry, I suppose it could be argued that the industry is proceeding in the wrong direction. That would be the reasoning behind the Government's move within this new legislative package to limit the number of shipyards by a new system of registration.

In principle I must express, on behalf of the Opposition, some concern about the use of some form of mechanism to keep people out and to make judgments about who should be entitled to a bounty and who should not, but, given the recent history of this legislation, I think it would be unwise for the Opposition to set its face against the Government's attempts to come to grips with that problem in the way that it has. As the second reading speech makes it clear that the Government will be monitoring the effect and impact of the changes it is bringing about, we do not intend to seek to change the legislation where it provides powers to limit the payment of bounty to specified shipyards. I note that the Government has put a safety net in there for shipyards which already have registration but which might not meet all the qualifications. Obviously the industry, as well as the Opposition, will be monitoring the application of that part of the new arrangements to see that it is administered with fairness and in a way which will produce positive results.

I think any examination of the industry would show that the recent report of the task force on the shipbuilding industry has isolated some of the major causes for the industry's present difficulties. Paragraph 142 of the task force's report states:
. . . the basic causes for the industry's present difficulties appear to be
low domestic and world demand
too many actual or potential participants in the industry
competitive finance packages offered by overseas yards.

To some extent the proposals brought forward by the Government do meet those difficulties. They do not increase the total domestic and world demand, but presumably they do offer Australian shipbuilders the opportunity to participate more fully in whatever world demand there is for ships. The limitations on the number of participants in the industry I have already commented on. The competitive finance packages offered by overseas yards are, to some extent, matched by the bounty which is now being offered and by the possibility of export finance.

The Opposition notes that in the second reading speech the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) said that there have been a series of discussions between the industry and the Australian Council of Trade Unions and both parties have agreed they will try to achieve an industrial agreement covering a range of issues. I think even the most cursory examination of some of the shipyards operating around Australia would indicate that labour disputes, the large number of trade unions being involved, demarcation disputes and so on have been a significant contributor to the difficulties in the industry. The Opposition certainly welcomes the fact that the Government is encouraging the industry and the trade union movement to seek agreements which will reduce those difficulties. I thought when I visited the New South Wales State Dockyard that it was an excellent example of what could be done, even at the level of a particular shipyard, to get over some of the practical difficulties which are faced in this area. The agreement which has been made for that dockyard represents a significant step in the right direction. The only depressing feature of that is that, in a sense, the shipyard had to be in extremis before the agreement could be reached. From the discussions which I have had at that dockyard it is quite clear that, in a sense, the real prospect that the shipyard might have to close concentrated everybody's mind on some of the practical problems and led to them being tackled.

The Government certainly has my support and encouragement in any moves it may make which will encourage the rationalisation of management within shipyards without the threat of there having to be an essential pre-condition. It appears to me that the sorts of changes which have been pursued by that dockyard-I mention it because it is one which I have had a chance to visit-are symptomatic of the sorts of changes which have to be pursued with the industry generally if it is to make a greater contribution to the Australian economy and if employment is to be maintained within it.
I have indicated in general terms our support for the Bill. We also welcome the Government's indication of intention, as expressed in the second reading speech, when the Minister said:

If the reports from the SCG indicate that continual progress towards rationalisation is not being achieved, the Government will review the augmented assistance package. Whether the export bounty is paid beyond the 1985-86 financial year will depend on the degree of progress achieved. Subject to the combined industry union response the Government will consider whether the general bounty assistance should also be reviewed.

Given the long history of industry assistance in this area and the very real difficulties which exist, it is very wise of the Government to indicate that this change, which is generally in a sensible direction, will be subject to monitoring and that there is no guarantee of continuous assistance unless satisfactory results are being achieved. The only concern the Opposition has with respect to that proposition is that it represents no more than a statement of intent. Whilst we accept that it represents the intention of the Government and of the present Minister, we would like to see some change to the legislation which would require that intent to be translated into action and the matter to be brought back to this Parliament. I note that the Minister has put a rather tight time limit on the assessment of whether progress is being achieved as far as the export bounty is concerned. In the passage from the second reading speech I quoted the Minister says:
Whether the export bounty is paid beyond the 1985-86 financial year will depend on the degree of progress achieved.

The Opposition does not wish to limit the Government to too tight a timetable because the results may take some time to show. The Opposition will, in the Committee stage of the Bill, seek to amend the legislation by inserting in it a sunset clause concluding at the end of the financial year 1986-87 which would do no more than simply require the Government to come back to the Parliament pursuant to the expression of intention which has been made in the second reading speech. The Opposition will put that proposition forward simply so that the industry can see that it is not just the Government but also the Parliament which is concerned to ensure that, where substantial taxpayers' funds are provided for industry assistance, it is not done on the basis of a permanent subsidy provided just because the industry is there, but rather that the subsidy is provided with a view to giving the industry an opportunity to improve its competitive position and ability to look outwards and to pursue the objectives which are viewed by most commentators on industry as being necessary if any industry in Australia is to have a long term future.

The Opposition is not under illusion about the fact that the shipbuilding industry is a very competitive industry around the world and that, at a time of low world demand, the pressures on Australian participants are very great indeed. However, there are shipyards around Australia which are showing a very good approach to meeting world competition. It is possible, given the evidence of recent years, that the Australian industry can perform better than it has done in the past. On that basis we think there should be a very clear message to the industry that the all-party support which has been given to the extension of bounty to exports and for the continuing provision of bounties to the domestic industry is given not on a basis of unqualified support and assistance but on the basis that it provides an opportunity for the industry to improve its performance, to provide greater wealth for Australia and greater employment for Australians and generally to meet our national objectives.
