SPEECH.PARA: The pressure of lobbies with vested interests, largely economic, on government's policies does threaten the equity of ordinary people. The pressure of the media, which usually expresses the voices of vested interests, gives very little expression to the voices of the powerless and the poor in our society. That can be a very real threat to democracy.

There is, sadly, a strong feeling of cynicism and alienation amongst the people of this nation, particularly amongst our young people who have, in this chaotic world, an urgent need for hope, for ideals, for that which is good and honest. Over a period of years there has been growing concern in the community about the attack on civil liberties and human rights and the intrusion into people's privacy that is happening in the Western world. It is vital that governments protect these basic rights that are so important to a free people.

Society faces many new challenges and to face them creatively requires new human and social understanding and interaction. We need to create new social patterns which enhance each and every person's full humanity and potential. New patterns in industry, in banking, in co-operative social and community goals which put people first are being achieved in small ways, in many countries with some quite remarkable results.

At the time of the French Revolution there was an upsurge amongst the people for the expression of equality, of equity for all, of freedom-freedom of conscience and creativity for the individual-of fraternity, of mutual aid and co-operation between each other. These ideals have not been fully realised in our society and the longing remains. We need a parliamentary system which can respond to and fulfil that longing. I think we must question whether it is best to work as government and opposition in confrontation. Are we really fulfilling our intended purpose? Could we not work better together as 'we' instead of 'them and us'?

In retirement I look forward to the opportunity to continue to work for those ideals which can create for people the realisation of peace and true humanity. I wish to thank all those people in this place and in the community who have contributed to my learning experience and knowledge. I thank my staff and friends and all those people who do care. I shall use my retirement well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I entered this Parliament in March 1983, a short time ago compared with the terms of those who have spoken before me today. I entered this Parliament with very high hopes but with realistic aspirations and an awareness of a tremendous responsibility held by the Australian Democrats. I entered a great institution, this Parliament, and I entered the Senate, a very vital and evolving part of that great institution. While I have been in this place a very exciting evolution has taken place. I came to this chamber as an Australian Democrat, with the balance of power being held by the members of my Party. That gave us a different kind of responsibility. I have done my best to uphold that responsibility. I know that my Democrat successors will always recognise the responsibility to scrutinise every single Bill, every report, every regulation and every ordinance; to consider the arguments for and against, the representations from interested individuals and organisations; to consider ways of improving that legislation and ways of achieving compromise between government and opposition; and, above all, to seek a path which minimises the impact on the losers and maximises the long term benefits for all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I express my very sincere thanks to the Senate staff who make life possible for us in the Senate. I mean that sincerely. We could not exist as a Senate without their professional guidance. I thank the committees and the staff of those committees. I pay a special tribute to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, which blooded me-not bloodied, but blooded-and to the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. The latter has been an exciting Committee to work on under the chairmanship of Senator Georges. I express my gratitude to the staff of the Department of the Parliamentary Library, to the research staff and to the staff of the Records and Table Office, people who have made it possible for my staff and me to participate in the debates in this Parliament. I express my gratitude to others who make life just a little easier for us when it gets very difficult. When we have had a 14-hour day for four days in a row we find that there is a friendly driver to help us get home while we slumber in the back seat of the car: We find that there is a very warm dining room staff to look after our every interest. I pay a tribute to the Press representatives, those people who have a very difficult job in putting the views of very demanding politicians to our respective publics.

Mr President, I express my very deep gratitude to you for the warmth of your welcome and very warm and friendly help throughout my stay in the Senate. I am sure you will not mind sharing those thanks with the Deputy President, who is one of the greatest committee chairpersons I have ever witnessed, and with the Acting Deputy Presidents and temporary Chairmen of Committees. I pay a special tribute to Senator Ruth Coleman, one of those chairpersons for whom I have a very high regard and great affection, but who is not with us at the moment. We hope to have her back shortly.

I pay a tribute to the Ministers and shadow Ministers, not just from me but from all my colleagues, for the access they have given us to themselves at a moment's notice, to their staff and to the heads of departments. That access has made it possible for the Democrats to function in this place and to perform one of our vital roles. I thank my fellow senators: Senator Button and his team; Senator Chaney, the Leader of the Opposition; Senator Scott and his colleagues; and Senator Harradine who sat beside me from day one and nudged me from time to time to let me know that I was getting out of line. Senator Harradine helped me to beat the system, as he does so frequently.

I particularly thank my Australian Democrat colleagues who are very fine individuals. They make a great team under a great Leader, Don Chipp. I thank my own research and electorate office staff, who must rate as second to none, judging from their performance and their capacity to uphold me in this place. I include in that group the staff on Senator Chipp's team and the staff of the other Democrat senators, who all seem to chip in whenever a pressure point is recognised by them. I thank my Western Australian constituents, particularly those Australian Democrat members who worked so hard for so long to get one senator into this place for so short a time. I recognise their disappointment that it has been for such a short time. I thank them for their input. I thank particularly all of the constituents of Western Australia who provided input in order to let me know what was the feeling in the electorate. I guess I should thank them for allowing me to have a brief holiday following the last election before returning to the Senate after the next election.

I conclude by publicly acknowledging a debt to a very special person throughout my life-my wife-who has shared the highs and lows and the pressures of being a parliamentarian and politician. Other senators would understand and appreciate the value of having a loving wife to share the pressures with. I acknowledge a debt to my family which has given that support as well, and to my many friends, both inside and outside the Parliament. Thank you, Mr President, and all honourable senators.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure all honourable senators very much appreciate the remarks of our retiring colleagues. I understand that the leaders of the respective parties, and others, will be speaking about our retiring colleagues in the adjournment debate of the Senate at 4.15 this afternoon.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sitting suspended from 1.19 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Honourable senators will be aware that Senator Grimes is absent from the chamber today. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Grimes in relation to his portfolio or those which he represents in this chamber should be directed to me. If I feel that another Minister has more appropriate knowledge of the topic, I might refer the question to him or her.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the answer which Senator Grimes provided on Tuesday to a question on notice in which I sought statistics on the number of pensioners affected by the assets test. Is the Minister aware of the answer that Senator Grimes gave me? I refer in particular to the last paragraph, which reads:

QUESTION.PARA: Statistics for particular postcode districts or social security regions are available upon request.

Is the Minister aware that, notwithstanding that answer, I am being refused access to those statistics? Does this reflect a new open government policy of the Hawke Government or does it mean that in future honourable senators should take such answers to mean the exact opposite of what is actually stated?

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, I would not have an answer to that peculiarly Grimes-Messner problem, if I may put it in those terms. I will make some inquiries and I may be able to give an answer at the end of Question Time.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to statements by the President of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, Captain Brooksbank, regarding the sacking of five pilots from the Queensland Government's Air Wing? What bearing do Captain Brooksbank's remarks have on recent statements made by the Queensland Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, about the operation of the Federal Government's VIP flight?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now have two totally opposed accounts of what happened to those five pilots who used to work for the Queensland Government Air Wing. It would appear that either Captain Brooksbank or Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen is lying. Let us look at the facts. On 29 May I told the Senate that there were reports that I believed were reliable that five pilots were sacked from the Government Air Wing in Queensland because those pilots insisted on logging the names of their passengers in accordance with what they believed to be their obligations under the air navigation regulations.

ANSWER.PARA: Later that day a spokesman for the Queensland Premier described my statement as a complete fabrication. He went on to say, and I quote from the newspaper reports:

. . . the Queensland Government had been reorganised, allowing pilots to reapply as contract labourers 'to provide the best possible value for taxpayers' money'. Three of the pilots successfully reapplied for the new contract and two others made their own decision to leave.
Captain Brooksbank has a different explanation. Last night on the PM program he said:
We believe the pilots were dismissed because they sought clarification of the interpretation of air navigation regulations from the Department of Aviation . . . we believe that he--
would prefer that the lists of passengers being carried by the Queensland Government Air Wing be not a public document. In this regard the VIP squadron and any other operations are conducted--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: We have the rather extraordinary position of a Minister of the Crown answering a question-I doubt whether it is a question without notice-and quoting as his authority a broadcast on the PM program. Quite frankly, this seems to be an extraordinary use of Question Time. The Minister is engaging in political propaganda. If he wishes to make a statement after Question Time, he may find that there is time to do that rather than continue with his Bills on Bass Strait. It seems quite obviously outside the scope of Question Time to have a question put which requires the Minister to answer by quoting some person whose name he gives but no other authority and in some way informing the Senate of his obligation as a Minister. It is an absurd situation and I suggest you call the Minister to order and ask him to sit down, Mr President.

—On the point of order: I can well understand Senator Chaney's and the Opposition's acute embarrassment on this matter, but the situation remains that in answer to a question properly put to me in this place yesterday I gave an answer which was subsequently described as a complete fabrication. I am taking parliamentary opportunity, in response to a further question from Senator Reynolds, to clarify the situation, and I am doing so by putting on the record the two competing accounts of this matter and allowing the Senate to decide for itself.

—I will allow the question. I had some difficulty in the first instance about the legitimacy of the question, but because it related to the VIP fleet I allowed it. I noticed some content of the Federal Department of Aviation involved in the matter, and on that basis I allowed the question.
—I will continue. Further along in the program last night, Captain Brooksbank said:

ANSWER.PARA: We have submitted evidence to that effect to the Department of Aviation and whilst they are investigating it, it is improper for me to comment. And we are waiting for the Department's response to that. What I would like to come to is that in fact the Premier's Department has stated they have not sacked the pilots. Now that statement from the Premier's Department is a falsehood, and it is made in the knowledge of its falsehood.

So it does become a question, as I said, of who is telling the truth-Captain Brooksbank, or the man who has refused to make public for the last 12 years the operations or the passenger manifests of his air wing. On the basis of the following evidence cited by Captain Brooksbank, I leave it to the Senate to decide. He said this last night:

On 22 January of this year on the Premier's Department letterhead, signed by the Co-ordinator-General, Mr Shubert, each of the five pilots were notified and I quote: 'I hereby give you three months notice of the termination of your employment with the Government Air Wing Premier's Department, Brisbane'. Then, a little later, on 1st March, again on Premier's Department letterhead, again signed by the Co-ordinator-General, Mr Shubert, and I quote in full'' 'Mr Brady, Deputy Director of Operations, Government Air Wing: Take notice that your employment is terminated absolutely as from the time of service of this notice upon you.'
This notice, said Captain Brooksbank, was taken around by police and physically handed to the man in question in his own home.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no wonder that you were sacked as Attorney-General.
—I understand Senator Chaney to be saying that his judgment is that Captain Brooksbank is lying. I would like Senator Chaney to make that judgment outside this place if he believes in its veracity.

—On a point of order: The Minister is now finishing his quotation from a radio broadcast by suggesting that it is I who is suggesting that that man is a liar or whatever. I have not a clue who he is. I think that for the previous Attorney-General to come into this place and quote as his authority the PM broadcast by some person we have never heard of and who has no official position is an absolute absurdity. No wonder Senator Evans was sacked as Attorney- General.
—Order! There is no point of order. I call Senator Evans.
—I have concluded, Mr President. I will let the record stand.

—Can the Minister for Finance explain his strong criticism earlier this week of Milton Friedman in light of Mr Keating's initiatives, first of all, to float the Australian dollar; secondly, to allow foreign banks to enter the Australian market; and, thirdly, to reduce tariffs on the automative industry, when these actions are consistent with Milton Friedman's economic prescription? Is Senator Walsh showing a fundamental disagreement with his Treasurer in regard to the currency market, banking sector and tariffs? How can Senator Walsh say that Milton Friedman is discredited when many of his ideas on free competition have been the catalyst to the United States economic recovery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course there is no fundamental conflict between the Treasurer and me, or indeed any conflict at all that I am aware of. I know that Senator Townley, and probably Senator Chaney as well, will have great difficulty in understanding this, but my criticism of Milton Friedman was quite specific. It was a criticism of the Friedmanite notion that any change in the money supply would lead to a commensurate change in prices in the same direction. If the money supply expanded by 10 per cent, according to the Friedman dictum, prices would also increase by 10 per cent. That is derived from the old monetary equation usually written as MV=PT. 'M', the variable on one side of the equation, stands for the money supply and 'P' on the other side stands for the price of goods. Logically, that has always been flawed because there were two other variables. Either of those could vary to offset to some degree, or even completely, changes in either of the other variables.

ANSWER.PARA: I said that I did not think that anybody still took seriously the simplistic notion popularised by Friedman that there was a direct and 1:1 linkage between changes in the money supply and the level of prices. That notion overlooked the technical difficulties of measuring the money supply, anyway. Perhaps Senator Townley still believes in that. If he does, I suppose that belief is consistent in its obsolescence with most of his other beliefs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to the question asked of him yesterday by Senator Macklin, who alleged that section 100 of the Repatriation Act had been amended by inserting the words 'direct combat with the enemy', supposedly in order to restrict veterans access to repatriation benefits. Is there any substance to this allegation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Macklin asked me a question dealing with section 100 of the Repatriation Act. I indicated then that his question revealed a lack of understanding of the legislation. I regretted the fact that, as spokesman for the Australian Democrats on these matters, he did not understand what was proposed in the May statement. The new Veterans' Entitlement Bills-as a consequence of our revising all of the 84 pieces of legislation-will be a necessary piece of legislation designed to eliminate confusing and often contradictory provisions and replace them with logical and comprehensible provisions. That was an objective of the previous Government and of this Government. It was established that there was a need to have an advisory committee look at the Repatriation Act.

ANSWER.PARA: All I ask of Senator Macklin is that he give the new legislation a chance instead of seeking to sabotage it before it is in place by making allegations which are creating unnecessary confusion amongst some sections of the veteran community. I want to set the matter straight in regard to section 100 and the insertion of the phrase 'direct combat with the enemy'. Section 23 of the Act prescribes that service pensions may be payable to people who served in a theatre of war. That section remains unchanged. By inserting the phrase 'direct combat with the enemy' in section 100, it will extend the application of the criminal standard of proof rather than restricting it, as has been suggested, because otherwise in a small number of cases the new legislation would not provide the criminal standard for those who, in certain circumstances, while carrying out activities in Australia during World War II, came into contact with the enemy. None of the existing provisions of the Repatriation Act in respect of a disability or service pension are otherwise affected.

Section 100 (d) defines who meet the requirement of 'active service' by virtue of service within Australia, then goes on to indicate in four different paragraphs those to whom the legislation applies. By introducing the words 'direct combat with the enemy' we have not changed that definition. The wording is designed not to restrict but rather to extend the criminal standard of proof provisions. This is a simple matter of establishing facts. By inserting this phrase we are in no way creating a restrictive regulation or piece of legislation. It is designed to cover in particular those who served in the Northern Territory during World War II. The critical point is that the expression 'direct combat with the enemy' is unrelated to any of those existing four provisions. The term 'operational service' will replace the concept of active service which is an outdated World War II concept and in no way will any of the existing beneficiaries be affected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment aware of the loss of public confidence in the Western Australian Government's system of environmental impact assessments prior to the commencement of development of ecologically delicate areas? In view of the Western Australian Government's diminished concern for its own environment protection procedures, will the Federal Government, firstly, reconsider whether it should continue to place such a high degree of reliance upon advice from the Western Australian Environmental Protection Authority when making decisions under the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and accordingly review the memorandum of understanding between the Federal Government and the Western Australian State Government on environmental impact assessments? Secondly, will the Government ensure that Federal environmental impact assessments are sufficiently rigorous to fill the gap left by the Western Australian State Government? Thirdly, will the Government require that environmental impact assessments be prepared and made available to the public prior to the making of any decisions to proceed with development proposals which are potentially of environmental significance? Finally, is the Government's intention to allow the Western Australian environment to be mistreated in the same way as is happening in Queensland?

—As Senator Jack Evans's question was very detailed and sought very detailed information I will have to take it on notice, although I assure him that I will make sure he gets an answer. I will either post it to him or wait until he comes back to the Parliament.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Jack Evans proceeding to direct a supplementary question to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is not in order. I rule that supplementary question out of order. It is a completely different question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, refers to the investigations by justice authorities in Queensland of the possible breach of the criminal law on a massive scale by doctors performing thousands of abortions in that State. I ask the Minister whether he recalls that in Question Time yesterday, after referring to article 17 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The Human Rights Commission is considering this week the issues involved in the Queensland abortion raid and will, no doubt, report in due course.

Is the Commission's consideration being undertaken as a result of a request by the Attorney-General, under section 9 (1) (d) of the Human Rights Commission Act, or is it conducting an inquiry of its own initiative? If so, under what provisions of the Act? Bearing in mind that the Commission, in its report No. 10 on the Au Yeung case, stated that, in its view, the Declaration of the Rights of the Child 'ranks equally' with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, can the Minister give an assurance that, in its consideration of or inquiry into the actions of the Queensland justice authorities, it will give due regard to the Human Rights Commission's responsibilities and obligations to that part of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child which calls for appropriate legal protection for the child 'before as well as after birth'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No doubt the Human Rights Commission will give appropriate attention to all human rights declarations and conventions that bear upon this issue. I was informed that the Human Rights Commission was considering the matter of its own volition with a view to determining whether it wanted to embark upon a formal inquiry and perhaps seek an Attorney-General's reference in that respect. When I said that it will be reporting in due course I meant only to convey that it would, no doubt, be reporting as to the outcome of its consideration of its deliberations. At this stage it is not my understanding that there is any reference from the Attorney-General on that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat that the enormity of the invasion of the civil liberties of the women and medical practitioners in question-many of whom suffered the most outrageous and extravagant invasions of personal privacy-remains absolutely and obviously indefensible and is clearly perceived to be such by the overwhelming majority of the Queensland population, including, obviously, a very large number of people who feel as passionately about the merits of the abortion issue as do Senator Harradine and no doubt many others in this chamber. It is important to draw a distinction between the pros and cons and the principles relevant to determining the argument about abortion on the one hand and on the other hand the kind of outrageous misuse and abuse of police and governmental power that was obviously involved in this raid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has fudged a response and has not directly responded to my question. The Minister stated that he was informed that the Human Rights Commission is undertaking a consideration of the matter. By whom was he informed? Is it a consideration or an inquiry? If it is an inquiry, I again ask him: Under what provision of the Human Rights Commission Act is the inquiry being conducted?

—I am sorry if Senator Harradine thinks that I fudged the answer; I do not believe I did. The Human Rights Commission is perfectly capable of considering matters at large as they arise and making its own decision as to whether it wants to pursue them further, whether by way of such limited powers of general inquiry as are open to it or by way of formal reference from the Attorney-General. No doubt it will weigh up the relevant considerations involved in this matter and make a decision and recommendation accordingly to the Attorney-General.
—By whom were you informed?

—I was informed by a staff member who is responsible for these matters who, in turn, checked, I believe, with the Attorney-General's office which, in turn, I believe, checked with the Human Rights Commission. Yea, I verily believe all those things. I will have to check whether that is an accurate account.

—Does the Minister for Veterans' Affairs agree with Royal Commissioner, Mr Justice Evatt, that today's expected passage of the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill has altered the situation for Vietnam veterans and may require legislative change to protect their position? Further, has he noted the view of Mr Peter Alexander of the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council who described the amended legislation as a breeding ground for litigation? In light of the criticism by the Royal Commissioner, do the Minister and the Government intend to maintain their support for the mini-Budget legislation? Can the Minister, on behalf of the Government, give an unequivocal assurance that Vietnam veterans will not be adversely affected by the changes to the repatriation legislation?

—I can give the assurance that in no way will Vietnam veterans' claims for entitlements be unfairly affected by either the May statement or the proposals that are contained in the Veterans' Entitlement Bill. It is true that some bush lawyers associated with some of the veterans' organisations have placed certain interpretations upon the proposals contained in the May statement. These interpretations have no substance at all according to the advice that has been given to me by lawyers in the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Attorney-General's Department. My firm view is that any recommendation that may arise from the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam with respect to proposed changes to section 47 of the Repatriation Act will be considered by the Government, as indeed will the views of any veterans' organisations during the period in which the Veterans' Entitlements Bill lies on the table for the consideration of the veteran community. Should it be found that there are valid reasons to doubt the assurances I have given to date the Government will take those matters into consideration. I can certainly assure Senator Chaney that in no way has it been the intention of the Government to include in the legislation any provision which would unfairly change the status of those applicants who served in Vietnam. Contrary to the position of the Opposition parties, who sent young men off to war in Vietnam against their will, the sympathy of this Government lies with those who served in Vietnam and no legislative attempts will be made by this Government to minimise their obligations.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer him to an article in the Age in which Terry McCrann calculates next year's Budget deficit at $6.5 billion. Can the Minister provide any information on Mr McCrann's calculation which was presumably based on papers released by the Treasurer in the Loan Council context?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have glanced at Mr McCrann's article and I think it would be fair to say that this is another one of those articles which tell us more about Mr McCrann's prejudices and preconceptions than about the issue which he is ostensibly addressing. Mr McCrann, of course, was highly critical of the May statement on the grounds that it was meaningless, that there was not enough blood on the floor or that sort of reason. I assume he would have been happy if we had, say, withdrawn unemployment benefits or age pensions entirely, or at least cut them in half, or something like that. That was the sort of thing that he seemed to want in order to be satisfied. But the Government, of course, is concerned with responsible and humane economic management rather than blood lust. The Government decided its approach to the Premiers and it was firmer and more responsible than any commentator, including Mr McCrann, had called for.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the figures, Mr McCrann has done a lot of assuming with varying degrees of error, and the most spectacular example of error in his calculations is probably the fact that he has assumed that Commonwealth authorities this year will borrow between $600m and $800m, and further that $700m will come from the borrowings of those authorities in 1985-86. I am advised by the Treasurer that in fact the figures for this year are $1,241m and, for next year, $1,136m. So the errors are of between 60 and 70 per cent. I am also advised by the Treasurer that he does assure Mr McCrann that the cut in the public sector borrowing requirement will be at least one percentage point this year. On the Government's figuring the reduction will be rather more than one percentage point.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, follows one asked earlier this week by Senator Missen on the removal of asbestos from the National Library of Australia. Does the Minister agree that there is overwhelming evidence that asbestos is a negligible hazard to occupants of buildings provided it is encapsulated and undisturbed, and in fact, in these circumstances, the process of removing it creates a much greater hazard to the occupants of the buildings than leaving it there would have done? Has the Minister seen the findings of the Canadian royal commission on the use of asbestos, which suggests that asbestos removal is a very cost ineffective contribution to public health? Do Australian investigations support the Canadian assessment that asbestos removal might save one life for every $80m spent, but expenditure in other preventative health areas, such as motor vehicles, results in one life saved for every $64,000 spent; medical programs, one life saved for every $112,000 spent and so on? Are these not much more cost effective ways of improving public health than asbestos removal? Is the nationwide campaign on asbestos removal truly a cost effective contribution to public health or is it a massive financial contribution to the Builders Labourers Federation?

—From my own knowledge I cannot deal with all the issues raised in the very lucid argument put at Question Time today by Senator Hamer. I am sure that there is a lot of sense in what Senator Hamer says. There is not always a guiding hand of rationality in all human affairs, as Senator Hamer may well know. After all, he was in the Navy for about 10 years. There are a number of elements in the question about which I will have to obtain detailed instructions. I will see that that is done.

—Will the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce indicate what changes he anticipates will occur in employment levels in the heavy engineering industry following the introduction of the interim assistance package for heavy engineering?
—None.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines has answered the question by way of interjection. She thinks there will be no changes in employment levels as a result of the Government's response to the interim report of the Industries Assistance Commission on heavy engineering. Many very glib conclusions tend to be drawn about some of these issues. I understand that a headline in one of the newspapers today was 'Jobs to go', or something like that, as a result of a response by the Government to the IAC interim report on heavy engineering. More importantly, the question that people have to address in considering some of these industry matters is whether jobs will stay if nothing is done. The fact is that there has been a steady decline in employment in the heavy engineering industry over the last few years. The decline in employment is directly associated with decline in demand, particularly from the resource industries and also with the decline in demand resulting from improved technological capacity in a number of industries which has reduced the demand for conventional products.

ANSWER.PARA: The question is important. The heavy engineering industry, as is the case with most industries in Australia, has to decide what the market is for which it produces goods. Traditionally, the market has been a small, Australian, domestic market. If the heavy engineering industry is to expand its employment it has to consolidate its operations, which will mean loss of employment in certain plants. It cannot expand its employment until it consolidates its operations with better technology than now exists. So, if you like, it is a chicken and egg situation, which is very difficult. However, if one is to do anything about restructuring industry and building a long term industry which can service both the Australian market and export markets, that process will have to be gone through.

I make the point to Senator Childs that we have 27 rolling stock plants in Australia. If nothing is done about that situation the majority of them will slowly die. Something has to be done to see that an appropriate number of heavy engineering plants devoted to rolling stock survive in Australia, that they have a better technological base and better encouragement for capital investment to ensure that their technology is up to standard. I believe that then those rolling stock plants which are left will grow and will have the capacity to export and to employ more people.

As I said previously, I am just trying to illustrate a point which I think some people miss, demonstrated by the sort of glib headlines one sees in the newspapers about these matters. I am afraid that Australia cannot opt out from the rest of the world in these matters. We have to have industries in this country which are at state of the art technology. That process will involve some difficulty, but it has to be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Given that the designs the Government has accepted from Ingenieurkontor Lubeck Howaldtswerke-Deutschewerft of West Germany and Kockums of Sweden are paper boats only, that neither design is ever likely to go into service with the home navies of the builders, that neither designer has any experience in building powered weapons discharge systems, and that the German company which the Minister hails as a world leader has never built a submarine with that most elementary of safety design features-a watertight bulkhead-does the Minister claim that these two designs conform with the criteria required of all tenderers by the Royal Australian Navy request for tender?

—Unfortunately, I cannot allow to be read into the record the remark that Senator Button just made to me, but the suggestion essentially was that it sounds more like propaganda from a disgruntled tenderer than anything that bears any resemblance to the facts of the present situation. The process that the Government has already been through to identify the two finalists, as it were, in the tendering stakes has been a thorough and exhaustive one. The criteria to be applied have been spelt out with elaborate precision and in very great depth and detail. A very high calibre team has been working on the issue for a long time within the Department of Defence. I personally saw the product of their presentation on this issue and I was impressed, as I think the rest of the Cabinet was, with the depth and degree of detail that has gone into the process so far. It has, indeed, been widely regarded as one of the most successful tendering exercises engaged in by the military to date. That is not to say that there might not be some bugs that remain to be resolved in the latter stages of the design and tendering process and the identification of the final successful tenderer. All I can say is that none of the evidence of which I am aware or of which I believe the Minister is aware suggests any empirical foundation for the concerns that Senator Scott expressed.

—Can the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women advise the Senate of the progress of the Government's affirmative action program? Are any special measures planned to overcome the difficulties in the employment of women in occupations not traditionally held by women?

—Yesterday I published the progress report on the affirmative action program on behalf of the working party on affirmative action. That report has been very well received. It draws on the first nine months' experience of the 20 private sector companies--
—Twenty-eight.

—Twenty-eight private sector companies-my thanks to Senator Baume, who is also a member of the working party-and three higher education institutions which volunteered last July to take part in the 12-month pilot program. Through the work of the pilot program, many strategies for opening up employment and training opportunities to women have been identified and are being developed. In answer to Senator Giles's question, I particularly refer to a paper put out by the Affirmative Action Resource Unit of the Office of the Status of Women called 'Strategies for Employers for Supporting Female Apprentices in Non-Traditional Trades'. I think the development of papers such as this will assist the program in its ultimate objective of giving wider and better job opportunities to women in the private sector.

—My question is also addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. I also refer to the affirmative action pilot program interim report. As the Minister said, she released that report yesterday. I have been unable to get a copy. Has the Minister released the report for public scrutiny? If not, when will she be doing so? Can the Minister confirm-and she has already confirmed-that one of the main findings as reported in the media is that the participating companies have encountered severe difficulties in attracting women into traditionally male fields? What conclusion does the Government draw from that finding? What is the Government's timetable for the legislative introduction of affirmative action and is this affected by the findings of the interim report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report was made public yesterday. I do not know what the actual arrangements through the Office of the Status of Women were-
—We all got one.

—Apparently all honourable members and honourable senators have been provided with a copy. I will make sure that Senator Walters has one also. Senator Walters asks whether one of the main findings was the difficulty in attracting women into non-traditional areas of employment. There are a number of findings in the report. It is a comprehensive report of the pilot program in its first eight months. I would not care to identify that particular finding as the main finding. Certainly, it is a significant finding. It exemplifies the usefulness of the pilot program because the pilot program has shown that, even when job opportunities or training opportunities in non-traditional areas are made available and advertisements placed to attract young women into these areas, there is resistance. That resistance varies from place to place, but several companies have reported difficulty in attracting apprentices.

ANSWER.PARA: This has led to a discussion by the participating companies as to how to proceed to be more successful in attracting young women to these areas. I should say that there has been a change. Several of the companies now have female apprentices in training in non-traditional areas but there needs to be more effort placed on understanding why young women are not attracted, even in areas where there is high unemployment, to training or jobs that offer security. The Affirmative Action Resource Unit and the participating companies are holding discussions with young women who have made the choice to go into non-traditional areas. From that they are forming a better picture as to how to present these job and training opportunities so that young women will feel confident enough to apply for them and have the benefit of that training.

Senator Walters asked about the time-table for legislation for affirmative action. The working party has not finished its work yet. This is a progress report. As well as the progress report, public hearings are being held throughout Australia to allow interested people to participate. One was held in Hobart this week, for example. More written submissions have been invited; so there is quite a deal more work to do. The next meeting of the affirmative action working party will be in a couple of months time and at that stage we will have a clearer idea of where we are going with regard to the development of legislative options. I expect that towards the end of the year the Government will have clear indications from the working party as to how it could proceed to the next step, which is some form of legislation to ensure that all large private employers have equal opportunity programs within their corporations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I asked whether the interim report would affect the legislative progress. The Minister failed to answer that. Also, the Minister said that the companies would have to look further to see why women were not participating. We should realise that for a butcher's apprenticeship 58 men and only one woman applied.

—I think I really did answer Senator Walters's question as to whether the Government's attitude to developing legislation will be affected by the progress report. Of course it will be. The whole pilot program and the existence of the working party, including any reports that are made in the course of the working party's work, are designed to advise the Government on what appropriate forms of legislation could be developed.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What is the Government's reaction to the reported statement of Sir Anthony Synnot, former Chief of the Defence Force Staff, who claimed that it was easy to see a defence threat to Australia emerging from Indonesia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of an article in the Australian yesterday, 30 May, reporting the former Chief of the Defence Force Staff, Sir Anthony Synnot, as saying that it was easy to see a defence threat emerging from Indonesia and citing as reasons Australia's vast size and small population and the extent of natural resources, as well as current policies relating to East Timor. It has to be said that the type of thinking indicated in the article is as erroneous and muddled as it is outdated.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government keeps under close review the question of what might constitute a threat to Australia's security. Quite apart from the question of Indonesia's capacity to mount such a threat, it is difficult on present analysis to understand why Indonesia would want to provoke a war with Australia; a war, as with most conflicts, that could bring no possible advantage.

The Australian Government is firmly committed to peace and has sought to maintain relationships, both internationally and regionally, conducive to that process. Whatever differences of opinion we might have with Indonesia on particular matters-I have referred to one such area in answers to other questions this week-we do regard Indonesia as a force for stability in the region, particularly as new areas of co-operation and trade develop.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. The Minister will be aware of complaints by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation that increasing amounts of Swedish beef are being dumped into Taiwan, Korea and Japan at the expense of the Australian product and, obviously, of Australian beef producers. He will also be aware that the Minister for Trade has expressed concern to Swedish authorities about the situation. I ask: When will the Minister for Primary Industry and the Minister for Trade explain to the farmers of Australia why Cabinet just last week rewarded Sweden for its pirating of Australia's beef markets by including it in the funded short list for the Royal Australian Navy's $2.6 billion submarine project? Will the Minister seek the support of the Minister for Trade in approaching the Minister for Defence and the Prime Minister with a view to excluding Sweden from this contract unless and until unfair dumping ceases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was necessary to listen to Senator Archer's question for only a minute to realise how stupid it was. It was a very silly question that was just asked. The suggestion implicit in the question was that, because Swedish beef was being sold in South East Asia, we should not consider buying, for example, a Swedish submarine or in any way trading with Sweden.

ANSWER.PARA: I ask Senator Archer to apply the example used in the case of Sweden to Japan. Is Senator Archer suggesting that because Japan has taken less Australian beef in the last year we stop taking Japanese products into Australia? Is Senator Archer suggesting that with the United States, too? That is exactly the silly principle which was implicit in the question asked.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a question of dumping.

—It is not a question of dumping. Senator Archer did not raise the question of dumping for a moment in the question. What he said was that Swedish beef was being sold in South East Asia. He did not use the word 'dumping' in the question.
—It is in the question.

—Anyway, in answer to the question, I will not ask the Minister for Trade, the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Primary Industry to consider retaliation against Sweden in the manner raised by Senator Archer. I will not ask them because I am not in the habit of asking my ministerial colleagues stupid questions.

—I address a question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. As he knows, the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill will be considered in the House of Representatives this afternoon as a consequence of the amendments to the Bill dictated by the Opposition. One of the key provisions of that Bill is the requirement that for a claim to succeed a reasonable hypothesis must be advanced linking disability or death to service. Is there any substance to allegations that this requirement effectively imposes an onus of proof on the pension claimant?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Hearn for her last question which raises again matters that have been the subject of some debate in both Houses of Parliament in recent times. I can give her and the Senate a categoric assurance that changes to the Repatriation Act arising from the Treasurer's statement on 14 May do not impose any onus of proof on pension claimants before repatriation authorities.

ANSWER.PARA: Section 25 of the Repatriation Act, which is not being amended, guarantees that no such onus will fall on the claimant. It further requires that the Department of Veterans' Affairs shall thoroughly investigate every claim and place before the authorities any evidence which is relevant to that claim. The requirement that for a claim to succeed a reasonable hypothesis must be advanced linking the veteran's disability or death to service does not alter this guarantee or obligation. This requirement has been introduced for just one purpose. I reiterate what I said yesterday: As a result of the High Court of Australia decision in the O'Brien case it is virtually impossible for the determining authorities which have been appointed to carry out a function on behalf of the Parliament to reject a pension claim, even in the absence of any evidence whatsoever linking disability to active service.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—This decision has horrendous implications for future Commonwealth spending and hence of course for the taxpayer. Of course, if Senator Macklin had voted for the tax Bills that this Government sought we would not need to reduce the deficit to the extent of $300m or $400m. Instead, he took an obstructive attitude in respect of those various pieces of legislation. The reasonable hypothesis requirement will return the determining system to the situation prevailing before the O'Brien decision. Seeing that this matter was raised yesterday and again today, I take this opportunity to inform the Senate of how the Collins English Dictionary defines the word 'hypothesis'. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: a suggested explanation for a group of facts or phenomena, either accepted as a basis for further verification (working hypothesis) or accepted as likely to be true.
I think that is a basis upon which any application before the determining authority ought to be considered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Trade aware of the report in yesterday's Australian Financial Review of the Government's concern about the threat posed to Australia's trade by the United States farm export bonus scheme which will enable the United States Commodity Credit Corporation to offer extra tonnages of farm goods as bonuses to countries which buy directly from the United States? In the light of that concern does the Minister now consider that cuts to the export market development grants scheme announced in May were ill-timed and ill-considered, given that our major trading competitors show every sign of engaging in an unrelenting trade war which will be at the expense of Australian export markets? Will the Government reconsider the cuts announced to the EMDG scheme and seriously consider introducing measures which help Australia's export industry to maintain and increase our export markets, such as rebates on import duties when those inputs are used to produce Australian exports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question bears a marked resemblance to an intelligent and thoughtful question asked by Senator Archer a few days ago. Yes, I have seen the reports in the newspaper of the proposed United States farm export bonus scheme. I have also seen some very thoughtful criticisms of that proposal from within the United States. Certainly, it seems to us to be a potentially very damaging and ill-considered proposal. The main burden of Senator Vigor's question relates to the cuts in the export market development grants scheme announced in the May mini-Budget. In my view those cuts were not ill-conceived or ill-considered. The implication of Senator Vigor's question is that naturally if one wants to promote exports in an increasingly hostile trading environment the best way to do it is to have an export market development grants scheme and pour more money into it. The Government has been increasingly concerned for some time about the effectiveness of the export market development grants scheme. An evaluation of the scheme by the Department of Trade disclosed that more than 50 per cent of the claimants under the scheme dropped out of it after three grant years, having generated little or no export sales at all. In summary, something like 50 per cent of the beneficiaries of the scheme generated no export sales at all.

ANSWER.PARA: Indeed, it was possible under the scheme for a claimant to receive up to the maximum grant of $200,000 a year for three years without ever producing an export sale. These findings, together with, I think, very well substantiated allegations of misuse and abuse of the scheme by some people, led to the review which was conducted and to the Government's ultimate decision in the matter which was announced in the May mini-Budget.

I also offer a personal view to Senator Vigor. It is no good spending a lot of money on an export grants development scheme if we do not have good things to sell. The real question is whether the scheme was properly targeted or whether money which has been spent for many years on that nice sounding scheme might not have been more beneficially directed into ways of ensuring that Australian industry had better products to sell. But that is just a philosophical difference which I have, perhaps, with some promoters of particular schemes who think that every problem can be cured by an immediate solution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation advise the Senate whether steps are in train to close the Darling Harbour helipad and whether any alternative arrangements are being made for a helipad site in the Sydney central business district?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sibraa asks me about the helipad in Sydney. At the outset I should explain that the provision of helipads in the Sydney central business district is solely the responsibility of the New South Wales Government. The national Government is involved, through the Department of Aviation, only in areas of operational safety and, of course, to that extent we have some vested interest in any changes contemplated by the New South Wales Government. The New South Wales authorities have advised the Department of Aviation of their intention to close the helipad at pier 39, Darling Harbour, as part of the reconstruction of that area by the Darling Harbour authority. I understand that the authorities in New South Wales have, however, not yet announced any other changes or when the closure will take place.

ANSWER.PARA: I am further advised that a number of alternative sites for helipads are being examined by the New South Wales authorities and the Department of Aviation, in response to New South Wales requests, has made safety and technical evaluations of those sites and has provided the results to the New South Wales Government. I therefore conclude by saying again that the provision and location of the helipads in Sydney are entirely the responsibility of the State Government, subject of course to the requirement that any proposed helipad must be in accordance with the safety and operational standards determined by the Department of Aviation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FEDERATED ENGINE DRIVERS AND FIREMEN'S ASSOCIATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy and the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is he aware of the alleged practice whereby officials of the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association in the Muswellbrook district office require payments from those looking for employment to be placed on a register? Is the Minister also aware that the payments required are accepted only in cash and that the amount varies from $1,000 upwards depending on where the individual is placed on the list? Is the Minister also aware that R. W. Miller &Co. Pty Ltd recently bypassed this system and employed 21 people through normal advertisements and that there has been a strike of over 1,400 Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association members in 11 mines in the Hunter Valley? Will the Minister advise what he intends to do to eliminate this despicable practice at Muswellbrook which has, yet again, damaged our reputation as a reliable supplier on international markets?

—I am aware that the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association has had a long-standing practice of submitting names to employers in the mining industry, particularly in the Upper Hunter Valley, and that it was the practice, until a recent controversy arose at the Mount Thorley mine, for the mining companies to accept the names of accredited FEDFA members put forward to them and to take them on in the order in which the names were submitted, provided they satisfied other criteria of work ability and so on. I am also aware that the R. W. Miller company at Mount Thorley has decided to terminate that practice, and that has given rise to the present dispute. I certainly am not aware of any suggestion hitherto that any money changes hands in relation to the placing of people's names on those lists. I simply say to Senator Parer that I hope that he has some reasonable evidence to support that allegation, because obviously it is a very serious one and certainly very libellous of the union and the officials who have practised that system over the years. If he has any hard evidence justifying the claims that he has made in this place, I suggest that he put it immediately before the appropriate authorities.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Will the Minister agree to have this matter investigated through either the Joint Coal Board or the Coal Industry Tribunal?

—I will agree to have it investigated when some hard evidence as to the nature of the practices in question is put forward by Senator Parer to me or to the police authorities. Otherwise, I will simply treat it, as I imagine the Joint Coal Board will, as a matter of scuttlebutt of a kind that is entirely familiar from right wing politicians when it comes to union practices. If there is any evidence to sustain it, obviously it is a matter that requires the fullest possible investigation. I will, of course, draw Senator Parer's question to the attention of the Joint Coal Board, I guess, in the first instance, so that its members know the sort of things with which they must deal in trying to resolve industrial disputes in the Upper Hunter Valley. But I repeat: The onus is squarely on Senator Parer, if he is to come into this place and make these sorts of allegations, either to put up or to shut up. By 'shutting up' I mean apologising as well to those workers and their representatives whom he has traduced by making these allegations. If he can put up, obviously the allegation and the use of parliamentary privilege for this purpose are justified. If he cannot put up, he ought to apologise posthaste.

—At Question Time today, Senator Messner asked me a question which was a follow-up question to one that he directed to Senator Grimes last week or earlier this week. I am advised that-and I quote-'Voluminous as it is', a copy of the computer print-out, 'Housing and statistics', which Senator Messner has requested, will be placed in the Table Office as soon as it can be run off. Apparently it is a very large document, and there has been some difficulty.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button)-by leave- proposed:

That the Senate, unless otherwise ordered, at its rising, adjourn till Tuesday, 20 August 1985 at 2 p.m., or such other day and/or hour as may be fixed by the President or, in the event of the President being unavailable, by the Deputy President, and that the day and/or hour of meeting so determined shall be notified to each Senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add:

Provided that the President, upon a request or requests by an absolute majority of the whole number of Senators that the Senate meet at a certain time, shall fix a day and hour of meeting in accordance with such request or requests, and such time of meeting shall be notified to each Senator.

For these purposes a request by the Leader or Deputy-Leader of the Opposition in the Senate shall be deemed to be a request by every Senator of the Opposition and a request by the Leader or Deputy-Leader of the Australian Democrats shall be deemed to be a request by every Australian Democrat Senator.
Provided further that the request or requests may be made to the President by leaving the same with, or delivering the same to, the Clerk of the Senate, who shall immediately notify the President.

In the event of the President being unavailable, the Clerk shall without delay notify the Deputy-President, or, should he be unavailable, any one of the Temporary Chairmen of Committees, who shall be deemed to be required by the Senate to summon the Senate on behalf of the President, in accordance with the terms of this Resolution.
This is the amendment which has been moved successfully for many sessions now.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button)-by leave-agreed to:
That leave of absence be granted to every member of the Senate from the termination of the sitting this day to the day on which the Senate next meets.

DEBATE.TITLE: GOVERNMENT RESPONSES TO PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE REPORTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a schedule in relation to the list of reports tabled by you, Mr President, in the Senate on 29 May 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The schedule read as follows-
SCHEDULE
GOVERNMENT RESPONSES TO PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE REPORTS
SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS
1. Burden of Proof in Criminal Proceedings Tabled 25.11.82 Interim responses 2.6.1983 and 15.12.1983
Final response provided in the Senate on 22.10.84.
2. Feasibility of a Contract or Makarrata between the Commonwealth and Aboriginal People Tabled 13.9.1983

The Government considers that the concept of Makarrata must be seen in the context of the efforts required to promote community acceptance for the concept of national land rights legislation. The wider issues involved in a Makarrata would make it difficult at this stage to enlist the support necessary to achieve constitutional amendment as recommended by the Committee.
SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS1. Tenure of Employment of Academics Tabled 9.9.1982 Interim response 15.12.1983

The Government is still engaged in consultation with the relevant unions and related organisations on matters associated with this report. There are still a number of issues to be settled. When these are finalised the Government will be in a position to complete its response to the Committee's report.

REPORT ON REPORTS
Tabling Statement by Senator Robert Hill

Because of time and resource constraints, it has not been possible for the Committee to attempt a detailed appraisal of each of the reports referred to it at this stage. In the first section of this report we report on a group of annual reports which in the main are concerned with the enforcement of Commonwealth criminal laws.
These reports are:
the Australian Federal Police Fifth Annual Report 1983-84;
the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions First Annual Report for period 5 March 1984-30 June 1984;
the Special Prosecutor, Mr R. V. Gyles QC's Second Annual Report 1983-84;
the Special Prosecutor, Mr R. V. Gyles QC's Final Report for period 1 July 1984-21 September 1984;
and the Special Prosecutor, Mr R. F. Redlich QC's Second Annual Report 1983-84.
As is stated in the Committee's report:

This is an area in which there have been some important recent developments such as the use of Special Prosecutors for the investigation and institution of prosecutions in relation to illegal activities identified by the Costigan Royal Commission into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union; the creation of the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions; and the establishment of The National Crime Authority.

The common thread running through the reports relating to criminal law enforcement is their recognition that if there is to be any reduction of crime in Australia there needs to be co-ordinated and vigorous law enforcement and the prosecution and stripping of assets of those people who derive large profits from such activity.

These annual reports are a very important part of the background to the Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Bill 1985 recently before Parliament. The Committee draws attention to the major points made in the reports and comments on the extent to which the Bill meets the points raised in the reports.
The Committee also reports at this stage on
the Criminal Injuries Compensation Ordinance First Annual Report 1983-84;
the High Court of Australia Fifth Annual Report 1983-84;
the Commonwealth Ombudsman and Defence Force Ombudsman Annual Reports 1983-84;
and the Trade Practices Commission Tenth Annual Report 1983-84
The Committee intends to report on the remaining reports referred to it in the Budget session.
I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Immediately prior to the luncheon adjournment I was speaking on the Australian Sports Commission Bill. I understand that new legislation will be introduced in the Senate this afternoon, which the Senate is required to deal with as a matter of urgency. As a result of that we have a very real difficulty with the amount of time available. Whilst the Senate might find itself denied the eloquence of the balance of my speech, I ask the Senate for leave to incorporate in Hansard the balance of my speech.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Georges

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a comment before I agree. It seems to me to be impossible under the Standing Orders for an honourable senator to incorporate a speech which he does not have prepared in a form which is legible for Hansard. I raise that point at this stage.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave Granted.
The speech read as follows-
In his second reading speech, the Minister pointed to a persistent theme, which he said had emerged during the investigations of the Interim Committee:
the need for a mechanism that allowed a much greater direct involvement by sport itself in determining needs, priorities and strategies for action

Yet under this legislation it appears that the priorities and strategies for action will be those that accord with the wishes of the Government. The Minister emphasises the ministerial control over the Commission in his second reading speech:

The Government is anxious to ensure that the Commission operates within the framework of overall government objectives and policies, which will guide the strategic plan to be prepared by the Commission for consideration by the Minister
Additionally, the Confederation of Australian Sport pointed out that:

In the appointment of Members of the Commission, sport has not been consulted, with the result that sport is concerned that many Commission decisions could be reached without reflecting a genuine sports' input

The other major part of this legislation is the provision for the National Sports Commission to form a company, the Australian Sports Aid Foundation, for the purpose of raising money for the development of sport.
The aim of this Foundation, according to the Prime Minister and the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, is:
To attract additional, private sector resources that can be used to support sports development programs that will benefit all levels of Australian sport . . .
It will, they assure us-
have the flexibility and autonomy required to generate additional funds from the private sector

I find it very hard to accept that the Australian Sports Foundation established under this legislation will be truly autonomous. The Commission is to form the Foundation, the Commission is to raise money through the Australian Sports Aid Foundation for the purposes of the Commission, and the Commission is to administer and expend money raised by the Australian Sports Aid Foundation.

It appears that the Australian Sports Aid Foundation will be very closely bound to the Commission's strategic plan which must of course be designed to fit in with Government policy, and requires ministerial approval. This is very far from my idea of an independent body.

Of course, the establishment of an Australian Sports Foundation will also increase the power of the Commission. As the Confederation of Australian Sport pointed out, this would lead to a position where the Commission would control:

All of the public sector funding of sport at a national level; a substantial amount of the private sector funding and sponsorship funds; and perhaps see itself as the clearing house for all sponsorship proposals for national sports.

In addition, the Minister has said that the Government is giving full consideration to the provision of full tax deductibility for donations to the foundation. This would or course have the effect of directing private sector funds to the Foundation-representing enormous sums of money. The Government estimates direct sponsorship of sport by the private sector is at least $50m.

These funds would then be distributed by the Commission, according to Government policy. In addition under this legislation, the Commission needs to have the written approval of the Minister to make grants, or lend money, or provide scholarships or like benefits.

Thus the Government has a remarkable degree of financial control over sport, without any obvious benefits for Australian sport. There are no guarantees of sports role in the Foundation to be found in the legislation, rather the dominant factor will be government policy.

Finally I would make the point that this legislation is a very good illustration of the differences of approach between the Liberal Party and the ALP. As Professor David Kemp put it in the autumn 1984 review of the Institute of Public Affairs:
Wise government . . . will not overburden itself by trying to take away the capacity to plan from individuals and groups and locate this authority in government itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will conclude the second reading debate. Because of the time constraints I will not make a detailed response to criticisms raised by the Opposition. I simply point out that the claims that there has not been consultation are quite wrong. There has been extensive consultation in the preparation of the legislation. Indeed, the modus operandi of the Australian Sports Commission will be consultation with sporting organisations and other relevant organisations. I think it is clear that there has been adequate and satisfactory consultation, given that expressions of support to the Commission have come from virtually all sporting organisations-for example, organisations associated with tennis; Australian football; rugby league; soccer; rowing; volley-ball; the Australian Olympic Federation; the Australian Institute of Sport; the Australian Sports Medicine Federation; and the Australian Council for Health, Physical Education and Recreation, amongst many others. So the Bill is the product of consultation. It is supported broadly throughout the sporting community. I believe it will achieve the objective of helping to support and stimulate a great variety of sporting activities which Australians enjoy. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

I have chosen to write to you direct rather than complete your Confederation's Questionnaire as I am concerned that certain answers may create an impression that the NFL is for one body and against the other.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little concerned about the fact that, although the Senate has been going to very great pains to consider the Government's program and to push through legislation quickly, some of the legislation which we have been dealing with over the last few days and which has been subject to relatively minor amendments-I think one amendment was in the telecommunications package of Bills and the other in the social security package-will not be dealt with by the House of Representatives. This chamber does not control the behaviour of the House of Representatives, but I would have thought that the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) had some say in the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been estimated that between $50,000 and $100,000 of the taxpayers' money is being spent on bringing back the House of Representatives. I am told that the House of Representatives will sit for a planned one hour under, no doubt, the usual procedures of gags and guillotines. In that hour two of the three Bills which have been amended in this place will not be dealt with and, therefore, will not become law until the Budget session. I find that not only strange but also rather offensive. I think most Australians would also regard it as rather offensive. I ask the Government to take urgent steps to ensure that the House of Representatives gets the messages which have been sent from this place and deals with them. To do less would be to short-change the taxpayers and the people of Australia.

It might be argued that this Senate should simply collapse in a heap on its amendments. I can only remind the Senate and the Government that, at the beginning of this session, a number of statements were made when the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Grimes) put down the program for the session. As I recall, we commented that it looked like we had a fairly heavy program. We talked about the fact that very often the Senate has been put in an awkward position with respect to dealing with legislation after the House of Representatives has risen. As I recall, it was common ground between the Opposition and the Australian Democrats that we were not going to be blackmailed out of dealing with legislation in the proper way by this sort of use or abuse of the Parliament.

I just want to say, on behalf of the Opposition, that we have shown a great deal of co-operation in the last two weeks of sitting to meet the requirements of the Government's program. We have forgone many debates. The Democrats gave up General Business last week and took a relatively small portion of time this week in return. We have not run matters of public importance debates on most of the days in the last two weeks of sitting. We have done a number of things to try to ensure that we will conclude the program in good order this afternoon. I would find it extremely offensive, as well as extremely wasteful, if the Bills which have been amended in this chamber were not dealt with by way of a message to the House of Representatives. I will register the strongest possible protest if that matter is not remedied immediately. I think it is a disgrace and I hope that the Government will do something about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Australian Democrats join in the rhetorical stakes on this one might I indicate that, while I fully understand what Senator Chaney has said, I believe it is quite possible that his remarks on this subject may prove premature.

—It is, of course, a matter for the Leader of the House (Mr Young) to determine the order of business in the House of Representatives. Certain discussions are taking place at this moment and I hope it will be possible to resolve the matter satisfactorily.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly welcome the comments that have come from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) because there is some very real concern on this side of the chamber about the repercussions that could occur-if the rumour that is going around the place at the moment turns out to be correct-in a number of areas, not least of which are those areas in the community that could have quite an unfortunate impact made on them by the non-implementation of some other clauses in the legislation. Senator Chaney was perfectly correct. Both his Party and ours made very clear statements that we believed that our role as members of parliament did not end when the House of Representatives rose; that we still saw the need to look at legislation on its merits and to amend it where necessary; and that we were not going to be either directly or indirectly blackmailed into passing, untouched, legislation brought into the Senate after the House of Representatives rose. For us to do that would simply be tantamount to saying that we did not have to be here at all, to giving the Government a blank cheque and virtually to saying that a bicameral system did not need to exist for some parts of the parliamentary year. The Government knew of the changes to the National Crime Authority legislation well over 24 hours ago-perhaps not quite so long; I think the session is getting to me--
