—I am right; it was the day before yesterday. The days are running into each other and I think that is affecting all of us. From memory the decision we took on the social security and repatriation legislation was made around 11 o'clock this morning, so there has been plenty of time for a Cabinet meeting, if it was necessary, to consider the legislation when a message was sent to the House. If there was not time for such a meeting, I would have thought that there was surely time for the Minister to speak to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) about it.
—That is all that would be necessary.

—Indeed, it is all that was necessary, as Senator Chipp says. I hope that the comments the Minister has made indicate that at least one of those two courses was taken and that good sense prevails, as it tends to do on the majority of occasions in this place, with the occasional hiccup, of which I hope this is not going to be one.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Amendment Bill 1985 and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Amendment Bill 1985 is to increase the rate of freight adjustment levy on Bass Strait crude from 1 January and from 1 March this year, and then to provide for increases in the levy as a percentage of the special freight allowance component of the import parity price for Bass Strait crude so that the levy, in effect, will be adjusted to the import parity pricing formula so long as it remains.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bass Strait freight adjustment levy is an attempt by the Government to reconcile some converging interests within the refining industry between refiners in Victoria and those in New South Wales and Queensland particularly. It is not a scheme that the Opposition has been very happy with. In fact, we criticised it and we support these proposed amendments only as an interim arrangement. The Opposition hopes that there will be an early move to a free market and that in that much more satisfactory atmosphere there will not be the same complaints or need for such legislation as this. Unfortunately, when the Senate is about to rise, this is not the time to engage in a debate on the important subject of a free market for oil, but hopefully there will be opportunity for debate on that at an early date in the Budget session.

The package of legislation to amend the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act and associated Acts is important. Although the Opposition supports it, it is certainly a matter which should be the subject of a good deal of consideration and debate in this chamber. This package of Bills makes a large number of important amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act and associated legislation. They have been the result of a good deal of work over many years and they make some very useful changes to the legislation.

The most important of those changes is to introduce for the first time the availability of retention leases. This has been needed for some time in the industry. It will be welcomed by the industry and I am glad that the Government has rearranged its program today at the last minute to enable this legislation to be passed. The legislation had been sitting at the bottom of the Notice Paper for some time and until the last minute it looked as though the Government had forgotten about it. The Opposition welcomes the fact that it is now being brought on this afternoon, even in this rush, so that it can be passed and so that the industry can have the benefit of the proposals for retention leases.

Without going into further discussion about the nature of those proposals and the nature of the legislation concerning them, the Opposition expresses its very grave concern that there are proposals floating around from the Government-proposals which have no doubt been inspired from the highest sources in the Government-about prohibitive fees being imposed for retention leases which may well render them to be of no commercial value or of very little commercial value once they have been introduced. This legislation does not do that; it provides for a reasonable lease fee at a mid-point between existing fees applying for exploration permits and production licences.

During the debate on the proposed cash bidding legislation rejected by this chamber a couple of weeks ago, the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, indicated that the Government would be looking at alternative measures to make up the expected revenue shortfall. He noted two possible measures to which the Government is giving consideration; namely, a retention lease premium of, possibly, $10m, or a signature bonus for the granting of leases in highly prospective areas. I do not know whether these proposals were made simply in a fit of pique at the rejection of the legislation, but very serious concern has been expressed about them by the industry. The Opposition sincerely hopes that the Government is not seriously proposing to go ahead with the proposal for a premium of the order of $10m for a retention lease. Certainly, that proposal justifies entirely the concern of industry that the whole cash bonus bidding system was a revenue raising exercise. That was always strenuously denied by the Government, yet at the very moment that that proposal was about to be defeated the Government has made these suggestions. This legislation does not contain that proposal, but in the light of what Senator Gareth Evans has said, and other statements that have emanated from the Government, the industry has raised a very great concern about it. This Parliament is putting through a proposal of great benefit to the industry, one which it has required and sought for a long time; yet at the same time there are suggestions floating around which, if implemented, would render it virtually useless to the industry. Perhaps the Minister in his reply will give some indication of present Government thinking on that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support this legislation for very much the reasons Senator Durack has mentioned and also share the concern he has expressed at the rumours that have gone right through the oil industry. I have had several communications today and yesterday indicating that the Government is considering increasing what is now a very modest and eminently reasonable retention lease fee of $4,500 a block, which is half the fee for a production lease, to some very vast figure. The amount of $10m has been mentioned in the telegrams and representations I have had today. This is basically a retaliation on the part of the Government because it was not able to get cash bonus bidding through this Parliament. I hope, as does Senator Durack, that all this talk is merely a manifestation of the natural irascibility of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) when he does not get his way, which we have seen before, and that he would not consider putting in a retention lease fee which would have the consequence of discouraging further exploration.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to cash bonus bidding, the Government showed a remarkable predeliction for killing the goose that laid the golden egg. We caution it not to contemplate doing the same thing here. It also should not resort to dirty tricks such as considering this as a Budget Bill or device of that kind if it wants to increase it at some stage. It is relevant that since these Bills are directed towards increased exploration, particularly in off-shore gas prone areas and in deep water, the question of our own fuel self-sufficiency becomes a factor.

I sound a note of warning to the Government and the community that the status of Australian oil reserves is not as reassuring as it was even a short time ago. That has a very direct bearing on whether or not pressure should be applied to the industry to extract more money from it somehow to get money up front before it gets the chance to explore. As it stands now, of the 231 million cubic metres of demonstrated recoverable oil as at 30 June last year, 200 million cubic metres is in the Gippsland basin area. There also is the largest resource of demonstrated sub-economic oil; some 31 million cubic metres of the national total of 57 million cubic metres. So these figures demonstrate the extent to which Australia's oil dependence has rested on one region which is now rapidly being depleted. We had hoped that Jabiru would be the discovery which would solve all of that, with initial projections of 200 million barrels. These projections have been downgraded to around 40 million barrels. This has caused a revision of world production estimates by the Bureau of Mineral Resources. Far too little notice has been taken of this and far too little mention made of it. The estimate has decreased from 185 million barrels a year in 1985 to 160 million barrels a year in 1988. That implies that our self-sufficiency and the time in which we can rely on getting oil from our own resources are much less than it was thought in the past. Predictions of one kind or another exist, of course, but it is a very risky business. Oil is not an infinite resource and at some stage the rate of discovery will decline. We have no way of knowing in advance when that will be but, as I have said, the latest BMR projections show us that it will be a lot sooner than we thought even a year or so ago.

The Jabiru situation should point Australia again to the urgent need, not only to encourage exploration and development through measures such as are contained in these Bills as they stand, but also to develop the technology of alternative energy sources. It is very depressing to note that the Government is spending so little on alternative energy sources. In 1983 the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, for instance, spent only 0.8 of one per cent of the total research budget on renewable energy. An area which deserves increased research and development is the production of methanol from natural gas. We have vast resources of natural gas, the rate of discovery of which far exceeds that of oil. It has been demonstrated by known technology, including by our neighbour, New Zealand, that this can be converted to methanol and to petrol. It can be a useful motor spirit. In California cars running on methanol now use about one million gallons every year. In 1979 the State legislature set aside $10m to investigate these alternative fuels. There have been some claims made before that these methods will not work. The results demonstrate that on a fleet basis they are successful. Motor vehicles run well and successfully using this fuel and could be expected to do so in Australia.

The strategic implications of these Bills are obvious. I will not go into them. They are recognised by New Zealand and should be recognised here. We probably have enough crude oil in known fields and in projected funds to meet our needs to the year 2000, which is 15 years away. The lead time for methanol production is at least five years. The changeover time for the automobile industry to produce a significant number of suitable cars is very much longer than that. I urge the Government that the time to begin the changeover to alternative fuels, such as methanol, or at least to begin active planning in that area, is now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for their support for these measures and I wish them an appropriately speedy passage. There are many issues which, if we had time, it would be pleasant to debate but I will have to defer that debate until--
—It might not be pleasant but they are important.

—I would be very happy to debate those matters with Senator Durack or anybody else, even Senator Mason, in the Budget session. As to the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Amendment Bill 1985 and allied Bill legislation, I acknowledge that not everyone is totally happy with the freight equalisation formula. I know that people are never likely to be happy with it because there is an element of compromise about it. I simply say, as I have said to the industry, that in the event that we do not move to a free market situation in January next, as has been foreshadowed as a possibility following the very extensive policy review going on at the moment, I am happy to undertake to review the freight equalisation arrangements as I was requested to do, I think by Senator Durack, in the latter part of this year. Whether that review will produce any variation from the existing formula remains to be seen but I certainly acknowledge that it is a continuing source of debate within the industry and deserves further evaluation if the present regime is to continue beyond the end of this year.

SPEECH.PARA: I now refer to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Bill and allied Bills. Senator Durack said that a very large number of important changes are made in the legislation. There does not seem to be either the time or the necessity to debate them now. Both Senator Durack and Senator Mason raised the possibility of more substantial fees being imposed for retention leases than those presently provided in the legislation. I say simply that the alleged proposals floating around are no more than that at this stage and, certainly, the Government has made no decision on the matter. I assure the Senate and the industry that there would be full consultation with the industry as to the impact of any such fees on the retention licences that we are creating today before any such decision were to be made. I repeat: The cash bidding legislation was not designed primarily as a revenue raising matter. I have said that endlessly during the debate on that; I repeat it now. I said, as I have said over and over again, that revenue was a secondary consideration, and it was there on the books as a secondary consideration. The Government will have to have regard to the implications of the rejection of the cash bidding legislation from a revenue point of view. It will do so in the Budget context; but at this stage it is quite premature to speculate on what course of action, if any, the Government might adopt in this respect.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or requests or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Opposition does not oppose this necessary legislation. Indeed, I am in receipt of a telex from the Wool Council of Australia seeking its urgent passage because of the wild fluctuations in the Australian dollar. This legislation will merely assist internal rearrangements of the funding for wool research, development, promotion, marketing and all the rest of it. The Opposition supports this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have had a request from the wool industry to have this legislation passed this afternoon, I seek the indulgence of the Senate to have a few notes incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Speech on Wool Industry Amendment Bill Package 1985

The Wool Industry is vital to the Australian economy, with exports expected to hit a record 2.5 billion dollars this financial year. Since the breaking of the drought the market has continued to make strong gains and has, since January this year, risen by more than 13%. Furthermore, forward estimates are predicting an 8% price increase for next season, over this season's prices.
The weakening Australian dollar against the U.S. currency resulted in an immediate increase of 48c a kilo, bringing the average cost of wool to 563c a kilogram-an all time high.

World consumption of wool rose by 3% in 1983 and is now at its highest level in 12 years. Therefore a combination of a devalued dollar, increased demand and favourable seasonal conditions have given some cheer to local woolgrowers, merchants and the Australian Wool Corporation. In fact, the Australian Wool Corporation is now to the point where it is almost out of debt and its wool stockpile could drop below the 1 million bale mark by the end of the season. The current situation is ample vindication for the Australian Wool Corporation buying stance and reserved buying decision for the stockpile may prove advantageous to the trade as supplies decline toward the end of the season. I congratulate the Corporation on its judgment.

China, a significant user of Australian wool continued to attract market development interest and in the years to come could become one of our major markets. China's plans for the modernisation and expansion of their own wool textile industry include a significant demand for technology transfer and Australia has demonstrated that it can help considerably in this area. The Prime Minister's wool initiative with China (similar to his steel initiative) though not fully developed and still in its infancy needs to be approached with some degree of caution in that there could be problems if the plan were too grandiose and delivery of the full program was seen to falter.

The Australian Wool Corporation is presently endeavouring to identify and develop new markets for Australian wool with the aim of increasing wool textile production in developing countries. In addition it is the main contributor to the International Wool Secretariat contributing almost two thirds of the I.W.S. budget in 1983-84.

(Funds are provided for world wide wool promotion in proportion to the weight of its net exports of wool.) Perhaps the greatest challenge now facing the Corporation is determining the relativity between wool types for SUPPORT and reconciling differences in support from State to State. In setting floor prices for wool or tariff levels for manufacturers I think that consideration should be given to exchange movements.

Although the demand for wool is increasing, competition from both cotton and synthetic fibres remains intense with synthetic fibre manufacturers claiming to have made further technological improvements in their fibres. In order to remain competitive production rates in the Australian Textile Industry have increased dramatically. This in turn has placed great demand on the quality of wool fibres. Considerable problems have occurred in recent years at various stages of production with poorer quality wool but C.S.I.R.O. processing trials should help to identify scouring conditions necessary to achieve optimum wool quality and processing efficiency throughout all stages of manufacture.

As wool is sold in highly competitive markets, we must ensure that our products are not disadvantaged in any way by other fibres and that we at least maintain our market share. The Wool Industry's growth and future prosperity will depend very much on our ability to find and develop new markets, to improve the economic efficiency of all stages of production, processing and marketing of wool and on our ability to meet the changing and challenging demands of the world textile and fashion markets. Research, marketing and wool promotion are vital, both to the wool industry and to the Australian economy.

Since the Wool Tax Acts of 1964, woolgrowers have paid a levy of 8% of the sale value of shorn wool. 5% of this was allocated through the Wool Tax Act to the Australian Wool Corporation for market support. Additional wool tax regulations divided the remaining 3% between wool promotion and market administration expenses (2.5%) and research (0.5%). The New Wool Industry Amendment Bill will enable these apportionments to be varied slightly on the recommendation of the Wool Council of Australia. The Council would like to be able to vary the wool market support component of wool tax receipts between 4 and 5 percentage points instead of the rigid 5% as it now stands and to make corresponding variations in the apportionments to wool promotion and research.

This need for flexibility has been brought home by the falling value of the dollar. In spite of returning higher prices to some woolgrowers, the devaluation has resulted in an increase in the funding required from Australian woolgrowers to meet their commitment to the International Wool Secretariat. This increase could amount to $25 million in 1985-86. Thus, it is of considerable importance that this Bill be passed before the 1985-86 selling season so that variations can be made in the allocation to wool promotion as recommended by the Australian Wool Council.

These amendments to the Act would enable additional funds to be directed to wool promotion or research whenever necessary to ensure that Australia retains its competitive position. The focus of consumer and fashion demand is presently on light weight high quality fibres of 23 microns or finer. With record prices being paid for superfine wool (19 microns) Tasmania has long been renowned for its fine and superfine merino wool and this year a record price of 16800c per kilogram was paid by Fujii Keori of Japan for superfine wool produced by Mr Jim McEwan of Cressy.

Also in recognition of the tremendous contribution the Taylor family of ''Winton'' have made to the superfine wool industry, Fujii Keori uses the name ''Winton'' on its top quality products. The ''Winton'' stud near Campbell Town in the Tasmanian Midlands has been operated continuously for 150 years by the Taylor family and theirs is one of the few remaining studs in the world to breed pure saxon merino sheep.

There are many other Tasmanian families like the McEwans and Taylors who have had a great influence on the Tasmanian wool industry. These include the Cameron family from Ross, the Thirkells from Cressy, O'Connors of Cressy and Avoca, Gibsons of Epping, Dunbabins of the East Coast, Dowlings of Ross and the Scotts from Ross. In mentioning so few families I am probably doing an injustice to other people who have made a significant contribution to the industry in Tasmania in recent years.

However, these high returns are not being received by producers of broader wool types. In fact, prices for 25 to 27 micron wool fell this year, resulting in substantial increases in Corporation stockpiles of these types. However, devaluation is helping these and other broader types to clear.

Thus we need to develop and exploit new opportunities for wool and new products that will utilise these coarser wools. Most of the carpets which utilise coarser wools are imported into Australia from New Zealand but I am pleased to report that once again Tasmania is leading the way for the rest of Australia. A recent $1 million contract to supply axminster carpets to the Sheraton Hotel in Hawaii places Tascot Templeton in a favourable position on the world carpet market. To remain competitive we need to develop new fibres, yarns and specialised yarn blends and develop new fashion products particularly leisure and sportswear.

More money must be directed into textile research and research into a whole range of issues including improved production, diseases in sheep, breeding programs, biotechnology, improved pasture species, wool harvesting and the development of improved wool measuring instruments.

The optimism shown by the Wool Council of Australia in recent months is, I feel, well founded and the flexibility provided for in this Bill should assist the wool industry to compete more effectively in the world market.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or requests.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button) proposed:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today during the luncheon period a number of honourable senators who are leaving the Senate after various periods of service made speeches which, in a sense, were valedictory speeches. I do not want to speak at length on behalf of the Government in relation to the speeches that were made. Let me say at the outset, however, that a naughty thought occurred to me when those honourable senators were speaking: Why do they not leave every Friday? I say that in the spirit that they were all very fine speeches which, in a sense, summarised the views they have individually expressed over many years in this chamber. I noted that for probably the first time in their careers each of the honourable senators who spoke was listened to with great respect by the chamber. That is something that has not happened here in the last 15 or 16 years in the case of Senator Scott, or the last two or three years for Senator Jack Evans.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose my greatest association with Senator Cyril Primmer has been as a senator for Victoria. We were senators in very gloomy days for the Australian Labor Party and travelled together around the country. I regard Senator Primmer as a mate and will always do so. We developed that mateship, I think, working together as senators from Victoria. I do not want to go in detail into his service on various committees of the Senate and so on. I just want to say that as a contributor here he has always been a stirrer, and that is not a bad thing to be. Since we have been in government he has stirred us quite a bit on numerous issues. He has played a catalyst role in the chamber, quite apart from his service on parliamentary delegations and committees, and we will certainly miss him.

Senator Scott said that I once supported him for the Deputy Presidency on the basis that I liked the way he read the prayers. I liked the speech he gave today too. It was a very dignified speech and, if I may say so, a very well structured speech, because in a sense he related what he felt when he first came into this chamber and the contribution he thought he could make to what he feels now, on leaving. I suppose in one sense it is sad that we will all do that. We will not feel that terribly much progress has been made. Nonetheless, we will have advanced important points of view in the Senate, and I know Senator Scott has done that over the period he has been here. I say personally to Senator Scott that I think at times he has even tolerated my views on rural issues. We have had the opportunity of discussing them together and I, from time to time, have learned a number of things from him and I very much appreciate that personally; Senator Scott has always been, if I might use an old-fashioned word, a gentleman in dealing with everybody in the Senate, including us, and that has been a very nice quality about his presence here.

Senator Lajovic was elected 10 years ago. I thought he explained in a very poignant speech his history as an Australian and as a senator. I think he did us more than kindness in saying how flattered he was to be a member of this chamber. I guess most of us see it as an honour, but sometimes we wonder whether it is such an honour to be elected to this chamber and to listen to some of the debates that take place. Senator Lajovic has contributed a very strong point of view, with which not all of us would agree from time to time but which we have certainly learned to respect. He has also improved my knowledge in Russian history immensely and kept me aware during the last few weeks by having me read a biography of Peter the Great, which has been an interesting experience.

Senator Jack Evans has been here less time than the others. I have already spoken to him and expressed my appreciation of his vigorous interest in a wide range of issues, many of which concern my portfolio responsibilities. I think he has been very fair to deal with and I appreciate his enthusiasm. I do not always agree with him, of course, but it would be strange if I did. He has played a very lively role in the Senate since he came here and we are sorry about his retirement and replacement by a senator from the Nuclear Disarmament Party.

Senator Jean Hearn has been a senator since 1980, following Ken Wriedt into this chamber. She has taken a very active interest in a number of social reform issues. We have perhaps seen that more in the Australian Labor Party than in the Senate. She has been a member of the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts since September 1981 and she has pursued those interests very vigorously. She has also been a very active senator in Tasmania. I had some objection to her activities from time to time because she kept sending me missives about what she had discovered at the Longford branch of the Labor Party about a particular social problem. Things like that are not always easy to deal with. I just give that as an example of her vigour which has caused problems for me.

I do not wish to say any more. I just wish to say on behalf of the Government that we value the contributions which have been made by departing senators. I think we can collectively say that we respect them all, although we may not necessarily have agreed with them all on various issues. In each case, we wish them a long and happy retirement. It is much nicer to be speaking in this form of valedictory speech than in the normal condolence motions which we sometimes have in the chamber. In the case of the retiring senators, we wish them a long life and a very happy retirement. We hope that we will see them back here from time to time as our visitors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I express best wishes to the five retiring senators. I endorse almost everything said by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in his remarks. I will not be up to my usual annoying self and pick out those little bits I disagree with. Instead, I will address some additional remarks, particularly to the two retiring senators from the coalition.

SPEECH.PARA: I had a very difficult early time with Senator Doug Scott. I had two major complaints against him. First of all, he is about 20 years my senior and one of the early experiences I had in this place was to be taken on to a squash court and absolutely whipped by Senator Scott, who at that time was suffering from a very bad hip. That was bad enough, but after I had been here for a little while I went home and my wife said to me: 'There is only one senator who always speaks sense'. I asked who that was and she said that it was Senator Scott. She has not made such a complimentary remark about any other senator that I can recall. I can only say that it has taken me most of the 11 years that I have shared the Senate with Senator Scott to get over those two initial obstacles in our relationship.

Senator Scott has made a very wide contribution in this place. He tended to be a little self-deprecating in his comments earlier today when he said that whilst he had had almost every position-it is true that he has had every position from your own, Mr President, very briefly to the deputy presidency; he has been a Minister, a Party leader, a committee man, a leader of delegations and so on, all of which is contained in the parliamentary records-he had not had many of those jobs for long. In fact, he was Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia from 1976 to 1980 and the Leader of it from 1980 to 1985. He has been one of the great constants of the Senate in the time that I have been here. I have always found him utterly reliable.

Having read the maiden speech he made in 1970, part of which he quoted earlier today-indeed, the very paragraph I had intended to refer to this afternoon-I can only say of Senator Doug Scott that I believe that he has consistently represented the values that he expressed in his maiden speech. No one can ask more of a representative than that. I would like to repeat one of the five points he made at lunch time today as I think it is a lesson to all of us in times when political theories tend to be advanced with great enthusiasm. Doug Scott said in his maiden speech:
We should temper our concern for pure theory with social and political considerations lest we become slaves to ivory towered conceptions.

I think there was a bit of an echo of Doug Scott's words in what was said by Senator Jean Hearn. Doug, I say to you on behalf of the Opposition that I hope we remember all of your five points. I for one will certainly remember that fifth point in the years ahead in opposition and, I hope, in government. I thank you for what I think has been an outstanding contribution to the Senate. I wish you and your wife well in what I know will be a very happy retirement from this place.

Senator Lajovic was kind enough to say when he came here that it was the proudest moment of his life. I think that was a very nice thing to say about arriving in the Senate and it is good that he still feels much the same about it 10 years later. Senator Lajovic's expression of pleasure at being here reminds me of the story about an American senator who said that he spent his first three months in the American Senate wondering how he got there and he spent the rest of his career wondering how everybody else got there. I think there may be a touch of that in your career, too, Misha. Although for you it was a wonder to you to arrive here, as you have seen more of it I am sure that you have come to understand that in this representative chamber you have had a very proper and appropriate place.

It should be part of the record this afternoon that the surprising thing is not that Senator Lajovic became a senator, but the fact that Senator Lajovic survived to come to Australia. If honourable senators have read any of the history of Senator Lajovic's original country in the period in which he lived there, they will know that he lived through dangerous and difficult times. Whatever one's politics in those days, life was very difficult. The complex battles which were fought, in both an intellectual and a military sense, during Misha's early lifetime I am sure took their toll of many of his contemporaries. I have often thought that it is an extraordinary coincidence that a Slovenian child, born when Misha was, should arrive here in the Senate, but it is even more extraordinary that he survived. We are very pleased that you did, Misha, and that you have graced this chamber.

In Senator Lajovic's maiden speech, he told us that immigrants had provided 59 per cent of the growth of population since 1947. Most of us in this place are not of first generation immigrant stock; we are all of immigrant stock. I simply wish to say that as a member of the Liberal Party I was always very proud of the fact that Senator Lajovic was one of our representatives. I am sorry that his obvious accent will be missing from this place because I believe that that alone was an encouragement to the great mass of immigrants who have come to this country, and you were a very good demonstration of what can be done. Your account of your early life here, which was very similar to the early life of so many post-war migrants, and your subsequent success in every sense in this country, are things we should all remember. On behalf of Opposition members, I thank you for your contribution to us, both in immigration debates and across the whole spectrum.

I am reminded by what Senator Button said of the comment made by Senator Wheeldon after, sadly, not the retirement but the death of Senator Greenwood, when he said that there was so much that Senator Greenwood said that he disagreed with, but he thought the loss of Senator Greenwood was the loss of the voice of a very important group in the community which would not be represented so readily thereafter. Senator Lajovic has represented a section of the Australian community in particular which, without him, will not be so well represented, although I can assure Senator Lajovic that we will do our best.

As far as Senator Primmer, Senator Hearn and Senator Jack Evans are concerned, time does not permit me to say anything further, because I am sure other senators wish to speak. I say only that each of them has made, in my view and in the view of the Opposition, a significant contribution in this place. I join with Senator Button in saying that the speeches which have been made today are a useful reminder of the principles that brought each of those senators in here and of what they sought to achieve here. The Opposition wishes all of them well and hopes they will have very happy and useful retirements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the Australian Democrats in paying tribute to the five senators who are retiring. As I listened to the speeches of honourable senators I could not help remarking to myself how the Parliament has changed, over the 25 years that I have been a member, in the human relationships that exist between people. Probably the most abstemious senators here, Senator Haines and Senator Macklin, coerced me the other night to go into the members' bar to have an end of session drink with them. It is the first time I have been in that bar for four or five months and it was totally empty. When I came to the Parliament almost every member of the Parliament, from both the Senate and the House of Representatives, used to go into that bar regularly. The Country Party members were always on the left hand side for some obscure reason. For an even more obscure reason all Australian Labor Party members were on the extreme right. The Liberals used to drink in the middle. Everybody had two drinks on average, and then went to dinner. During that half hour there was an interchange of views and personalities between all parties; there was a lot of fun and a number of personalities around the place. In latter years, that fun and those personalities seem to have gone. I think the Parliament is poorer for it. For example, I have probably spent only five minutes in private conversation with Senator Jean Hearn during the whole of her tenure here and I think that is a pity. We also seem to be breeding a new race of politicians-very sincere, earnest people who are so busy with themselves and their parliamentary duties that the time for fun and social intercourse with one another seems to be going.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not like to sound like an old soldier but I wonder where are the characters like Eddie Ward, Bill Wentworth, Les Haylen, George Pearce, Bert Kelly, Jeff Bate, Kennelly, Murphy, Wheeldon, McLaren, Gair, Cormack, Paltridge, et cetera. They do not seem to be here any more. I think the Parliament is poorer for it.

I can remember an incident which presiding officers like you, Mr President, would frown upon, and which we do not have any more. It was rumoured that Bill Wentworth changed his personality in the House of Representatives at the time of every full moon. One evening he was speaking in his brilliant way denouncing the Communist Party and the evil in it. Les Haylen had gone down to the bar to borrow a white coat from the barman. The barmen here used to wear white coats then. He stood next to Bill Wentworth in the House and said: 'Excuse me, sir, the green cart is waiting for you.' Of course he was chucked out. I suppose it is one of those incidents at which one had to be present to know how funny it was. Characters like Les Haylen and Wentworth do not seem to be here any more. Perhaps it is a better place; perhaps it is not.

I can remember Senator Chaney's father being the mischievous organiser of a game of football every Thursday night in room U41. About six of us were involved-Malcolm Fraser, Bill Snedden, Fred Chaney Snr, Shane Paltridge and a few others. We used to manufacture a paper football and allow the frustrations and latent hatreds of the week to come out. I can remember being a little vigorous with Malcolm Fraser on several occasions at those games of football. We had that kind of experience with one another.

I knew little of Cyril Primmer until we joined the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania. We served on that Committee together for six or seven months. I got to know Cyril Primmer very well, which I had not done to that stage. I formed an incredibly high respect, admiration and affection for him. He is a decent, straight and caring man. In all that time I never heard him speak ill of any other human being.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except in the Department of Foreign Affairs.
—I have that reference in my note too. Only on one occasion have I heard him speaking vigorously in the Senate. Whether we agreed with him or not I admired the way he stuck to his personal campaign.
—He proved to be right.

—Yes, he did. He stuck to his personal campaign on that. Although he displeased Senator Gareth Evans from time to time-probably with good reason on that issue-he was, as Senator Georges said, proved to be right. The thing that is terrific about Cyril Primmer is that over recent years he has seemed to look younger every year. He is looking forward with such zest to his retirement down on that farm of his in the Western District that I am sure that if we see him in a year or two he will be looking like a callow youth by then. We wish you well, Cyril, in your retirement.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a similar affection for Doug Scott. As I think Senator Button said, Senator Scott is not only a gentleman but also a gentle man. I certainly will miss the contribution he makes to this place and the example of honour and decency that he sets; but perhaps I will miss mainly the very pleasant conversation we have every morning when the cricket is on about selecting the Australian team and making very erudite comments about its performance and about who should open the bowling and who should open the batting.

I have one other comment that I would like to make about Senator Scott at this stage. Many people will forget that he was appointed a Minister and remained a Minister for about 12 months. He belongs to the same party as Ian Sinclair, who at that time had temporarily stood down or been stood down from the Ministry. It was essentially for that reason that Doug Scott became a Minister-it was his turn because of his ability and his seniority. But when Ian Sinclair was cleared of the charges and Malcolm Fraser decided to reinstate him in the Ministry, the gracious and generous way in which Doug Scott put his own ministerial career to one side and did not rock the boat within the National Party was an example of selflessness to all honourable senators.

With respect to Senator Lajovic, I think he summed matters up himself in his speech. Having been a member of the Liberal Party-but this could apply to any political party-I know how difficult it is to get preselection, particularly on a Senate ticket. Senator Lajovic had disadvantages in the gaining of preselection in the Liberal Party that nobody else here has faced. He overcame those disadvantages-the accent, the fact that he was born in another country, and so forth. It is to his eternal credit that he was able, by sheer persuasion and by his example, to gain preselection. I hope that, in the trip that he takes when he leaves, he will give the warm regards of my wife and me to that town by a certain sea in my wife's country of Austria, which, if I were to name here, Mr President, you would rule me out of order-for wrong reasons, but quite properly so. That is a private joke that Senator Lajovic and I share. His delightful European sense of humour has enchanted us all.

I do not know Senator Hearn very closely. I have been impressed with the interest and the compassion that she has always shown, in the few speeches she has made, for people less fortunate than herself, and with the great concern she has shown for the welfare of animals and about cruelty to them.

It is Senator Jack Evans for whom I reserve my final comments. This may well be no reason for other senators to thank him, but had it not been for Jack Evans there would be no Australian Democrats today. Contrary to popular belief, when I resigned from the Liberal Party in 1977, my whole intention was to get out of politics. The last thing in my mind was to help to form a new political party. It was Jack Evans, whom I had not met then, who pleaded with me to come and address a meeting in Perth. It was in Perth, with Jack Evans chairing an overflowing meeting in the Perth Town Hall, that the Australian Democrats were born. I regard it as a tribute to Jack Evans personally that my friends in the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party say that the Democrat senator they least like to deal with is Jack Evans-not because he is unpleasant, but because he is such a tough negotiator and so unyielding in the deals that he pushes for the Democrats. I think that is a tribute in itself. I can say that there is no harder working Democrat-in fact there is no harder working senator-than Senator Evans. He will be dreadfully missed in this place. I am sure we will see him back. I wish him and his wife godspeed in their visit overseas and for the future.

I do not know how many people listen to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation broadcasts of Parliament, but this I do know: I reckon I can name at least five people who will be silly enough, nostalgic enough, and sentimental enough to be regular listeners to the Senate in the next few years. I wish all those honourable senators well. I congratulate them on their service to the community and to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — On my own behalf and on behalf of the rest of the members of the National Party of Australia in this chamber, I wish to be associated with the remarks that have already been made. One of the attributes of this place is one that too few people are aware of. Even though honourable senators are elected as representatives of political parties, it is not long before their colleagues see them as individuals. No matter what a senator may think he is, no matter what cloak or ego he hides behind when he comes here, he is soon stripped down to the bare essentials and people see him as he is and treat him as they find him. On occasions such as this, we really see that happen. We heard some very moving speeches at midday when the retiring senators spoke to us. Now, we are all speaking on the valedictory. The very nature of the Senate, with its committee system, has been alluded to. Honourable senators cannot work within the committee system without getting an appreciation of each other's qualities. In gaining an appreciation of each other's qualities, we get to know each other so much better.

SPEECH.PARA: I, like Senator Chipp, have not come to know Senator Hearn very well. One quality that has come across is her concern and compassion for other people, particularly those less fortunate than we are and the underdog. Her concern for world peace is something which we all share. We probably differ on the way that it should be achieved. Senator Primmer, my old dairy farmer mate, if you like, and I on quite a few occasions sat here late at night and reminisced and decided that any sensible dairy farmer would have been in bed long ago, and indeed he would have. Cyril, it has been great to know you. It has been great to serve with you in this place and, indeed, on some committees. You have been a stirrer at times, but we all appreciate that. As Senator Button said, this place needs stirring every so often.

When I was thinking about what to say to Senator Jack Evans, I thought: 'By gee, it was just last Wednesday that I was pouring bucketsful of scorn on the Australian Democrats'. I might add I was enjoying it too. That is one of the ironies of this place. If I could misquote the Bard: 'On Wednesday I came to bury you; today I am here to praise you'. In your short time here, we have learnt to appreciate your qualities, your debating ability and the way that you have hung tenaciously to your ideals and put forward the Democrats' position on the matters in which you have expertise.

It has been a great privilege to know Misha Lajovic. I suppose, if I were to live a half a dozen lifetimes, I would not have to go through the experiences that Misha and Tatjana had to go through to be part of a democratic society. Misha told us that when he left his home country and got a job as an interpreter he never dreamed that one day not only would he be an Australian but also part of one of the highest forums in this land. He said that that says a lot for Australia. Misha, that says a lot about you and your qualities.

I refer now to my colleague Doug Scott. On a previous occasion I remarked that when the bells rang Doug was usually out of the door before I was. I can see his rollicking gait as he walked down the passageways ahead of me as though he was still on the bridge of a Fairmile. I think the term he uses is 'going flat out, 22 knots, and everything rattling'. But with the even beat of an old engine driver I can soon pass him and get to the chamber before him. All the things that have been said about Doug are true. He has been a Whip's delight. He did whatever was required of him. He gave his complete loyalty. If we wanted him to talk for five, 10 or 20 minutes, he did it. The important thing about it was that when we read his speeches they all made sense. We cannot all admit to that when we have had to filibuster on certain occasions.

Doug, you have made a great contribution. You have been a gentleman and a scholar. We all know about that hip of yours. My only concern is that you do not make a claim under section 47 in the near future and, having done so, make personal representations! On behalf of the National Party, as I said when I began this valedictory, I wish all senators who are retiring all the best. The Senate is a great place. Few other people know how this place operates. We do form friendships and they breach all political lines. That is how it should be. We do appreciate each other's qualities. I hope that all the senators involved have a wonderful time in their retirement.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —As President of the Senate I join with those who have spoken in conveying my best wishes to our colleagues, Senators Primmer, Scott, Lajovic, Hearn and Jack Evans, who are retiring, and thank them for their services to the Parliament, to the Senate and to Australia. Senator Primmer and his wife, Lorna, have been friends of mine for many years, long before Senator Primmer himself entered Parliament in 1971. He has been a loyal, conscientious and dedicated member of the Australian Labor Party. I know he is highly respected on both sides of the House, and I wish him well.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senators Scott and Lajovic are senators of different political persuasion from me, but with me have represented the State of New South Wales in this Parliament for a number of years-Senator Scott first in 1970 for a short time, and then from 1974 onwards, and Senator Lajovic since 1975. They have both been dedicated servants to the Senate and to the State they represent and in the time we have known each other I think it fair to say we have formed a warm friendship.

Senator Hearn came to us from Tasmania in 1980 as a result of the retirement from the Senate of the then leader of the Labor Party in the Senate, the Hon. Ken Wreidt. In her brief time here she certainly has played an important and sincere part in the affairs of the Parliament.

Senator Jack Evans is the only member of the Australian Democrats who is retiring. Senator Evans was elected in 1983. He has been most active in the debates that have taken place in this chamber and I am sure his services to the Parliament will be missed.

So it is that two Labor stalwarts are leaving us; the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate is retiring; Senator Lajovic of the Liberal Party makes his exit; and, for the time being at least, so does Senator Jack Evans of the Australian Democrats. All the political parties represented in the Senate are losing great personalities and great talent as a result of the retirements taking place here today. I personally have enjoyed the company of all our retiring colleagues. My life has been made richer for having known each of them. I wish each of them and their respective spouses long, healthy and enjoyable retirement. I trust that periodically they will be returning to Canberra to renew friendships and acquaintances.

I also want to say that I understand that during the forthcoming parliamentary recess the Clerk of the House of Representatives, Mr Doug Blake, who has worked in the Parliament for 35 years, will be tendering his resignation. I am sure that all honourable senators join me in thanking him for his lengthy service to the Parliament and wish him and his wife well in their retirement.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 4.44 p.m., until 2 p.m. on 20 August 1985, unless previously called together in accordance with the resolution passed earlier this day.
