The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Australia linked itself closely with the Western Group to the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva; if so, has this prevented Australia from supporting the Working Group established to discuss a nuclear test ban and, specifically, prevented it from discussing a moratorium on nuclear testing and proposals for a treaty to ban underground nuclear tests.
(2) Has Australia adopted this position in order to align itself with the United States, which does not want to stop nuclear tests in order to promote its laser weapons program for outer space.

(3) Is there any reason why the Australian Government cannot support a nuclear test ban whilst working on a water-tight system for the verification of nuclear tests, as surely a moratorium on tests above 3 kilotons will allow for instruments to be placed in appropriate territories so that tests under 3 kilotons could also be monitored.
(4) What are the objections concerning a complete moratorium on nuclear tests.

(5) Has Australia, as part of the Western Group, with regard to the Working Group established to examine the arms race in outer space, prevented discussion on any draft treaties or other substantive proposals; if so, is not this stand inconsistent with the stand Australia and other Western nations adopted (with the exception of the United States of America and Great Britain) in supporting UN Resolution 38/70, which specifically requested the Conference on Disarmament to negotiate a treaty for the prevention of an arms race in outer space.

(6) Will Australia immediately call for a halt to all weapons tests in outer space and request prompt negotiations to identify more precisely what is to be forbidden, pending the conclusion of appropriate treaties.

(7) Is Australia not supporting the establishment of a Working Group to deal with the issue of a nuclear weapons freeze under the Agenda heading of 'Cessation of the Nuclear Arms Race and . . . Prevention of Nuclear War'; if so, why.

(8) Is it still feasible, given the possible difficulties in verifying a total nuclear weapons freeze, to limit the testing and deployment of a number of ballistic missiles, on the United States side to the Minutemen II and III, the M-X Poseidon, Trident I and II and Pershing II missiles and on the Soviet side to the SS-13, 17-21, 23, SSN-6, 8, 17, 18, SSX-24, SSNX-20 and 21; if so, will the Australian Government immediately call for a one year freeze on the testing and deployment of these weapons, pending negotiations for arms cuts.

(9) Will the Australian Government as an immediate contribution to a nuclear weapons freeze stipulate that no quantitative additions be made to the joint United States-Australian military bases at Pine Gap, North-West Cape and Narrungar for a specified time.

(10) Will the Australian Government ensure that these matters are taken up with the Australian Ambassador for Disarmament, Mr Butler, and other officials in Australia's delegation to the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva and that the Australian delegation will openly declare these proposals at the Conference on Disarmament and seek to have them established as the basis of a clearly identifiable Australian position.
(11) Why did the Minister for Foreign Affairs not supply answers to questions (1) to (10) above in 1984, since notice of them was given in Question No. 1152 on 13 September 1984.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia is a member of the Western Group in the Conference on Disarmament (CD) in Geneva.

This has not prevented Australia from expressing its strong support for the conclusion of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty at the earliest possible date. Moreover, participation in the Western Group has enabled Australia to exert influence in an attempt to resolve a procedural dispute which has been holding up work in the Conference on the nuclear test ban issue.

This procedural impasse arose from the decision by the Socialist Group (i.e. Warsaw Pact) and the Neutral and Nonaligned Group to oppose the re-establishment of a subsidiary body of the Conference in the 1984 session to address the nuclear test ban issue unless a new mandate for the subsidiary body were agreed. (Subsidiary bodies of the Conference are now called ad hoc committees not working groups). These two Groups each proposed draft mandates which differed in some particulars but both called for the ad hoc committee to initiate negotiations on a nuclear test ban treaty. Both these proposals were, however, not acceptable to some other member countries of the CD, including the United States, who regard such negotiations as premature.

Australia, therefore, proposed a compromise mandate calling on the CD to undertake substantive work on the scope and compliance and verification aspects of a comprehensive nuclear test ban 'with a view to the negotiation of a treaty'. The Western Group, including the United States, agreed to this proposal. Although this Australian initiative was supported by many of the Neutral and Nonaligned members of the Conference as well it did not prove acceptable to all members of the Conference.

As I said in the Conference in Geneva on 7 August, 1984, Australia would have preferred a mandate calling for immediate negotiations but since there is no consensus for such a mandate, it proposed instead a mandate that would, if accepted, have enabled the Conference to address the technical issues which need to be resolved before a Comprehensive Test Ban could be concluded. The delegations which withheld their agreement to this proposal achieved the result that no work on the nuclear test ban was undertaken by the Conference in 1984.

This procedural deadlock has regrettably persisted to date in 1985 despite Australia's continuing efforts to resolve it and the support which those efforts have received from Western and Neutral and Nonaligned delegations. China has said that it will join in the work of the ad hoc committee if Australia's proposal is agreed by the Conference.

(2) The motivation of Australia in this activity has been to try to bring about the conclusion of a Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty because that is Government policy and because it accords with the obligations of all parties to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty to negotiate in good faith towards nuclear disarmament.

As indicated above, the United States agreed to the Australian-proposed mandate to have the CD undertake substantive work with a view to the negotiation of a Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. One might say the United States aligned itself with Australia. The Government does not believe that Australia's objective of achieving the conclusion of a treaty would have been better served by aligning Australia with the Soviet Union and other countries which, by insisting on an 'all or nothing' approach, prevented the CD from undertaking any work on the nuclear test ban issue in 1984.

(3) The Government's objective is a ban on all nuclear tests, not just those over a certain size. The question rightly alludes to the problems of verification, particularly of explosions below a certain size. (There are problems of measurement at distance of underground explosions much larger than the 3 kiloton TNT equivalent figure mentioned in the question). It is precisely to seek internationally agreed answers to questions of this type that Australia has proposed that the CD should undertake detailed practical work on the verification and implementation requirements of a Comprehensive Test Ban. I tabled in Geneva a set of principles to guide the CD's work on this subject.

It is also with a view to resolving such questions on an internationally agreed basis that Australia has proposed that the CD should proceed forthwith, without waiting for conclusion of the test ban treaty, to establish a fully operational global seismic network, possibly supplemented with atmospheric fallout samplers and other technologies. The Government has also provided funds for the expansion of Australia's own seismic detection capabilities so as to strengthen our ability to contribute to such a global network in support of a Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty.

(4) The main objection to a moratorium (i.e. a voluntary suspension of nuclear tests) is that no reliance could be placed on it. The moratorium on nuclear testing observed by the United States, United Kingdom and Soviet Union from 1958 ended in 1961, when the Soviet Union resumed testing. Australia advocates, instead of a moratorium, a legally binding treaty with effective measures for verification and compliance. There are no proposals before the CD for a moratorium on nuclear tests.

The objection voiced by the Soviet Union, India, Argentina and other countries to a complete ban on nuclear tests is that it would not allow so-called 'peaceful nuclear explosions'. Australia, for its part, supports a complete or comprehensive ban on all testing including so-called 'peaceful nuclear explosions'. This issue is known as the 'scope' of the treaty and is one of the issues that the Australian-inspired mandate would have had the CD address.
(5) No. There was no ad hoc committee on the prevention of an arms race in outer space established during the 1984 session of the Conference on Disarmament.

Again the reason was a procedural dispute centring on the extent to which the mandate would call for immediate negotiations. Australia co-operated with members of the Western and Neutral and Nonaligned Groups seeking a solution that would have enabled the CD to undertake useful preliminary work for treaty negotiations by identifying the issues to be covered in such negotiations. Australia's position was that whereas it could have agreed to a different mandate, it also agreed that the logical and methodical way to proceed to address the novel question of arms control in outer space was to begin by identification of the issues. (Part 6 of the question alludes to the need for such work.) I suggested to the Conference as one of the issues for consideration in this context the possibility of measures to protect from attack all satellites (early warning, communications and the like) which contribute to the preservation of strategic stability and can be instrumental in monitoring disarmament agreements. I also suggested that the same protection be extended to the ground stations which are essential to the operation of these satellites. As in the case of the nuclear test ban issue, the efforts of Australia and other countries from the Western and Neutral and Non-aligned Groups to achieve a compromise which would have enabled the CD to perform useful work on outer space arms control were unsuccessful in 1984.

While it was deeply dissatisfied with this outcome, the Government does not believe that its objective of bringing about agreements to prevent the extension of the arms race to outer space would have been better served by the Australian delegation aligning itself with delegations which took an 'all or nothing' stance and consequently prevented the CD from agreeing to undertake any work at all on outer space arms control in 1984.
The Government believes that the Australian delegation's activities were fully in accordance with Australia's support for resolution 38/70 at the 1983 United Nations General Assembly.

In particular the mandate which Australia supported and which would have allowed the ad hoc committee to begin work by identifying the issues for subsequent negotiation, reflected the approach successfully adopted a few years ago on the subject of chemical weapons. In that case it enabled the CD to undertake much useful work towards a Convention to ban chemical weapons, to the point where a draft treaty on this subject was recently tabled by the United States. In fact, the Chemical Weapons Ad Hoc Committee was the only organ of the CD to undertake constructive activity in 1984. The Australian Delegation participated prominently in this work.

This year, following further negotiations in which Australia participated actively, the Conference on Disarmament agreed in March 1985 to establish an ad hoc committee on outer space with a mandate virtually identical to that supported by Australia in 1984.

(6) Unfortunately the CD never got to the point in 1984 of considering ancillary interim measures to facilitate negotiations of treaties on arms control in outer space. Whether a moratorium on testing would in fact serve this purpose is a moot point. Such a moratorium has been proposed by the Soviet Union but is unattractive to the United States since the Soviet Union already has an operational anti-satellite weapon system which it has tested in space some 20 times, whereas the United States has only began to test the system it is developing.

As indicated above, in 1984, Australia supported unsuccessful efforts to have the CD identify more precisely what should be forbidden in future treaties to prevent an arms race in outer space. Hopefully the CD will now undertake this work.

(7) This question in fact relates to two separate items of the agenda of the Conference. Australia has not participated in the inconclusive debate over the establishment of an ad hoc committee to deal with the agenda item 'Cessation of the Nuclear Arms Race and Nuclear Disarmament'. The establishment of such a committee was opposed by the Western nuclear weapon states. They argued that only the nuclear weapon states themselves can actually negotiate a reduction of their own nuclear arsenals and that the INF/START processes are the most appropriate means of doing so. The Soviet Union advocated a nuclear disarmament subsidiary body in the CD but it also seems highly unlikely to allow the CD to negotiate away its nuclear arsenal. Part of the Warsaw Pact's proposal for the ad hoc committee was that it should draft a nuclear disarmament program. This would have been duplicative of the work already carried out by the CD on a Comprehensive Program of Disarmament, which is to include a balance of nuclear and conventional disarmament measures. Australia has frequently expressed its support for the resumption, continuation and successful conclusion of the bilateral nuclear disarmament negotiations.

Australia has supported the establishment of an ad hoc committee on the agenda item 'Prevention of Nuclear War, Including all Related Matters'. This would discuss nuclear-related matters and Australia has been active in trying to promote agreement to this end.
In the event no agreement was reached to establish ad hoc committees on either of these agenda items in 1984.

(8) The question of limitations on the deployment and testing of ballistic missiles is a matter that has been under negotiation between the superpowers intermittently since 1969; some agreements have been reached between them (the SALT accords) but negotiations were suspended throughout 1984. Australia took the view that the immediate priority was a resumption of superpower negotiations on these issues and that this objective was not assisted by proposals for new approaches which do not address the problems which have been encountered in this context to date. The superpower negotiations were resumed in early 1985 and the Government strongly supports their objective of securing deep reductions in nuclear weapons and the avoidance of an arms race in space.

I very much doubt that it would prove feasible to secure the agreement of the superpowers, either to limit the testing and deployment of ballistic missiles to the models listed in the question or to suspend the testing and deployment of these missiles for a year. One example of the reasons why neither proposal seems likely to commend itself to the two superpowers is that last year's suspension in their negotiations on these subjects arose from their inability to agree on limitations to 'intermediate range nuclear forces' (INF), which include, among other weapons systems, the Soviet SS20 and the United States Pershing II missiles mentioned in the list. The first proposal would impose no restraint on further deployments of these missiles, the second would be seen by the NATO countries as conferring an advantage on the Soviet Union. This is because the Soviet Union would retain the SS20s which it deployed when NATO had no modern INF missiles but NATO would be prevented from deploying the missiles it has planned to counter the SS20 deployment, in the absence of agreement for their removal. Moreover, current complaints by the United States about Soviet implementation of restrictions under the SALT II agreement on the testing of new ballistic missiles illustrate the difficulties of verifying compliance with agreements to restrict testing of ballistic missiles to specified models.

As Australia sees it, there is another more pressing issue to be agreed between the superpowers. This is the limitation on their strategic arsenals which they will observe after the end of 1985 when the SALT II arrangements are due to expire.

(9) No. As the Government has made clear, these facilities contribute to the avoidance of nuclear war and to the verification of arms control agreements. It would not assist those objectives to prevent additions and improvements to the facilities. No variations to these facilities can take place without the Australian Government's knowledge and consent.

(10) As it is evident from the annual reports of the Australian Delegation to the Conference on Disarmament and other widely distributed public material, that Delegation, headed by the Ambassador for Disarmament, and other Australian officials engaged in disarmament work are fully briefed on all the matters addressed in this question and on the other matters on the international disarmament agenda. I would also draw attention to my own statements in the Conference on Disarmament on 7 August 1984 and to the United Nations General Assembly on 4 October 1983 and 2 October 1984. Contrary to the implication in the question, Australia's strong support for a comprehensive nuclear test ban, for agreements to avoid the extension of the arms race to outer space and for effective measures to halt and reverse the nuclear arms race has been declared on many occasions and Australia's position on these issues is clearly identified. As the public record further indicates we have gone beyond a mere declaratory position to the much more difficult and thankless task of seeking to achieve practical results, especially in support of a comprehensive nuclear test ban and a comprehensive convention against chemical weapons.

I expressed the Australian view of the disputes in the Conference on Disarmament about ad hoc committees and their mandates in my speech to the United Nations General Assembly on 2 October 1984 when I spoke of 'a shameful procedural deadlock holding up the agenda of negotiations'. On 7 August I had expressed directly to the Conference itself Australia's deep dissatisfaction at this stage of affairs. The efforts of the Government and the Australian delegation in Geneva will continue to be directed at seeking to have the Conference on Disarmament undertake the negotiating tasks for which it was established, and to seek the conclusion of effective and verifiable agreements, notably on the Comprehensive Test Ban, a Chemical Weapons Convention and Outer Space.
(11) A reply was prepared for Question No. 1152 in October but it was regrettably mislaid in the run-up to the elections in December last year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 22 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government aware of the allegations of police involvement in organised crime and, in particular, child pornography, in Queensland.
(2) Does the Government have any information on these sorts of activities by police in Queensland.

(3) Would it not be more appropriate to refer this matter to the National Crime Authority so that its resources and expertise would be available, in spite of the Queensland Government's stated intention to investigate this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I am aware of Press reports of the allegations.

(2) No. The Australian Federal Police only has jurisdiction to investigate criminal activity where breaches of Commonwealth legislation are involved. In the present context, pornography, in particular, would be a matter subject to Queensland legislation.

(3) The NCA may investigate a matter which involves relevant criminal activity as defined in the National Crime Authority Act. Under the Act, a reference enabling the Authority to use its coercive powers may arise in one of two ways-the Authority can seek a reference from a Government (via the Inter-Governmental Committee as appropriate) or a Government, (with the approval of the IGC as appropriate), could directly refer the matter to the NCA. It must be remembered that the National Crime Authority was not established to deal with all allegations which might arise in the public arena. It was primarily established to deal with those investigations which are beyond ordinary police powers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance upon notice, on 27 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Department of Finance tell the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development Examiners, visiting Australia to study science and technology matters, that:
Technology, and the Research and Development necessary to generate and apply technology, should in our view, be regarded as simply another input into the production process of goods and services.
(2) If so, did the OECD Examiners specifically criticise and reject this view, expressing 'considerable trouble' at accepting it as valid; and
(3) If so, does the Minister for Finance see any need for this view to be now discarded by the Department of Finance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's questions is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) The Department is often invited to express views on matters which impinge on its responsibilities and has made numerous submissions to various inquiries of interest to the Government, including the OECD Examiners Report on Australian Science and Technology Policy. In pursuing their inquiries and preparing reports, it is desirable for members of policy review committees to have the benefit of broadly based advice and opinions, including those with which they may choose to disagree. I have no intention of directing my Department as to the views it will put to OECD examiners on this or any other subject.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 19 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: In what circumstances can the widow's pension be paid to a husband who is forced to renounce work to look after his family following the death of his wife.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: A male sole parent is not eligible for widow's pension. However, subject to the same income or assets test as the widow's pension and to prescribed residence conditions, a male sole parent may be paid a supporting parent's benefit. The rate of supporting parent's benefit payable is the same as the rate of widow's pension.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 20 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What approaches have been made by the Queensland Minister for Racing, Mr Hinze, the Queensland Government, the Queensland Police Force or the Queensland Turf Club to either the National Crime Authority or the Australian Federal Police for assistance in either the present caffeine doping scandal or the earlier Fine Cotton fiasco.

(2) Will the Special Minister of State issue an immediate assurance to the Queensland Government that the facilities of the Federal Government and its instrumentalities are available to help investigations should Queensland wish to stamp out racing malpractices threatening Queensland racing and an important national industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that the only approach made to the Australian Federal Police has been a request from the Queensland Police for assistance in regard to the Fine Cotton inquiry. I am not prepared to indicate the exact nature of that assistance as this could prejudice police investigations.
I am informed by the National Crime Authority that it has adopted the general practice of neither confirming nor denying that approaches have been made to it on particular matters.

(2) Racing malpractices in Queensland fall within the jurisdiction of the Queensland State Government. If the Queensland Government should find any matters which involve a breach of Commonwealth law, no doubt it will take the relevant steps to involve the appropriate Commonwealth authorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 28 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian Government sent a formal protest to the Government of South Africa regarding the killing of at least 19 black South Africans on 21 March 1985 when police opened fire on a funeral procession in Cape Province.
(2) Does Australia intend to raise the matter or support any other nation that does so in the United Nations.

(3) Will Australia re-affirm, in the strongest terms, its total opposition to sporting contact with South Africa until the repulsive apartheid policy is totally abandoned, and the slaughter of blacks ceases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government's very strong opposition to apartheid has been placed firmly on public record. Most recently the Government, in response to tragic violence in South Africa, made a strong statement on South Africa to the United Nations Security Council on 8 March 1985. Mr Hayden made a statement in Parliament on the deplorable killings in Uitenhage on 21 March, the day of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Sharpeville Massacre. The Government sees no other purpose being served by making a purely formal diplomatic protest. The South African Government is kept well aware of the Australian Government's views and concerns on apartheid through our Embassy in Cape Town and the South African Embassy in Canberra.

(2) Yes. Australia supported the provisions of Security Council Resolution 560 adopted on 12 March 1985 which condemned South Africa's policy of apartheid and endorsed the Security Council President's statement on 22 March expressing grave concern over the rapid deterioration of the situation in South Africa.

(3) On 26 October 1983 the Government announced its decision to strengthen its policy on sporting contacts with South Africa following a general Cabinet review of Australia's relations with South Africa. This policy, which aims to discourage sporting contacts with South Africa, is in line with the Government's total rejection of apartheid and with its objective to persuade the South African Government to dismantle the apartheid system. This policy is also consistent with both the United Nations General Assembly Resolution 31/6 of November 1976 and the 1977 Gleneagles Declaration on apartheid in sport.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State the following question, upon notice, on 16 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the investigation concerning Mr Christo Moll and his associates and various figures in Australian public life, will the Special Minister of State provide up-to-date information on the state of the investigations by the Australian Federal Police into Mr Christo Moll's tax avoidance activities, said to have resulted in revenue losses exceeding $200m.

(2) Has the Special Minister of State received requests for indemnity for Mr Christo Moll, either from Mr Moll himself or from the Australian Federal Police, to obtain detailed information on Mr Moll's activities and associates with a view to successful prosecution of offences committed; if so, what decisions have been made with respect to such requests, what are the reasons for the decisions and have further investigations provided the Minister with any grounds to review his decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am not prepared to reveal details of the continuing Australian Federal Police AFP investigations into the affairs of Mr Christo Moll as this might prejudice the outcome of such investigations.

(2) I am advised by the AFP that Mr Moll did raise with them the possiblity of his being granted an indemnity. He was told how to make a formal request but as far as the AFP are aware, he has not made such a formal request nor has any been made on his behalf.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 18 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Did Qantas recently decide to reject designs for new uniforms which had been commissioned by it from Sydney designer Mr Trent Nathan; if so:
(a) why was it considered necessary to reject the designs;
(b) if the designs were considered to be unsuitable, why was no further attempt made to secure the services of another Australian designer;

(c) why did Qantas management in February 1985 'deem it appropriate to start to assess international designer interest' one month before Mr Nathan made his final presentation to Qantas' Wardrobe Selection Panel on 13 March 1985; and
(d) why did Qantas management find it necessary to 'quickly commission' an international designer to develop the new Qantas wardrobe after rejecting Mr Nathan's designs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: As this matter is one which falls within the operational responsibility of Qantas management, advice was sought from the Company, which has provided the following information.

(a) Over 15 months ago Qantas commenced a program for the development and manufacture in Australia of a new wardrobe for its cabin crew, sales and airport personnel. The main costs and work involved is in the manufacture of the garments and a firm decision was taken that the manufacture would be carried out in Australia. From the 43 Australian organisations which responded to Qantas' invitation to design this wardrobe, a short list of eight finalists was selected by a fashion consultant panel.

In August 1984 a distinguished panel of six fashion and design experts viewed presentations from these eight Australian designers. The panel recommended to Qantas that none of the eight submissions were acceptable but if the Company still desired an Australian design, then one of the eight finalists, Trent Nathan, could be given a second opportunity to develop a totally new concept.

(b) As the Company was most anxious to commission an Australian designer, one finalist was given a further six months for this task. On 13th March 1985 he made his final presentation to three Australian members of the panel. It was the unanimous conclusion of these judges that Mr Nathan's further attempt did not meet the overall standard of design excellence that was needed.

The present Qantas female cabin attendant's uniform was developed by a leading international designer some 12 years ago and put Qantas into the forefront with a uniform of design excellence that has also stood the test of time. It has been a great disappointment to the Company that it has not been able to find an Australian designer, after some 15 months of searching, who could create a wardrobe concept anywhere near the standard achieved with the present design. Furthermore, the Company's new corporate identity program, of which the new wardrobe was an integral part, had already commenced, and the staff associations involved had been promised the introduction of new uniforms commencing in December 1985.

(c) In February 1985 the Australian judging panel expressed their concern at the apparent lack of progress being made by Mr Nathan during the six months since granting his second opportunity. Consequently the Company considered it prudent to assess without commitment whether there was any interest on the part of top international designers to design for Australian manufacture.

(d) The unanimous recommendation of the judges following Mr Nathan's final presentation on 13th March was that his design concept fell far short of the Company's objectives. The recommendation to reject Mr Nathan's designs was unanimously supported at the time by the Staff Advisory Panel, which had been actively involved in this project for over 12 months.
This panel consisted of representatives nominated by the Cabin Crew Associations, Federated Clerks Union and the Australian Transport Officers Association.
Qantas management accordingly recommended to the Board that an international designer be commissioned to develop the new Company wardrobe.

The Company has not yet commissioned any designer and is currently in discussion with the various staff unions and the Fashion Industry Council of Australia. Regardless of selection of designer the garments will be made in Australia as is the present, and past, practice. On this occasion, the manufacturer will provide over $1m to that portion of Australia's fashion industry which manufactures in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 18 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why does Qantas use a Paris-based consultant, Eric Giordan, for inflight and marketing advice instead of an Australian company.

(2) What remunerations or other rewards were paid by Qantas to the seven person panel which recently rejected commissioned designs for new staff uniforms prepared by Sydney designer Mr Trent Nathan; how many members of the Panel have associations with overseas companies; and how many members of the Panel have connections with Vogue magazine.
(3) Is Vogue Australia employed by Qantas as a professional consultant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Qantas has advised in relation to the particular question:

(1) Qantas because of its worldwide operations uses a number of consultants to advise on a wide range of topics. For example, a panel of distinguished Australian authorities on wine advises the Company on the selection of Australian wines to be served on Qantas aircraft throughout the world. Mr Eric Giordan's role is to advise the Company on the selection of some European items for inclusion in the Inflight Shop for on-board sales.

(2) The remuneration paid to the judging panel is a matter of confidentiality between the Company and the persons concerned. In accordance with Company policy the members of the wardrobe selection panel at the time of appointment provided the Company with a declaration stating:

'I understand your Company's desire that the members of the panel retained to judge the submissions of the designers should be, and be seen to be, unbiased and objective and consequently to this end, I confirm that I have no financial, or other interest either direct or indirect in any of those designers' business'. Two of the judging panel are employees of Bernard Leser Publications Pty. Ltd., the publishers of Vogue Australia magazine.
(3) Vogue Australia as an independent expert was consulted in relation to the new wardrobe. Vogue Australia has also provided advice to the Company on minor inflight items.
