QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 8 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the effective rate of protection for colour television sets for the period 26 October 1984 to 25 October 1985.
(2) What will be the effective rate of protection for colour television sets under the long-term duty rate of 20 per cent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The effective rate of protection for the local manufacture of colour television sets for the period requested is indeterminable. As a result of the Government's recent decision on assistance for colour television sets the industry is experiencing a period of adjustment including increases in import competition and changes to the levels of value added. These ongoing changes preclude a meaningful estimate of the effective rate of protection for the period requested.

(2) The effective rate of protection for colour television sets under the long term duty rate of 20 per cent is of course a matter for prediction. As a result of the Government's recent decision on assistance for colour television sets we expect the effective rate of protection to be similar to the average accorded manufacturing industry. This prediction is based on estimates by the Industries Assistance Commission and an expected increase in value added by some local manufacturers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 7 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the salaries and allowances paid to: (a) the Chairman; (b) the Deputy Chairman; and (c) the other members of the Australian Film Commission.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Remuneration Tribunal has determined the annual fees for the Chairman and Members of the Australian Film Commission to be:
These amounts include an adjustment for the national wage case decision of 3 April 1985.
A travelling allowance of $100 per overnight stay in a capital city and $80 in other than a capital city has also been determined for the holders of these offices.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 8 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment aware that the European Economic Community's Sixth Value Added Tax Directive (Article 13A (1) (n)) exempts the following services from VAT: 'certain cultural services and goods closely linked to theatres supplied by bodies governed by public law or by other cultural bodies governed by the member states concerned', if so, in seeking to apply a broadly-based consumer tax, will the Government be providing for similar exemptions for the arts and artists in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No decision on introduction of a broadly-based consumption tax in Australia has yet been made, nor will a decision be made prior to the Tax Summit in July.
It would be premature of me to express a view on the nature and extent of any exemption which might or should apply on introduction of a broadly-based consumption tax.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 10 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has low priority been given to policing of illicit stills in Australia and to excise lost in respect of them.
(2) Has a departmental paper, prepared by a Mr Curran, estimated that revenue so lost was a minimum of $3m per annum.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The illicit distillation of alcohol may occur commercially in large quantities or non-commercially in backyard stills which usually provide small quantities of low grade alcohol for limited distribution or personal use. Because of the revenue potential involved, investigations into the alleged operation of stills suspected of producing commercial quantities are accorded equal priority to investigations into other areas of major commercial fraud or instances where community protection issues are involved.

(2) No. Research of departmental files has located a brief minute prepared in July 1979 at the request of officers from the Auditor-General's Office by Mr Curran, a Sydney based officer. In this minute Mr Curran estimated that the amount of excise loss based on maximum utilisation of the illicit stills seized in New South Wales between 1 January and 19 June 1979 as $39,993.75 per day based on maximum utilisation. Mr Curran has since indicated that he was aware at the time the minute was prepared that the stills referred to would normally be operated on an itinerant or seasonal basis and he had no intention of inferring in the minute a per annum loss of revenue based on the daily figure.

Subsequent to the audit of the Inland Services operations in several States the Auditor General in Efficiency Audit Report No. 4, dated 11 March 1982, made the following comments on illicit (spirit) production.

'Departmental controls over illicit production vary among collectorates. The most successful programs in terms of numbers of prosecutions involve development of an intelligence and information base primarily through the cultivation of informants, the investigation of likely sources having regard to cultural influences and seasonal factors and selective investigation. From the figures available to Audit, controls are not cost effective on the basis of additional duty recovered although data are not available on the deterrent effect of controls. Eight and a half man-years (salary cost over $110,000) were invested in 1977-78 in search of illicit production leading to the recovery of duty of $19,000 representing 1900 litres of spirit. Almost 4000 litres of spirit and over 4000 litres of wash were seized in 1977-78 and 1978-79 (excise revenue of about $50,000) at costs of almost $250,000 for the two years. The Department advised:

There is no data available on the total production of illicit alcohol in Australia. The members of the spirit industry have a vested interest in preventing illicit activity and the lack of information from that source despite constant and direct requests tends to confirm the view that the production of illicit spirit is not significant.

Audit cannot disagree with this view. However, given that the duty liability from the daily production of an average still is about $700 there is sufficient risk for the Department to invest some effort in assessing the size and scope of illicit production based on extrapolating from finds.

Subject to substantial erosion not being evidenced, a deterrent approach based on cultivation of informants and wide publicity for seizures and fines, could be adopted as the most cost-effective approach.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 28 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government recently increased the licence fees for warehouses licensed under the Customs Act from $1,900 to $6,646 (for new licences) and $5,346 (for renewals); if so:
(a) Upon what basis were these increases of approximately 250 per cent and 180 per cent respectively calculated; and
(b) what consultation took place with warehouse licensees prior to the introduction of this new scale of fees.

(2) Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce prepared to make the report of the consultants Price Waterhouse Associates Proprietary (referred to in Explanatory Statement to Statutory Rules No. 71 of 1985 under the Customs Act) available for study by interested parties.

(3) Why, when the scale of fees is set out in Statutory Rules No. 71 of 1985 (Customs Regulations (Amendment)), does Australian Customs Notice 85/107 refer to the Statutory Rules as No. 77; are the Statutory Rules different; if not, is this an error in the Customs Notice.
(4) What appeals, if any, lie against the decision to make such a large increase in fees in one step.
(5) Are the new scale of fees made in such a way that they are capable of disallowance by the Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The increases in fees were based on recommendations contained in a report to the Department by the firm of consultants Price Waterhouse Associates Proprietary. The consultants were engaged to advise the Department on improved procedures for determining and recovering costs relating to warehouses as well as depots.
The terms of reference for the consultant were as follows:
'The purpose of the consultancy is to review the method of determining charges for licence fees and associated Customs services relating to Customs warehouses and depots.
The consultant is required to report on and made recommendations concerning the implementation of an equitable system of charging based on administrative cost recovery principles.'

(b) The research by the consultants was carried out in May and June 1984 and involved interviews with the industry associations which utilise the services provided by section 79 of the Customs Act as well as several visits to actual warehouse premises.

(2) The consultants provided two reports-one which addressed the specific matters relating to the question of appropriate bases for fees for both warehouses and depots. This report would be made available to interested parties on request. The second report addressed operational matters relating to officers and the conduct of the consultancy and because of this would not be made available to interested parties.
(3) The mention of Statutory Rules No. 77 in the Australian Customs Notice No. 85/107 is a typographical error. An amended Australian Customs Notice in course of issue.

(5) All Regulations are required to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after making the regulations pursuant to section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and may be subject to disallowance accordingly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 May 1985 Senator Reid asked a further question without notice regarding the availability of the crime collection unit of the Australian Federal Police in Canberra (Hansard, pages 2028-9).

ANSWER.PARA: The Special Minister of State has provided the following answers to specific matters raised by the honourable senator:
'. . . I am told that in fact the criminal records unit of the AFP was on that day'-11 May 1985-'closed for the first time in 23 years . . .'
I am unable to comment as to whether or not the criminal records unit (CRU) has ever been closed before. It was, in effect, 'closed' for one shift on that day.
'. . . so information was not available and could not be supplied in response to interstate requests.'
While information was available [accessible to the Senior Constable in the adjacent Alerts List Unit (ALU)], neither Operations nor the Senior Constable had been advised or instructed to access it.
'He'-the Alerts List Officer-'had been in the force for only four months and had neither the expertise nor the ability . . .'

This is not correct. He was a Senior Constable with eleven years service. It is acknowledged that he had only been performing duty at the ALU [Information Branch (Crime)] since 29 April, 1985 but searching records at the CRU is a simple task. While his initial induction centred on the role and activities of the ALU, he was 'walked through' other units in the Branch and given an insight into operations and systems there.
'. . . to get into what I am told were the locked sections closed off by a roll-down garage door device covering the crime collation unit and the criminal records unit.'

The sections were locked by a pull-down grille barring access to the 'public', that is, the counter where police call to conduct checks. The grille displayed the word 'Unattended'. The CRU was accessible to the Senior Constable.

The configuration of the office space gives open-door access one to the other. It is acknowledged, however, that if the Senior Constable was in the ALU, and office machinery was operating (for example, teleprinter), he may not have heard the telephone in the CRU, had such telephone been ringing at that moment. Additionally, he had not been directed to attend to CRU inquiries.

'It seems that a telex was received from Victoria requesting information about a certain person and a response was sent.' (Leave granted to have the telex incorporated in Hansard) '. . . (it) refers to the fact that police were unable to advise on priors-that is prior convictions-as its crime collation unit would not be on duty until 2300 hours on 11 May 1985 . . . I would like an assurance that this telex was sent from the AFP last Saturday . . .'
The telex appears to be a copy of a telex message forwarded to Victoria Police from the AFP Operations Room at City Police Station, Canberra on the evening of 11 May 1985.

It is true that neither the CCU nor the CRU were manned for that afternoon shift. One member reported sick, the other was granted 'special leave' due to a family illness. The NCO about to complete his shift reported to a Superintendent (who was then in his office) the fact that only one member (ALU) would be on duty unless other members were called out. The Superintendent directed that there should not be any call-out as he was of the view that the ALU member would be on duty and could handle inquiries for all three units.

This is where the system failed. Through lack of communication, the ALU member was not directed to handle inquiries that may be received in the CRU. Further, the NCO to whom the Superintendent spoke advised the Operations Room that there would be noone on duty in either CRU or CCU. Operations Room was not informed that the member in ALU could handle inquiries relative to the unmanned offices.
The Superintendent in charge of the area is to review the rostering arrangements to ensure a capacity to have all three units effectively operational 24 hours each day.
'. . . overtime has virtually been cut out . . . and there is a ban on overtime.'

There is no ban on overtime. There have been some readjustments of priority in the interests of effective and efficient management but overtime is being worked and paid as commitments demand. In no case have essential operational commitments been reduced.
'. . . the level of policing is not what it ought to be. There are not as many motor vehicle patrols as usual . . .'

There are as many mobile patrols available now as there have been, although during morning shifts some patrols may have only one officer. When emergencies occur, such as the recent demonstration at Parliament House, patrols are redirected to assist, leaving areas such as Woden and Belconnen short of mobile units for the time being. Nevertheless the level of policing is what it ought to be.
'We hear of the drug unit not operating after 4 o'clock in the afternoon . . .'
Rosters of the Australian Capital Territory drug squad indicate that only on two occasions in recent months has that unit not operated with an afternoon shift. Both were Sundays.
'. . . we hear of the scientific squad not being available after 4 p.m. unless a senior officer specifically says that it ought to go . . .'

There has been no restriction on overtime in the scientific units. It is true that some validation by a senior member is required of the need to have a call-out after hours. This procedure was introduced when members in the scientific area claimed that some requests were unnecessary and their time was being wasted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 22 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Peter Fulcher provide the Australian Federal Police or the New South Wales Police with information relating to or leading to any criminal investigations; if so:
(a) did the provision of any such information by Peter Fulcher form the 'extraordinary circumstances' leading to his early release; and
(b) if it did, were any results of the provision of that information sufficient to justify the early release.

(2) If the information obtained from Fulcher was important enough to warrant the early release of Fulcher on 11 June 1985, why did the Attorney-General bring that date forward by 6 months on 6 December 1984.
(3) In view of the fact that New Zealand authorities had warrants for Fulcher's arrest going back before September 1983, why did the Attorney-General:
(a) wait 2 months before answering the letter from New Zealand authorities asking if Fulcher was going to be released;
(b) refuse to deny or confirm Fulcher's early release to the New Zealand authorities; and
(c) not tell the New Zealand authorities that Fulcher had been released until 15 days after the event.
(4) Why were there no conditions on the licence issued to Fulcher.

(5) What is the legal position of a 'proviso' such as that which was apparently attached to Fulcher's Release on Licence; and what is the legal effect of a 'proviso' which states that Mr Fulcher be of good behaviour and not violate any law until 11 December 1988.

(6) Since the Labor Government has been in office, what steps has it taken to organise, simplify and streamline extradition matters between New Zealand and Australia or between Australia and any other country.
(7) Will the Government give an undertaking to reform any existing law in relation to New Zealand-Australian extradition, so that repetitions of this affair will not occur.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) It has been consistent Commonwealth Government practice for a number of years to neither confirm nor deny the matters raised by these questions.

(3) (a) On 31 October 1984 the Department forwarded a reply to the New Zealand Police. An immediate response could not be given to the New Zealand request because of the need for the Department to consult.

(b) The New Zealand Commissioner was expressly told that in cases of this kind it was the Department's practice not to reveal that information to anyone, not even Australian law enforcement agencies, or to prison and parole authorities.
(c) Neither the Attorney-General nor the Department informed the New Zealand authorities of Mr Fulcher's release.

(5) The Legal effect of the 'proviso' which states that Mr Fulcher be of good behaviour and not violate any law until 11 December 1988 is that if he is convicted of any offence before that date his licence may be revoked by His Excellency the Governor-General acting on the Attorney-General's advice. Mr Fulcher, in these circumstances would be liable to serve the balance of his federal term.

(6) So far as extradition between New Zealand and Australia is concerned no amendments of the law are proposed. Extradition arrangements between Australia and New Zealand are applied regularly and are considered effective. The New Zealand Solicitor-General indicated in his report that New Zealand would ensure that in future cases their warrants were recorded well ahead of any possible release. Since the Hawke Government has been in office a draft model treaty has been proposed to form the basis of negotiations with countries to replace 'inherited' treaties and to conclude treaties where hitherto no extradition arrangements existed. An extradition task force has been established to review all Australian extradition arrangements and to improve Australia's extradition coverage. That task force has forwarded the draft model treaty to numerous countries and received favourable responses for treaty negotiations from many of these countries. A negotiating team is travelling to Europe in June to conduct extradition negotiations. Substantial amendments have been made to the Extradition (Foreign States) Act and the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act during this session. Many of these amendments have been designed to simplify and modernise Australian extradition practice.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 19 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Australian Government adjust the prices of Australian petroleum products in line with changes in the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) oil prices; if so, why has the Government failed to reduce the price of petroleum products, given the recent reduction in OPEC oil prices.
(2) Is an oil import pricing policy which takes advantage of increases in crude oil prices, by passing them on to the consumer, yet ignores reductions in crude oil prices, inconsistent.

(3) Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware of the increasing hardship caused to the people of the outback who bear the escalating costs of petroleum products every time they travel, by road or air.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under the import parity pricing system, Australian crude oils are priced at levels equivalent to the cost of importing crude oils of a comparable quality. The Government considers the official price for the Saudi Arabian crude oil, Arab Light, to be the most appropriate international price for import parity pricing purposes. Arab Light is traded in large volumes, is of comparable quality to Australian crudes and would be a major import into Australia if Bass Strait crude was not available. As the official price of Arab Light is specified in United States dollars changes to the $US/$A exchange rate cause changes in the imported cost of Arab Light (in Australian dollars) and hence in the import parity price for Australian crude oils. The 1 March 1985 adjustment to import parity prices incorporated the $US1 per barrel reduction in the official price of Arab Light which occurred on 30 January 1985. However, this $US price reduction was more than offset by the decline in the $US/$A exchange rate over the previous two months-since the previous adjustment to the import parity price. Further declines in the $US/$A exchange rate since 1 March 1985 have caused the further increase in the import parity price which has applied from 1 May 1985.

(2) The Government's import parity pricing policy recognises both increases and reductions in the cost of importing crude oil and I draw the honourable senator's attention to the reductions in the crude oil price made by this Government on 1 April 1983, 1 July 1983 and 1 January 1984.

(3) A reduction in the exchange rate generally results in an increase in the prices of all internationally traded commodities. The Government recognises that its recent decision to increase the import parity price for crude oil will increase transport costs. It is not considered appropriate that particular sections of the community should be shielded from the effects of the currency depreciation which has caused these price increases-similarly it would not be appropriate to prevent the benefits of the depreciation from flowing through to the export and import competing industries. It is worth noting in this context that an improved outlook for exports will be of benefit to many people in the outback since many of their activities are linked to export industries and that, to some extent, this will offset the costs of higher petroleum prices.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 19 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware that 1002 electricity linesmen and associated workers employed by the South East Queensland Electricity Board have been sacked by the Queensland Government, and that these men were only offered back their jobs if they agreed to new conditions of employment that involved:
(a) signing an agreement containing a 'no strike' clause; and
(b) agreeing to work a 38-hour week instead of the 36.25-hour week that was in place before the strike and subsequent sackings.

(2) Is the Electricity (Continuity of Supply) Bill passed by the Queensland Parliament on 2 March 1985 in breach of any conventions of the International Labour Organisation that have been ratified by Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is very conscious of the current situation in the Queensland power industry including the plight of the dismissed South East Queensland Electricity Board (SEQEB) workers and the legislative action taken by the Queensland Government in the last few weeks.

The actions of the Queensland Government are contrary to the principles of sound industrial relations and have severely eroded the basic rights of workers to organise and pursue their legitimate goals through appropriate industrial tribunals.

It is also a matter of record that the Queensland Government has twice rejected recommendations of the Queensland Industrial Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which would have averted the disruption to the State's industry which occurred in February.

The Federal Government has intervened in proceedings before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to support federal award coverage for power industry workers in Queensland and has introduced legislation into Federal Parliament to facilitate these proceedings and allow all the matters involved in this dispute to be discussed in an independent industrial forum.

(2) The Government's legal advisers have examined the Electricity (Continuity of Supply) Act 1985, as well as other recent Queensland industrial legislation and have identified a number of breaches of international treaties, including International Labour Organisation (''ILO''), Conventions, to which Australia is a party.

There may be other breaches disclosed after further examination. Moreover, even where the existence of Queensland legislation itself is not a breach, the exercise of powers or the taking of other action under the legislation would need to be examined to consider whether it constituted a breach of any of Australia's international obligations.
The breaches which have been identified so far are as follows:
Abolition of Forced Labour Convention, 1957 (ILO Convention No. 105)
International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights

* Under section 3 of the Electricity (Continuity of Supply) Act 1985, the Electricity Commissioner is given an extremely wide power to direct any person who he considers capable of carrying out the necessary work, to perform work to provide, maintain or restore a supply of electricity.

* Under section 4 of the same Act, employees of the Queensland Electricity Commission or of an Electricity Board are liable to a penalty for non-compliance with such a direction. While it appears that no penalty attaches to non-compliance by other persons, they may understandably feel under the menace of a penalty, at least until there is a judicial determination on the matter.

* These provisions are too wide to be permissible under ILO Convention No. 29 which requires the suppression of the use of forced or compulsory labour. Although some exceptions are permitted under the Convention, the legislation is not confined to the circumstances covered by the permissible exception.

* The power to direct may be exercised, even when no real emergency exists, to require non-employees to perform work or to require employees to perform work outside the normal scope of their employment.

* To the extent that the legislation does enable the power to be exercised in these ways, it authorises 'forced or compulsory labour' contrary to ILO Convention No. 29 and the existence of the legislation constitutes a breach of that Convention.

* Moreover, the power is wide enough to authorise forced or compulsory labour of kinds specified in ILO Convention No. 105. Among other things, the Convention prohibits the use of forced or compulsory labour as a means of labour discipline or as a punishment for having participated in strikes. To that extent, the existence of the legislation is in breach of that Convention.

* Article 8.3 of the International Convenant on Civil and Political Rights also proscribes forced or compulsory labour. Although provision is made in Article 8.3 for certain exceptions, the power of direction mentioned above is not limited to circumstances falling within those exceptions. To the extent that the legislation exceeds the scope permissible under Article 8.3, its existence constitutes a breach of that provision.
Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise Convention, 1948 (ILO Convention No. 87)
International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights

* Under section 7 of the Electricity (Continuity of Supply) Act 1985, there is effectively a prohibition on strike activity in the electricity industry. In addition, the Electricity Authorities Industrial Causes Act 1985 makes participation in a relevant strike an 'illegal' act and imposes a duty to refrain from participating in certain strikes. Employees participating in a 'strike' (as defined) in the electricity industry are subject to an automatic loss of pay, and, at the employer's option, to dismissal or suspension without pay.

* ILO Convention No. 87 guarantees the right of workers to further and defend their occupational interests. The Freedom of Association Committee of the Governing body of the ILO ('the Committee') has said on a number of occasions that the right to strike is a legitimate means of exercising this right.

* The Committee has also recognised that the right to strike may be restricted or prohibited in the civil service or in essential services because a strike there could cause serious hardship to the community. However, the Committee has stated that where there is such a restriction it should be accompanied by adequate, impartial and speedy conciliation and arbitration procedures in which the parties can participate at every stage and in which awards are binding in all cases on both parties. These awards, once made, should be fully and promptly implemented.

* It may be that the Electricity Authorities Industrial Causes Tribunal established by the Electricity Authorities Industrial Causes Act 1985 is able to employ such conciliation and arbitration procedures in relation to the matters coming within its jurisdiction. However, that tribunal has no jurisdiction to relieve employees of the sanctions referred to above. Moreover, there is no court or other body independent of the employer, the Minister or the Electricity Commissioner, as the case may be, who can determine whether an employee on whom sanctions have been imposed has, in fact, participated in a relevant strike [see sub-sections 28 (4) and 29 (4) of the Electricity Authorities Industrial Causes Act 1985 which oust the jurisdiction of the courts].

* These elements of the State legislation do not comply with the rights protected under the provisions of ILO Convention No. 87. Furthermore, the lack of provision for resort to a court or other independent body in relation to the imposition of sanctions conflicts with Article 7 of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights which requires the provision of 'just and favourable conditions of work'.

* Another breach of ILO Convention No. 87 occurs by virtue of the new provisions enacted in the Industrial Conciliation and Arbitration Act Amendment Act 1985 relating to the cancellation and suspension of the registration of a union. There is insufficient scope for consideration by an independent tribunal of the substance of a case against a union in relation to the grounds for cancellation or suspension.
Right to Organise and Collective Bargaining Convention, 1949 (ILO Convention No. 98)

* The existence of sections 3 and 4 of the Electricity (Continuity of Supply) Act 1985, which respectively confer powers that extend to the giving of directions to union members as such, and impose penalties for non-compliance, constitutes a breach of this ILO Convention.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 20 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Under which Act of Parliament and/or regulations are persons (including members of the legal profession) subjected to a scan-search upon entry into the premises of the Family Court of Australia.
(2) Under which Act and/or regulations are the baggage, briefcases or handbags of such persons opened and searched.
(3) Under which Act and/or regulations are civilian personnel employed by a private company (i.e. Thomas Nationwide Transport (TNT)) empowered to conduct such searches.
(4) What fees are paid to TNT for such services, and under which appropriation are such payments authorised by the Parliament.

(5) What guidelines are issued to TNT or other persons conducting such searches, under which Act and/or regulations have such guidelines been issued and how and when have such guidelines been made public.

(6) Which Government department or agency is supplied with the written notes taken by such security personnel, and: (a) what are the purposes of keeping such written records; (b) are such records available for inspection under the Freedom of Information Act; and (c) for how long are such records kept on file.

(7) Why have legal practitioners and others who require regular admission and access to the Family Courts not been issued with permanent security passes which would allow them entry without the necessity to submit to a search or scan on each occasion of their entry to the Family Courts.
(8) Which other Courts enforce such procedures upon people entering them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2), (3) There is no express Statutory Authority for the security measures which have been put in place on premises of the Family Court. The Authority for the action taken derives from the rights of the Commonwealth as occupier of the premises and the power of the Judges of the Court, as a Superior Court of Record, to control entry on to the premises and the conduct of persons on the premises. The security measures have the approval of the Judges concerned.
(4) The average weekly payment to TNT is $7,972 for services at Sydney and Parramatta. These payments are authorised by the Parliament under Appropriation Division 170-2-05.
(5) Standing Orders for TNT personnel have been issued by the company following discussions with Family Court officials. They have not been made public.

(6) There are no written notes taken as a matter of routine by TNT personnel. A Log Book recording attendance is maintained by the TNT personnel. Any major incidents are to be reported by TNT to the Principal Registrar in writing and transcribed to the Court's normal security incident form. Security incident reports are used to analyse the extent of security threats with a view to providing appropriate responses. Such reports are kept indefinitely. Should a request for access under FOI legislation be received it will be considered in accordance with the relevant Act.

(7) There are a number of practical difficulties in administering the procedure of issue of permanent security passes to persons other than Judges and Court staff. The question of the issue of a limited number of permanent passes to persons having frequent business in the Court is being kept under notice.

(8) The Sydney and Parramatta Family Courts are the only Family Courts having these procedures in place each day. Other Family Courts may use them in response to a specific threat. I understand that some State Courts adopt similar practices when necessary. In many overseas courts, for example, in the United Kingdom and U.S.A., similar security measures are in continuous use.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 20 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the progress of negotiations for international agreements for the transfer of Australians serving terms in gaols of other countries to complete their sentence in Australia.
(2) When will the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General be considering the issue of implementing transfer arrangements.
(3) What is the progress of draft legislation and other arrangements for the transfer of Australians who are prisoners in overseas gaols.
(4) When will Australian prisoners, in overseas gaols, be able to be moved home.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Negotiations with other countries for international agreements have not commenced. The nature of the proposed scheme is still under consideration within the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.

(2) The Standing Committee of Attorneys-General considered the matter of international transfer of prisoners at its last meeting on 2 May 1985. At that meeting, it was decided that the Commonwealth would prepare revised proposals for the Committee's consideration. These would include ways of excluding serious drug offenders from the scheme.
(3) The drafting of enabling legislation has not commenced. It would not be appropriate to commence this until the nature of the scheme has been agreed.

(4) With the nature of the proposed scheme not yet agreed, it cannot be accurately predicted when prisoners, who might be eligible for transfer under the scheme, will be able to be transferred back to Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: In view of the comments in the final report of Special Prosecutor, R. V. Gyles, QC, on the role of certain banks in facilitating the activities of tax avoidance promoters by destroying records and refusing to co-operate with investigations, will the Attorney-General be acting on Mr Gyles's suggestion that compulsory powers may be necessary to make investigations in this area effective.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Upon the completion of Mr Gyles's term of appointment, the work being conducted in his Office was integrated into the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions Mr I. D. Temby, QC. Mr Temby established a Major Fraud Division to deal with the work conducted by Mr Gyles. Mr Temby personally conducted a major review of the operations of this work.

In relation to Mr Gyles's suggestion that the role of certain banks in facilitating the activities of tax avoidance should be the subject of a separate investigation, this matter was considered by Mr Temby at an early stage after the integration of Mr Gyles's Office. Upon the material available to Mr Temby, he was not prepared to recommend that additional and increased resources should be devoted to this task. This decision was made after taking into account the available evidence and the various competing priorities of outstanding bottom of the harbour investigations. This situation is, however, being kept under review and in the event that material which clearly demonstrates criminality comes to hand, the matter will be reassessed.
Additionally the Government has established a working group of officials to examine the question of controls on the operation of accounts with financial institutions and related matters.

The working group comprises representatives from the Departments of the Treasury, Prime Minister and Cabinet, Special Minister of State, the Attorney-General's Department, the Director of Public Prosecutions, the Australian Federal Police, and the Reserve Bank.

The working group is looking at the question of the retention of bank records for a minimum period, the provision by depositors of certain basic information on the opening of accounts and possible reporting requirements in respect of certain financial transactions. So far the working group has invited comments from industry groups such as financial institutions on how the implementation of greater control on bank records will affect their operations.
The Treasurer is to report to Cabinet on the working group's findings in the near future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 16 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the constitutional basis upon which the Government proposes to impose terms and conditions upon State governments in respect of the allocation and use of State land, in the context of its proposed national Aboriginal land rights legislation in view of the fact that the use and allocation of land within States has been the constitutional responsibility of the States.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: On 20 February 1985, the Government released the Preferred National Land Rights Model discussion paper. The Preferred Model provides the basis for consultations with the States and interested parties about national land rights legislation. The Preferred Model does not contemplate that terms and conditions will be imposed upon State Governments in respect of the allocation and use of State land. Indeed, as recognised in the Preferred Model, the co-operation of State Governments is welcomed in meeting the legitimate claims of the Aboriginal people for land ownership and the Commonwealth will not seek to override State land rights legislation that is compatible with the Preferred Model. Any Commonwealth law would, therefore, regulate the use of State land only in accordance with these principles and to the extent permitted by the Constitution. In this regard, the principal constitutional powers available to the Commonwealth Parliament are the power to make laws with respect to the people of any race for whom it is deemed necessary to make special laws (Constitution, s. 51 (xxvi)) and the power to legislate with respect to the acquisition of property on just terms from any State or person for any purpose in respect of which the Commonwealth Parliament has power to make laws (Constitution, s. 51 (xxxi)). I should, however, stress that the Commonwealth has not yet established a final position and, accordingly, the form and content of any Commonwealth legislation is yet to be determined.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 16 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: In view of the sustained fall in world prices of Arabian Light Crude Oil and recent devaluations of the Australian dollar, how does the Government justify continuing the world parity pricing of indigenous Australian oil.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The import parity pricing policy has been adopted by this, and previous, Governments as a means of providing encouragement for petroleum exploration and development and the efficient use of energy resources through petroleum conservation and its substitution by more plentiful energy resources.

The import parity price is based on the official price of Arab Light crude oil, converted to Australian dollars, and adjusted to reflect allowances for quality differentials, freight, insurance, loss, and wharfage. This formula ensures that Australian refiners pay prices for indigenous crude oil equal to its replacement value.

In March 1983 the official price of Arab Light was reduced by $US5 per barrel and again on 30 January 1985 by $US1 per barrel. These decreases in the official price of Arab Light have been incorporated in the Government's import parity pricing decisions, but movements in the $US/$A exchange rate have also had important effects on prices in Australian dollars. The substantial depreciation in the $A which has occurred over the past few months has been the cause of recent increases in the Australian price. I recall, however, that on 1 April 1983, 1 July 1983 and 1 January 1984 the price of indigenous crude oil was reduced as a result of either decreases in the price of Arab Light or favourable movements in the value of the $A.

It should also be noted that the Government has recently issued a discussion paper on 'A Modified Free Market for Indigenous Crude Oil' and is currently seeking comment from interested parties on this issue.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 18 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to a statement made in the Brisbane Sunday Mail on 24 March 1985 by the Queensland Minister for Welfare Services, Mr Muntz, in which he claims marriage breakdowns are hitting Australian taxpayers hard, and of a further claim by Mr Muntz that the Federal Government should spend more money towards marriage support instead of openly promoting 'easy divorce'.
(2) What is the cost of supporting the Family Court.
(3) Has the Family Court eliminated a great deal of misery within Australia, and swiftly ended marriages that clearly had no chance of lasting success.

(4) Has the Family Court saved litigants many thousands of dollars in legal costs that otherwise would have been frittered away chasing lost causes, and in doing so, restored happiness and security to men, women and children who would have otherwise been denied either of these essential factors.
(5) What has been the rate of divorces in Australia over the past three years.

(6) What can be the effects not only to the matrimonial couple but also any children of an unhappy and hopeless union by being forced to continue the relationship simply because the cost of parting is prohibitive.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Government provides considerable financial resources towards marriage support. In particular, it is aware that there has been increased demand on the services offered by approved marriage counselling organisations. Despite restraints on Government expenditure in recent years the level of funding made available for grants to these organisations has continued to increase. The increases in the last two years have been 10.99 per cent and 11.26 per cent respectively and these figures compare favourably with consumer price index increases of 6.9 per cent and a projected 5.25 per cent in the current year. In the 1984-85 financial year, the Government allocated $4,100,000 in grants to approved marriage counselling organisations and a further $85,000 to approved organisations for conducting programs of pre-marital education.
(2) My Department has identified the following estimated costs of supporting the Family Court of Australia and Family Court of Western Australia for the 1983-84 financial year-
$ Salaries of Judges of Family Court of Australia
3,080,000 Salaries of staff of Registries of Family Court of Australia
9,142,000 Administrative Overheads of Family Court of Australia (all expenses including superannuation, rent and rent equivalent costs)
8,563,000 Payment to Western Australia for Family Court of Western Australia
2,730,000 Commonwealth Reporting Service (all administrative expenses but excluding superannuation, rent and rent equivalent costs)
3,655,000 Payments to the States for preparation of Welfare Reports

(3) The Family Law Act, under which the Family Court of Australia was created, provided for a single ground of divorce of irretrievable breakdown of marriage evidenced by 12 months separation. It can be said that the Family Court of Australia has been able to reduce the distress suffered by people who before 1976 would have had to have waited a number of years before being able to obtain a divorce to secure legal recognition that their marriage was at an end.

(4) Before 1976, parties to a marriage were able to obtain a divorce on several grounds related to matrimonial misconduct (for example adultery, habitual cruelty). Proof of one of these grounds often involved a petitioning spouse incurring significant legal costs to no useful purpose save to satisfy the procedural requirements for his or her divorce. The Family Court of Australia is able to grant a divorce upon the present single ground which is relatively easy to establish and does not involve a judicial inquiry into the reasons behind the breakdown of the marriage.

(5) The Australian Bureau of Statistics, in its publication entitled 'Divorces Australia 1984', states the number of divorces in Australia and the crude divorce rate for Australia (that is, the number of divorces per 1000 of the mean Australian population) for the last three years are as follows-

(6) If the cost of obtaining a divorce were prohibitive, unhappy couples who wished to end their marriages would be likely to separate and not take steps to obtain legal recognition of the end of their relationship. This would result in a significant gap between recognition by Australian society, through its laws, of terminated marriages and marriages that have in fact broken down. It would not be in the interests of spouses or their children for this situation to exist.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What has the Australian Government done to show support for the right of a legitimate opposition in South Korea, given the treatment of Kim Dae Jung on his return to Seoul, during the election, and the restrictions still placed on him.
(2) Have Australian Government representatives misled Kim Dae Jung.

(3) Have there been any official visits to Seoul arranged by the Australian Government of such a kind as to make it clear to the Korean Government that Australia believes that a legitimate opposition exists and should exist.
(4) Has the Australian Government made any official representations to the South Korean Government expressing concern at the way Kim Dae Jung is being treated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In the twelve months prior to Mr Kim Dae Jung's return to the ROK on 8 February, the Government made representations three times to the ROK Government urging that his return should be without incident and without prejudice to the ROK's new forward-looking policies. It is pleasing to note that despite an incident at Seoul airport on his arrival Mr Kim's return to the ROK was in fact relatively incident free, and that he remains unharmed.

The outcome of the recent National Assembly elections, which included a healthy showing by the opposition, appears to be a sign of the development of the democratic political process in the ROK and, as such, is welcomed. Since the election, there has been a merger of opposition parties to give the major opposition party, with which Mr Kim Dae Jung is linked, a total of 102 seats in the National Assembly, as compared with the Government Party's 148 seats.

The ROK Government's announcement of 6 March that political bans would be removed from the remaining fourteen persons barred from political activity in the ROK was also welcomed. We understand that as a result of this, restrictions on movement and association which had been imposed on Mr Kim since his return were lifted. He is still constrained from forming or joining a political party because of his suspended gaol sentence, but the question of an amnesty for him is already under active discussion among political parties.
If a serious incident were to occur involving Mr Kim Dae Jung, the Australian Government would regard it with concern.

(3) No. The Government has however indicated that it welcomes the ROK's new forward looking policies of liberalisation, and has expressed the hope that the process will continue. Since the National Assembly elections in February this year, the Embassy has met and had extensive discussions with Government and opposition politicians, including Mr Kim Dae Jung.
- the Government did however make representations on three occasions in the twelve months prior to his return;
- his return has been relatively free and he is unharmed;
- if a serious incident involving Mr Kim Dae Jung were to occur, the Government would view it with concern.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 8 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the cost of the operation of the Freedom of Information Act (the Act) in the financial year 1983-84.
(2) Can details be provided of the costs of each aspect of the operation of the Act (that is, publicity, preparation of materials, etc.).
(3) What has been the cost of pursuing, from tribunals and courts, a clearer definition of the Act.
(4) What has been the actual cost of processing inquiries made under the Act, other than those costs in (1) to (3) above.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Attorney-General's Department receives information from agencies subject to the Act on the costs of the operation of the Act in each agency for the purpose of publication in the Attorney-General's Annual Report to Parliament on the operation of the Act. The Annual Report for 1983-84 was tabled in the Senate on 28 February 1985. As stated in that Report, the total costs identified by agencies for the 12-month period from 1 July 1983 to 30 June 1984 was $17,632,712.

(2) No records are kept in relation to the costs of each aspect of the operation of the Act. Agencies identified costs only in terms of staff costs and non-labour costs. For the 1983-84 financial year these were-
$ Estimated staff costs: (a) 16,961,634 Identified non-labour costs:
* printing 221,557 * training 144,473 * fees to legal counsel 74,897 * computer time 32,978 * other 197,173

(a) This figure is made up of $9,022,146 salary costs and on costs (or overheads) of $7,939,488 being 88 per cent of the salary costs. The on-cost allowance of 88 per cent was applied after consultation with the Public Service Board and the Department of Finance.

(3) All appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal are brought by applicants seeking review of a decision by a Minister or agency under the Act. Appeals to the Federal Court on questions of law are brought by both applicants and agencies. Records on the cost of defending appeals in the AAT and the Federal Court are not maintained. In the period since the Act commenced operation on 1 December 1982 to 30 April 1985, 369 applications have been made to the AAT and 172 are still outstanding. In the same period appeals to the Federal Court were lodged by five applicants and three agencies. Of these three are outstanding.
(4) See the answers to (1), (2) and (3) above.

(2) Have the standards referred to in (1) above remained the same for male and female applicants since the inception of the Australian Federal Police; if not, what changes have been made and with what purpose?

(3) In each of the years from July 1980, how many males and females, respectively, applied to enter the Australian Federal Police, how many were successful in each case and what are the most up-to-date figures for the current financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

Since members of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) are required to apprehend offenders it is essential that their locomotor capacity be perfectly normal. Applicants must be in good health and successfully undergo a medical examination by a police doctor.

Spectacles may be worn, but vision must be no less than 6/9 unaided each eye. Near vision-read 0.5D at 36-40 cms unaided. Visual fields normal. Colour perception normal with pseudoisochromatic charts (ISHIHARA).
The whispered voice should be understood at three metres, with the applicant standing side on to the examiner.

In September 1983 the minimum height requirements for males seeking entry into the General Policing Component was returned to 175 cm, for the following reasons:
(a) The lowering of the minimum height had not had any appreciable effect on attracting greater numbers of suitable male applicants;

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Imports of Shoddy or Dangerous Goods

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Attorney-General ensure that the new Office of Consumer Affairs liaises with the Australian Customs Service to block the entry of shoddy and/or dangerous goods at point of entry into Australia.
(2) Is the Attorney-General aware of the increasing instances of dangerous appliances and children's toys having to be recalled after accidents have occurred.
(3) Can the Attorney-General provide details on the number of reported accidents involving goods, referred to above, over the past three financial years.

(4) Can the Attorney-General identify the major offending countries exporting shoddy and/or dangerous goods to Australia and advise what action has been taken against these countries and their Australian importers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I can assure the honourable senator that the Office of Consumer Affairs will continue to liaise with the Australian Customs Service on the need to prohibit the entry of unsafe goods into Australia. Officers from Customs and Consumer Affairs have established close communication on product safety matters since the two areas split from the former Department of Business and Consumer Affairs in 1982.

(2) I am not aware of any increase in the instances of products being recalled after accidents have occurred. The number of products being reported by State and Territory consumer affairs agencies as allegedly unsafe has remained at approximately 80 per year. I would appreciate any details the honourable senator may be able to provide on this matter to illustrate the apparent increase.

(3) I am unable to provide details on the number of reported accidents involving goods as there is not an injury surveillance system operating in Australia at the current time. A feasibility study into the operation of such a system has been undertaken by the Child Accident Prevention Foundation of Australia. The Office of Consumer Affairs is liaising with the Foundation on the establishment of a pilot study for an all-age, all-injury reporting system. It is hoped this injury reporting system will be operational by the 1986-87 financial year.

(4) The source of goods which have been the subject of legislative control under the Trade Practices Act cannot be narrowed to one or two countries. The range of products controlled is varied, as is their source.

Dangerous goods are banned from sale by Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers. Importers in Australia are directly subject to banning orders and the exporter, in turn, would suffer loss of sales to Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 10 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister urgently investigate allegations made in Queensland State Parliament on 7 March 1985 that a 'Mr Rand regularly flies between 'Silver Plains' (on Cape York Peninsula) and Honolulu without having a customs or immigration clearance'.

(2) Could the Minister inquire into the following statement made by Mr Glasson, Minister for Lands, Forestry and Police and confirm or deny the allegation contained in it: 'Police inquiries revealed that Mr Rand has undertaken numerous overseas flights between 1973 and 1983, but again no evidence of any offence in this State has been disclosed relating to these trips. The Commissioner of Police is unable to say whether any of these trips were made without customs or immigration clearance. However, this would be a matter for the appropriate federal departments. While there is no evidence at this stage to directly involve Mr Rand in any unlawful activities, you may rest assured that all possible action will be taken should evidence be forthcoming to support a prosecution'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I am advised by the Australian Federal Police that this is not a matter for investigation by them. I note that the honourable senator has addressed a similar question to my colleague, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. May I suggest she also seek information from my colleague, who is responsible for the Australian Customs Service, namely, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 14 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has a report entitled 'Preliminary Report on the Study of Off-spring of Tasmanian Vietnam Veterans' been tendered to the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam.
(2) Has the report referred to in (1) above been prepared by Professor Charles Kerr of the School of Tropical Medicine in the Commonwealth Institute of Health and Dr Barbara Field.
(3) Referring to the report in (1) above: (a) who has the right to publish the report; (b) who paid for the production of the report; and (c) when will the report be made public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A report marked 'Confidential' and entitled 'Preliminary Report On The Tasmanian Veterans' Study' was tendered to the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam on 27 May 1985. The Royal Commission gave this report exhibit No. 1932.

(2) Statements made to the Royal Commission by Professor C. B. Kerr and Dr B. R. Field show that the preliminary report referred to in (1) above was prepared by Professor Kerr and Dr Field from data made available by the VVAA.
(3) (a) I do not know who has the right to publish the report in (1) above. However, please see (c) below.
(b) I understand that evidence was given at the Royal Commission hearing that costs incurred in the report's production were met from VVAA funds to which the Government has contributed.

(c) At the conclusion of the hearing of the Royal Commission on 28 May 1985 it was indicated that this document may no longer have any status, as one of its authors, Dr Field, sought to have it torn up. I cannot indicate the present status of the document.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government aware of reports that cholera has broken out in a number of refugee camps in Ethiopia.
(2) Can the Government confirm the report referred to in (1) above, and if so, what measures does the Government intend to take in order to alleviate the suffering of these people.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government is aware that the risk of outbreaks of cholera in Ethiopia has been and remains high, and is apparently worst in the border area with Somalia where there are substantial refugee populations. I understand that cases of cholera have also occurred in a number of famine relief centres in drought affected areas but that the Ethiopian authorities and non government organisations have usually been able to react quickly and to contain the disease.

(2) The Government is naturally concerned not only that cholera victims should receive adequate and rapid treatment but also that the more difficult problem of preventing the disease should be tackled. Together with other major aid donors, Australia made these concerns known to the Ethiopian Government and in particular to the Chief Commissioner of the Ethiopian Government's Relief and Rehabilitation Committee, Mr Dawit. In addition, Australia has provided over $1m in medical supplies and personnel to a number of non government organisations including ICRC and the Australian Red Cross, and UNICEF, for the purpose of alleviating the risk of disease in famine relief and refugee centres as part of its total relief aid package of $26m to Ethiopia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 February 1985 (Hansard, page 325) Senator Cooney asked me as the Minister representing the Attorney-General the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has any analysis been made by the Attorney-General's Department on any trend since 1970 in firstly, the number of regulations made under Commonwealth legislation providing for monetary or custodial penalties or both where the onus of proof is cast on the person accused, secondly, the number of convictions recorded under such regulations, and, finally, the penalties imposed as a result of such convictions? If the answer is yes, is such analysis available? If the answer is no, is there any plan to carry out such analysis and make it available?
The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

No analysis has been made by the Attorney-General's Department of any trend since 1970 in the number of regulations made under Commonwealth legislation providing for monetary or custodial penalties or both where the onus of proof is cast on the person accused. Nor is there any record of the number of convictions recorded under such regulations or the penalties imposed as a result of such convictions. There is no plan to carry out any such analysis, since, in light of other competing priorities, departmental resources are not sufficient to enable officers to be allocated to that task. In this regard I also reiterate and fully endorse the comments made by my colleague Senator Gareth Evans, in his capacity as my representative in the Senate, in response to a question without notice from Senator Crichton-Browne on 22 May 1985 (Hansard, page 2334) concerning the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on 'The Burden of Proof in Criminal Proceedings'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 May 1985 (Hansard, page 1752) Senator Macklin asked Senator Ryan, as Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the following question:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer to the tendering on 20 November last year to the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam of a list purporting to be a list of Vietnam veterans who have died since the Vietnam war. Was that a true and accurate list of the figures held by the Department of Defence at that date? Is there any evidence that the Department misled the Commission in the tendering of that list?
The Department of Veterans' Affairs has furnished the following information:
No list of names of Vietnam veterans was provided by the Department of Veterans' Affairs to the Evatt Royal Commission on 20 November 1984.

The Department provided data on deceased Vietnam veterans to the Royal Commission on 23 November and 26 November 1984. Some of that material was eventually tendered to the Royal Commissioner by those assisting him and received exhibit numbers. The material did not purport to be a list of the figures or the names of Vietnam veterans held by the Department of Defence on a particular date. However, part of the material was a listing of names which were common to the Department of Defence nominal roll and to a list prepared by the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia.

After the material was provided by the Department, it was found that the name of one veteran whose deceased status was known at the time to the officer compiling the material was omitted from a list of 834 names given to the Royal Commission. However, that same list contained the names of four veterans now known not to have served in Vietnam. These facts and the reasons for them were explained to the Royal Commission as soon as they were known.
